This semi-fluid, half-lotion serum brings together a trio of hyaluronic acid, the benchmark molecule approved by dermatologists and used in optimum concentrations to effectively act on crepey and wrinkled skin. Hyaluronic acid helps to maintain optimum levels of hydration within the skin by trapping water in deep layers, in the same way as a sponge, strengthening skin cohesion and increasing firmness. Over time, hyaluronic acid contained in the body decreases by half, making WRINKLE DIMENSION an appropriate year-round solution to provide maturing and wrinkled skin with a perfect supply of hyaluronic acid for an instantly rejuvenating effect. \n \nWRINKLES DIMENSION HYALURONIC ACID CONCENTRATE\u202615 ml, suggested retail price $100.50 \n \nDirections for use: apply several drops before face cream, morning and evening. \n \nKey ingredients: \n \n\u2022Hyaluronic Acid Trio: \n\n Encapsulated High Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid \u2013 deep wrinkles are filled and hollow areas are volumized thanks to the strategic shape and controlled release of ingredient.  Low Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid \u2013 small molecules of hyaluronic acid penetrate skin layers, swell on contact with water and accumulate to fill fine lines, smoothing surface wrinkles.  High Molecular Weight Hyaluronic Acid \u2013 plays a vital role in regulating skin hydration thanks to its strong water-retaining power. Skin is moisturized and transepidermal water loss is stopped.  \nVie Collection at a glance : \n\nAs a cosmeceutical expert in the spa industry, Vie Collection is a high performance, high-end skin care line focused on bridging the gap between traditional cosmetics and esthetic medicine. Vie Collection has targeted, non-invasive and clinically proven alternatives and complements to the top five cosmetic medicine procedures available today. JoyFLIPS is also a semi-finalist in the annual Innovator Showdown competition to be held during the conference. \n \nAttendance at the conference is not necessary to win. Our technology provides the tools to scan, preserve and share thousands of print photos, and to pass down the stories they tell through storytelling in voice and text. We then automatically connect these stories to related historical media from numerous sources. In addition to showing Miller\u2019s paintings, Art Ventures will exhibit a suite of drawings, drenched in mystery and never before published. Combined with the dreamlike magic of his paintings, these drawings provide glimpses of something mystic and profound. Paton Miller will be attending the opening February 1st, and will be available for media interviews, upon appointment. \n \nAccording to Art Ventures Gallery Director Katharina Powers, \u201cWhat strikes me looking at Paton Miller\u2019s artwork is the purity of his dramatic landscapes. Paton provides an antidote to the so-called \u201cfilter bubble\u201d in which this generation, growing up with the Internet, lives. Paton\u2019s work provides a respite from the Internet and takes us out of algorithmized isolation. He takes us on a journey, and shows us what life is about.\u201d \n \nWriting in Art News, noted critic Donald Kuspit, said about Paton Miller\u2019s work, \u201cThese pictures make clear a familiar, but often forgotten point: that the expressivity of a representational scene often depends upon the abstract intensity generated in response to the medium. Without this visionary intensity, representational painting can become a kind of perceptual journalism. It becomes all the more important when the artist is picturing inner rather than overt horror. The achievement of ecstatic abstractness also indicates that the artist is master of the scene, rather than overwhelmed by what she or he is rendering \u2014 to make it appear magically upon command, which is what Miller\u2019s version of realism does.\u201d \n \nPaton Miller\u2019s work has been awarded the Painting Award at the Florence Biennale and is in public collections at American Embassy in Abu Dhabi and Bogotá, Colombia. Recent exhibitions include shows at White Room Gallery, NYC; Gallery Shchunkin, NYC; Galerie Yoram Gil, Beverly Hills; and Horwitch Newman Gallery, Scottsdale, AZ. \n \nFollowing the opening of his exhibit at the Art Ventures Gallery in Menlo Park, Miller will be in residence at the Art Ventures studio in Saint Helena from July through August. While there, Miller can engage with other visiting artists in the residency program, and create new work. In a program unique in the Bay Area art world, Art Ventures invites rising art stars from Europe to work shoulder to shoulder with their Californian colleagues in a purpose-built painting studio. Following their studio residency artists are invited to curate their own solo show at the Art Ventures Gallery exhibition space. \n \nThe result is groundbreaking: part exhibition space and part art movement. \n \nFor more information about Paton Miller and Art Ventures Gallery email info(at)artventuresgallery(dot)com \n\nArt Ventures Gallery is located at 888 Santa Cruz Avenue, Menlo Park, CA 94025. Paton Millers Artwork will be on display from February 1, 2017 through February 25. A reception for the artist will be held at Art Ventures Gallery Wednesday, February 1, from 5 pm to 7 pm. All press and media are welcome. \n \nFor the original version on PRWeb visit: http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/01/prweb140231","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Top News US Full Feed"},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: fine arts news","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Finance latest","group":"Finance"}],"title":"Art Ventures Gallery Announces Inaugural Exhibition, Against (the) Algorithm\u2014Around The World In 40 Years","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"SSUChronicle.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"606907479","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"14"},"name":"SSUChronicle.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Financials"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.ssuchronicle.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/01/prweb14023107.htm","http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/01/prweb140231"],"sequenceId":"695204584245","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:37Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

However; the invisible potentiality is unlimited and infinite. The high conscious intelligence continues its path to infinite potentiality to everlasting-limitless universe. \n \nDeRu further explained: \"Zen sees the reality of potentiality is in the emptiness within and between the visible worlds. It is that emptiness of potentiality makes the universe going with consistent and constant expanding in infinity.\" \n \nThis is how the Zen Master sees the world, \"The high conscious mind of the universe guides and decides the direction of the universe expansion and development. When one follows the heart of the high conscious universe, one believes and achieves one\u2019s dream with unwavering faith and confidence. One will eventually be intotal communication and merge with that of infinite oneness.\" \n \n\u201cIt is that Zen mind propagates and instigates Imagination which opens the 3rd eye to vision the infinite Potentiality of the true reality of the universe.\" according to DeRu. \u201cWe are all part of, and microcosm of the universe. Our body particles are universal participles and our atoms are part of the universe atoms. Zen Master DeRu sees Quantum theory along with scientific experiment of quantum physics gives lights, like taking many pictorial shots of reality of the world, to ordinary conscious beings, believers and non believers alike to observe and see the truth of the world, and the conscious universe in communication and expansion with unlimited potentiality without time or space limitations. \n \nDeRu firmly believes, \"In that Zen world one begins to see, In lieu of the fittest and fiercest fight for victory and survival with competitiveness from the selected few, humanity leading all conscious beings together claim victory by synergy and cooperation with compassion and love.\u201d \n \nDeRu maintains, \"war and fierce competition is for ignorant self-serving few, leading to self-destruction, it is, he said, the synergy in peace with harmony in cooperation leading all beings to greater development in advancement of conscious beings.\" \n \n\"Leaving Newton as a hero of the past,\" he insists, \"we must move on, following vision of the Ancient Chan in all conscious, subconscious and superconscious communication, human beings shall explore further. seeing beyond and through that visible illusionary world into that true universe intelligence and wisdom, and see the true potential world beyond time and space with the guidance of Albert Einstein, Max Planck and Niels Bohr\u2019s scientific minds.\" \n \nMaster Shi DeRu a 31 generation Shaolin Chan (Zen) Master has been teaching Living Zen Mind and Zen meditation with TaGong for over three decades worldwide, especially in China and the US. \n \nHe has been hosting his Annual Qi Retreat in the US for the last two decades with various theme topics on health and happy living. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395306587","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"STADIUMS & ARENAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"BASKETBALL","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"OAKLAND, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"LOS ANGELES, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"510","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396206170&p=2kx&v=1&x=3hSMe-J1eR5lS5IRRKRylA","id":"29396206170","content":"OAKLAND, Calif. - Doc Rivers has been sick for three weeks, the Los Angeles Clippers coach's strength so sapped on Saturday evening that he rarely stood while his team was getting demolished, 144-98, by the Golden State Warriors at Oracle Arena. \n\nWhen Rivers did stand a few times, there were so many things to admonish his team about that it probably just made him weaker by the moment, the Clippers offering so little resistance that they allowed a season high in points and suffered their most one-sided loss this season. \n\n\"I thought we gave in way too easy,\" Rivers said. \"You should never lose by this much in any game, in any situation. But they're better right now. Until we improve, they're going to keep beating us.\" \n\nRivers mostly sat and witnessed his team go down in the third quarter under an avalanche of Stephen Curry three-point slings and Warriors points that sent the Clippers to their eighth consecutive defeat to Golden State. \n\n\"If I won eight games in a row, I would have a mental edge,\" Rivers said. \n\nCurry, supposedly playing with a sore left quadriceps, detonated for 25 of his 43 points in the third quarter. He was five for eight from three-point range in the period, during which he seemed to be playing alone. \n\nFor the game he was 15 for 23 from the field, nine for 15 from three-point range. \n\nOf all the 72 points the Clippers surrendered in the first half, the most painful had to be when Curry eased up the court and casually and knowingly hoisted a three-pointer from half court that splashed through the net as the halftime buzzer sounded. \n\nThe fans went crazy. The Warriors celebrated, none more so than Draymond Green, who chest-bumped Curry so hard he fell on the court. Curry stayed on his belly for a few seconds, his arms extended. \n\nThe Clippers could only solemnly trudge to their locker room. \n\n\"We can talk about, like, being who we are. But who are we?\" Clippers guard J.J. Redick said. \"To me, we're the most inconsistent team, maybe in the league. Like, we're inconsistent. That's who we are. So, like, if we're going to be inconsistent, we can't expect to come in here and play these guys and be inconsistent and play well. It's not realistic.\" \n\nThe Clippers have lost four of five games since point guard Chris Paul had surgery for a torn thumb ligament that is expected to sideline him six to eight weeks. \n\nBut they will see the Warriors again Thursday night at Staples Center knowing it's going to take a better effort than this one. \n\nBlake Griffin, in his second game back after missing 18 games following right knee surgery, had 20 points for a Clippers team that was never in this game. \n\nThe total destruction by the Warriors notwithstanding, Rivers has been unsure what has put him in a weakened state. \n\n\"It has been three weeks now, so it's not been a fun stretch,\" he said. \"I'll get through it. I just want to find out what the hell it is to be honest.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"BRODERICK TURNERLos Angeles Times"},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: NBA - Golden State Warriors news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: NBA - Los Angeles Clippers news","group":"Sports Teams"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: latest scores","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Curry, Warriors clobber Clippers, 144-98","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Sacramento","zipCode":"95816","state":"California","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Sacramento","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Sacramento Bee","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169672618","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4516"},"name":"Sacramento Bee","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Basketball","Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.sacbee.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204586308","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29373734041","companies":[{"symbol":"BQC","primary":true,"name":"A-Smart Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"SES","titleCount":0,"isin":"SG1G74871706"},{"symbol":"BQC","primary":true,"name":"A-Smart Holdings Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"SG1G74871706"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"CLERGY & RELIGIOUS VOCATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"REFERENDUMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"65"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"CONSERVATISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"61"},{"name":"CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BREXIT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LIBERALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION INSTITUTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"LONDON, ENGLAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BRUSSELS, BELGIUM; BELGIUM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"68"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"88"},{"name":"BELGIUM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"68"}],"wordCount":"2447","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396206176&p=2kx&v=1&x=m1unI0RU3So0Sh47Y29mcQ","id":"29396206176","content":"\"The stupid are cocksure while the intelligent are full of doubt,\" said Bertrand Russell of the populist wave of the 1930s. If Britain\u2019s agonised liberal elite think of any of the Brexiters as cocksure, the name Daniel Hannan would surely top the list. The Conservative MEP is the high priest of Eurosceptics \u2014 a stiff Shakespeare-obsessive for whom self-doubt would appear to come as naturally as a double-backflip. \n \nFlip through one of Hannan\u2019s many eloquent books, and you will find a dreamy blueprint for Brexit. In this world the clouds of negotiations clear, parliamentary supremacy shines, and we \"stride into the sunlight\". \n \n\"I\u2019d probably been planning for [Brexit] longer than almost anyone,\" he tells me at one point over lunch. Later he adds: \"I just think there is so much irrational pessimism in the world.\" \n \nSome politicians are Marmite. Hannan is acupuncture \u2014 you either believe in him or you don\u2019t, in which case it all feels needlessly painful. The liberal New Statesman magazine has a regular column, \"What is Daniel Hannan demonstrably wrong about this week?\" ; it is still to run short of material. Even some on his own side are wary of his obsessiveness. Senior figures in Vote Leave, the official Out campaign in June\u2019s referendum, scornfully labelled him \"the world\u2019s greatest debater\", and left him out of the big televised showdowns. \"We tried to keep him away from important decisions,\" said one. \n \nAnd yet Hannan, 45, was unquestionably central to the biggest decision of all. When he started as a student activist in the early 1990s, leaving the EU was a fringe movement; he helped turn it into mainstream Conservative thinking. \"He persuaded the Conservative party person by person,\" says a friend. \"His genius is persuading people, without them realising they\u2019re being persuaded.\" I\u2019m not sure how they don\u2019t realise: I\u2019ve met suited men with cropped hair and name badges who are less evangelical. \n \nAlmost before sitting down, Hannan is detailing his methods. \"Politics is didactic,\" he starts. I quickly order a glass of wine. \"Not for me, I\u2019ve got a very busy day,\" he says. The European Parliament will not wreck itself. \n  \nBrussels is the belly of Hannan\u2019s beast, home to the tens of thousands of bureaucrats and politicians who run the European Union. But he actually quite likes the place. \"First of all, the food is very good,\" he says, before moving on to the \"very affordable\" housing \u2014 and an obligatory moan about the weather. \"There is 30 per cent more rainfall here than in London, which is a lot if you think about it. Awful lot.\" \n \nWe are in a chic neighbourhood dotted with Art Deco and Art Nouveau façades, a couple of miles from the EU institutions. Hannan and his family used to live nearby; his daughters attended one of the European Schools free for EU employees. \"I\u2019ve tried to stop using Brussels as a shorthand for what I don\u2019t like about the EU. It\u2019s a slur against this really rather handsome and good-tempered town,\" he says. Later he confesses the only English thing he really missed was the countryside. \n \nThe restaurant consists of eight simple tables, tiled floors and walls, and two huge windows overlooking a quiet crossroads. It\u2019s perfect, I think, before Hannan points out the old meat hooks near the ceiling. \"It used to be a butcher\u2019s, as you can see.\" A non-meat-eater, I belatedly recognise the type of continental restaurant where the first six letters of végétarien are silent.\" \n \nThe first two of the main courses are steak,\" says Hannan, translating the menu. \"Then breast of duck. \u2026 veal sweetbread. \u2026 normal veal with mushrooms.. .\" \n \nI\u2019ve absolutely no idea where Culoiseau is,\" he continues, raising my spirits momentarily, \"but I\u2019d imagine La Poularde de Culoiseau is some kind of chicken.\" \n \nSod it: as Sarah Palin put it, if God had not intended for us to eat animals, how come he made them out of meat? I swallow hard, and order the only bloodless thing on the menu \u2014 a poached egg with mushrooms \u2014 followed by something random I can pronounce. To my slight horror, it turns out to be veal sweetbread. Hannan goes for the poached egg and the duck. \n \nLike all ardent patriots, Hannan grew up abroad \u2014 he is possibly the most famous Peruvian immigrant in London since Paddington. His mother was a diplomat, his father an expat farmer threatened with expropriation. The experience pushed him towards conservatism, even before he started at a British public school. It was Enoch Powell who first inspired Hannan to question Brussels, and the Maastricht treaty that convinced him Britain needed to leave. As a history student at Oxford, he wrote furiously against the Exchange Rate Mechanism. When the Conservative party signed up to it, he concluded the experts didn\u2019t always know best. \"Nobody likes a smart alec,\" he sighs. \"Which is why it\u2019s always better for your career to be wrong and in company rather than right and on your own.\" \n \nHannan is still a relative loner. His version of Brexit-wooing Remainers, staying within the European Free Trade Association, criticising Donald Trump \u2014 contrasts sharply with the nativism of Nigel Farage. His latest book, What Next, sets out his agenda for Brexit Britain \u2014 including free trade, tax cuts, low regulation, localism and direct democracy. These Singapore-style reforms are \"by far the most important\" part of Brexit, he claims; they bear some resemblance to what Theresa May has threatened, if Britain is unable to secure a favourable deal with the EU. \n \nWhat changes would he have made to the prime minister\u2019s long-awaited Brexit speech, delivered earlier this month? \"I don\u2019t think I would have changed it at all,\" he says. \n \nThe eggs arrive, swimming in gravy, mushrooms and, I should have guessed, bacon. Our waitress smiles proudly. \n \nThe emerging history of the referendum is that David Cameron could easily have won, with luck and a better campaign. For Hannan, that presents an opportunity. \"An awful lot of people were quite close to that middle point, and it was quite a marginal decision which way they went. That\u2019s why I don\u2019t think it\u2019s true there\u2019s this unbridgeable gap or schism. It is possible to construct a relationship with the rest of the EU that will satisfy the vast majority.\" \n \nHis confidence is piercing. Has he never doubted his ideas? \"I always had a bottom line. Had the PM come back with a deal that set the precedent that we could bring powers back, I\u2019d have been happy with that.\" \n \nIt was easy for the Leave campaign to criticise Cameron, I suggest \u2014 you\u2019ve never had to hold power. Only a few Hannan ideas have been put to the test. One was a proposal for elected sheriffs \u2014 now in place as police and crime commissioners. Turnout at the last elections averaged 27 per cent, making it the only office to provoke more apathy than the European Parliament.\" \n \nYeaaah,\" says Hannan, cautiously. \"What is it Prospero says, \u2018This thing of darkness I acknowledge mine?\u2019 \" He blames \"the implementation\", including the \"terrible name\". \"Focus groups said sheriffs sounded too American. Which is the most depressing comment on our lack of interest in our history. I mean, where the hell do they think the Americans got the name from?\" \n \nIt is a rare flash of Hannan\u2019s humour. Soon he is serious again, defending his record. He was bearish on the euro, bullish on the British economy after the Brexit vote, and opposed to rescuing the banks in 2008. \"I would argue that what we are seeing throughout Europe and throughout the west \u2014 Trump, Bernie Sanders, Marine Le Pen, Geert Wilders, Syriza, Podemos \u2014 are all delayed reactions to the bank bailouts, the delegitimisation of the market system,\" he says. \n \nI\u2019m not sure I follow, but by now I am more engaged trying to cut through the fat of the sweetbread. Hannan, in contrast, remains focused.\" \n \nI was reading a report by some German economists about how financial crises are different from a normal economic downturn. \u2026 They studied every financial crisis from 1870 in 20 different countries \u2014 France, US, Switzerland, you know \u2014 they said they always saw a massive bump in populist politics, on the left and on the right. There\u2019s always a move towards a fairly authoritarian mood, which doesn\u2019t happen in a normal recession.\" \n \nThe relatively good news is that it has an end. I would say we\u2019re seeing that end already, the glimmerings of it, in Greece. Greece began the cycle before anybody else, and Tsipras is now breaking records for unpopularity.\" \n \nHannan\u2019s chips and beans are untouched. The remains of his duck are large enough to fly away. \n \nHow will Trump\u2019s presidency unfold, I ask. \"The US, you could argue, was precisely designed to contain the ambitions of a Caligulan leader. The founders had someone very like him in mind.\" \n \nWell, the founders didn\u2019t have in mind that the US would be a nuclear-armed superpower. \"No. But other than their foreign policy, there are quite delineated powers. \u2026 Put it like this, if he were to behave unconstitutionally, or if he were to show utter unfitness in office, there is a majority for impeachment in both chambers. If there\u2019s one thing that will exert any restraint, it will be that.\" \n \nLater I ask how opponents of Trump and Le Pen might speed up their defeat.\" \n \nThe populists always fail in their own terms,\" Hannan begins. Aha, so Brexit \u2014 \"Let me be more specific, the protectionists always fail. They always end up delivering the sharpest fall in living standards to the people who are their biggest supporters.\" \n  \nI pop down the stairs to the loo. When I return Hannan is staring gleefully at a Twitter ruckus on his iPhone. He puts his phone to one side, revealing its Union Flag case. \n \nIn his book he calls for parliament to vote each year on how many migrants to allow into the UK. How many would he favour, I ask. \"I\u2019m in favour of a more liberal policy when it comes to high-skilled workers. I\u2019d also take students out of [the numbers].\" \n \nSo how many? \"There is going to be some reduction anyway, because the whole remittance value of zlotys from a British income is not what it was. \u2026 The only two changes I\u2019d make is a requirement that you had a job before you came. \u2026 And I would take complete control back on benefits: I\u2019d have a moratorium before you start paying.\" So you think parliament should vote on a number, but you don\u2019t have one in mind? \"It would vary year by year, but no.\" \n \nHe moves on to refugees, which he sees as being a huge issue for \"the next 50 years\". In 2015 he spent time at an Italian hostel for migrants who had arrived via Africa. \"Every country in the world has got to find some way of determining how to regulate an almost unlimited flow of people who will come in claiming refugee status. These are not people coming from Syria.\" \n \nDoes this mean pulling out of the 1951 refugee convention that commits the UK to allowing people to claim for asylum? He is open to persuasion on this but wonders if we shouldn\u2019t \"just be honest about the fact that it\u2019s arbitrary and say we will give the home secretary discretion over admitting 15,000 people a year or whatever. It\u2019s going to be terribly unfair to number 15,001 but every system will be unfair to somebody. This is at least one where it\u2019s rational.\" \n \nThe waitress offers pudding. Hannan wants mint tea, but I need sustenance. \n \nWe\u2019ve been here nearly two hours, and Hannan has dispatched his tie, undone two shirt buttons, pulled out his chair. Yet his manner remains formal. When I ask if there\u2019s another side to him \u2014 away from determined argument \u2014 he cites how he recently tested his \"strong conviction that lime is almost always superior to lemon in any sweet or savoury situation\". \n \n\"On Sunday afternoon I performed a controlled experiment \u2014 I got exactly the same [lemon drizzle] cake mix, and I did a blind tasting. \u2026 sure enough, lime won, three votes to one!\" Perhaps direct democracy will save us after all. \n \nBy now I am finding Hannan\u2019s obstinacy strangely provocative. How do we hold you accountable if Brexit doesn\u2019t work, I ask. \"I\u2019m not sure how you\u2019d define \u2018doesn\u2019t work\u2019.\" If £350m a week isn\u2019t available for public services? \"It is perfectly legitimate to cite the gross figure in politics. \u2026 That\u2019s the normal way. \u2026 \" Not really, I say, during the campaign you also said that Britain had created more jobs than the rest of the EU put together. That was a net figure including Germany (lots of jobs created) and Greece (lots of jobs lost). \"Overall people can look up the figures and decide whether they think it\u2019s fair.\" \n \nPerhaps the question is, for people claiming to restore trust in democracy, didn\u2019t the Leave campaign just damage it massively? \"Find me any referendum in the world where people haven\u2019t tried to fight tactically as well. \u2026 Both sides did that.\" \n \nDessert arrives \u2014 a mountain of Chantilly cream, a monument to the common agricultural policy. Using a long spoon, I confirm the absence of bacon. \n \nI turn to Hannan\u2019s future. He started in Brussels convinced that Tony Blair would try to take the UK into the euro. \"I was assuming things would come to a head much earlier than they actually did. \u2026 I wish I\u2019d done other things in retrospect.\" \n \nHis inclination now is to make up for lost time and he is considering leaving politics when his term expires in 2019. \"I could teach, I could write, I could go into business, I could go back to journalism,\" he suggests. In his early years as a MEP he wrote leaders for the Daily Telegraph, where he cut a tweedy figure and was known as a young fogey with adamantine right-wing views. \n \nWouldn\u2019t he miss it all? The Twitter spats with left-wingers? The media appearances? \"I really wouldn\u2019t!\" he protests, possibly too much. \"When you make a film, you need lots of different people with different skillsets \u2014 the producer, the director. \u2026 \" he reflects. \"I\u2019m happier as a scriptwriter than an actor.\" \n \nThe exhausting maelstrom of the referendum has exacted a price. \"There\u2019s a brilliant, brilliant Emily Dickinson poem about how common to be somebody. You know, I\u2019d like to be nobody, how common to be somebody.\" He pauses. \"I think of that \u2014 often.\" \n \nFor the moment Hannan is somebody, and a driver has pulled up outside to ferry him back to euroland. \"Do you need a lift?\" he asks. \"That\u2019s very kind,\" I say, but perhaps, like him, what I really need is a break. \n \n\u2022 The writer is an FT political correspondent \n \n© The Financial Times 2","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"European Union news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Europe news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Belgium news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"},{"name":"UK business news","group":"Business"}],"title":"LUNCH WITH THE FT: Conservative MEP Daniel Hannan on what Britain should do next","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Southern Africa","countryCode":"ZA","country":"South Africa"},"editorialRank":"1","name":"Business Live South Africa","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"229948990","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"5"},"name":"Business Live South Africa","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Politics","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://businesslive.co.za","publisher":"BDFM"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204586619","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T00:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

In addition, foreign nationals from those countries with valid visas, green cards, or other entry documents should consider returning to the United States immediately before the signing of this Executive Order. Other countries could also be added. \n \nNote that the proposed order bars entry to the U.S. even if the foreign national has a valid visa, Temporary Protected Status, Lawful Permanent Resident (green card) status, or any other entry document. \n \nSenior Partner and Immigration Attorney, Jeff Joseph, stated, \"Pure and simple, President Trump's draft executive order is a thinly veiled effort to scapegoat Muslims and will not make America safer. Banning travel for people based solely on the country they are from even after they have already been vetted by immigration is ineffective and overreaching. We should focus our attention on people for whom we have actual grounds for concern or suspicion. President Trump is basing these policies on a combination of an unfounded fear, debunked information, and xenophobic pressures.\" \n \nPresidential Executive Order: Protecting the Nation From Terrorist Attacks by Foreign Nationals \n \nhttp://www.aila.org/infonet/wh-protecting-the-nation-from-terrorist-attacks \n \nAn unsigned copy of the Executive Order issued by President Trump on January 27, 2017, titled Protecting the Nation from Terrorist Entry into the United States by Foreign Nationals. \n\nAILA Doc. And is now expanding in California. \n \nBayonne, New Jersey. (PRWEB) January 29, 2017 \n \nQuartz Master is a quartz surfaces manufacturer, headquartered in Bayonne, New Jersey. The company produces the highest quality and largest quartz slabs in the industry. It distributes through many select locations in US and Montreal, Quebec, Canada. And is now expanding in California. \n \nThe demand for Quartz Master\u2019s Marble Collection prompted the company to open its first distribution center in California. In June 2016, Quartz Master opened its new 6500 square foot warehouse in Los Angeles to serve Los Angeles County. But within a couple of months, the distribution center was making deliveries to fabricators from as far south as San Diego to as far north as San Francisco. \n \nWhen it opened, the warehouse was stocked with a modest number of slabs, but within weeks it had to be restocked to meet demands. It now has millions in inventory. On January 2nd, they opened an office in San Diego, and on February 1st, an additional warehouse will open in San Francisco on Mariposa Avenue in Mountain View. \n \nQuartz Master is recognized for its Marble Collection. In 2011, after 12 months of laborious engineering, Quartz Master introduced the world\u2019s first marble design to Quartz. And in 2014, they perfected the art of book matching. Today, most all of their marble designs are book matched. Homeowners and interior designers appreciate the low maintenance, durability and unmatched stain resistance of quartz. And they love that they can design a kitchen that has the beauty of natural stone without the expense and hassle. \n \nTo meet demand and high-quality customer service, Quartz Master will have representatives throughout the state, who will supply showrooms, interior designers, and fabricators with samples and customer service. \n \nAbout Quartz Master \n\nQuartz Master is a world\u2019s experts of quartz surfaces. Quartz Master\u2019s slabs are made of 93% natural quartz and 7% resin, making it the hardest, most durable and non-precious stone in the market. It guides the reader to get to the root of blockages like excess poundage, release the cause of what was keeping her stuck, to get to that new job, new outfit, new healthy relationship or new health regime. Her book is readily available on Kindle, Amazon, CreateSpace and http://www.padaran.com for easy reading under the category of self-help, personal transformation, and self-help, motivational. Her book\u2019s official launch date is February 11, 2017. \n \nDaya was in a near death car accident and could no longer continue her work as a Yoga instructor or prepare her own food for the family. She had to rely on what the three males in the house could prepare for her, which were often fast foods. While no Yoga or exercise was possible for a very long time, she chose to exercise in her mind using tools she had learned previously in her study of yoga and fitness. This reinforced her understanding of the power of thought, particularly strong before, during and after sleeping, in transforming our reality. \n \nThere is an inherited gift of Creative Mind that is available to each of us. Our Maker is always in Total Agreement with whatever thoughts are held and entertained as truth. Consider these points from Daya's book. \n\n The power and knowledge to work with thoughts and utilize them to transform reality is always available. Consciousness is it! It creates the world from within to without, from mind to manifestation.  Ego uses guilt, anger, blame, judgment or criticism to create a self-reinforcing prison.  Changing perception changes reality.  Daya's words and inspirational story fire up the mental-emotional changes that can lead to a changed body image, enhanced relationships, goals achieved and transformation realized.  \nBookViral\u2019s Review \u2013 \"A faith-based and enlightened approach to overcoming life\u2019s challenges, Grow Thin While You Sleep proves a powerful catalyst for positive change. Highly accessible, Daya Devi-Doolin isn\u2019t an author to persuade her readers with undue complexity or make outlandish claims, but by candidly sharing her own experiences she invites her readers to take a step back and consider an alternative perspective. It\u2019s certainly compelling, and whilst you might find similar texts on the subject few authors inspire on the level that Daya Devi-Doolin does, or more importantly succeed in making the vital connection between spiritual and bodily well-being. In clear and concise prose her guidance is easy to visualize and follow. Through her own transformative experiences, both concept and execution are easy to incorporate in our daily regimes. She includes recipes to compliment her holistic methodology, but it\u2019s in the cleansing of body and mind that she opens us up to the possibilities of long-lasting and transformative change in our lives through influences we might otherwise not recognize or act upon.\" http://www.bookviral.com/grow-thin-while-you-sleep/4593174055 \n \nDaya-Devi Doolin\u2019s book \u201cGrow Thin While You Sleep!\u201d has answers that lead to where success lies. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T02:55:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396207083","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"JOB CREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"55"},{"name":"ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"POKER","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"67"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; RECESSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"UNITED NATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"POLITICAL CANDIDATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"US STATE GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GOVERNORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"US CONFEDERATE FLAG CONTROVERSY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"LOBBYING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; SOUTH CAROLINA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"GREENVILLE, SC, USA; UNITED STATES; SOUTH CAROLINA, SC, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"54"},{"name":"BOB RILEY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"NIKKI HALEY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MARK SANFORD","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JOHN F KENNEDY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"50"}],"wordCount":"672","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396207083&p=2kx&v=1&x=m9uUDGLt6UmzzENuPrCqAg","id":"29396207083","content":"South Carolina\u2019s new governor, Henry McMaster, has boatloads of political and governmental experience. But that doesn\u2019t mean he can\u2019t learn a little, especially from people who have occupied the same seat that he took over this week. \n   \nFrom predecessor Nikki Haley, sworn in this week as America\u2019s ambassador to the United Nations, McMaster can learn the lesson of being seen when it matters. Haley might want people to remember her for being a governor of job creation, but that was an obvious priority at the tail end of a recession. It might be better for McMaster to look at how Haley dealt with various crises \u2013 a hurricane, floods shootings \u2013 during her six-year tenure and realize that part of effective leadership is taking charge in a crisis and being seen a lot by people to illustrate things are under control. \n   \nFrom her predecessor, Mark Sanford, McMaster might learn more of what not to do as governor. Sanford had a \u201cmy way or the highway\u201d attitude in dealing with the legislature, which often pitted him against lawmakers of his own party. The takeaway from this relationship for McMaster should be to listen more. \n   \nFormer Gov. Jim Hodges used innovative thinking and political muscle to get approval of his big-ticket agenda item: an education lottery. It has wildly exceeded expectations, opening the doors of college to tens of thousands of South Carolinians like never before. From Hodges, McMaster can learn to think outside the box. \n   \nThe four-year term of Gov. David Beasley offers the lesson of courage for McMaster. As governor, Beasley, a Republican, sought to remove the Confederate flag from the top of the Statehouse dome. He also opposed unregulated video poker, incurring the political wrath of the gambling lobby, which poured millions into Hodges\u2019 campaign. While Beasley lost his 1998 re-election bid, the flag eventually came down and video poker went away. Beasley later won the coveted John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage Award for standing up to institutional forces and doing the right thing. \n   \nThe leadership style of the late Gov. Carroll Campbell, a Republican who led the state for eight years with a Democratic legislature, offers lessons for McMaster. Many people might remember Campbell for his focus on getting government to work more like a business or for pushing restructuring after Operation Lost Trust cracked the old way of doing business at the Statehouse. But as former Campbell top staffer Bob McAlister recalled this week, \u201cIn these times of incredible political turmoil where people are spitting vitriol and acid out of their mouths, the modern interpretation of Carroll Campbell is how to get things done with people with whom you don\u2019t agree philosophically.\u201d (This is a lesson that might have served Sanford and Haley, too, in their dealings with state lawmakers.) \n   \nDick Riley of Greenville will be remembered forever as South Carolina\u2019s education governor. Riley, who later served as U.S. secretary of education under President Bill Clinton, continuously pushed South Carolina to do more to educate its children during his two terms as governor. Even today through the Riley Institute at Furman University, Riley beats the drum of bettering education to improve opportunities for the state\u2019s residents. Recent governors haven\u2019t had strong education records. McMaster would be wise to pick up the drumsticks and push for full funding of K-12 education as well as more early kindergarten opportunities. \n   \nFinally there\u2019s former Gov. Fritz Hollings, challenged in 1986 for his U.S. Senate seat by a young McMaster in his first political bid. While Hollings prevailed, McMaster can look back to Hollings\u2019 days as governor (1959-63) and find inspiration related to innovation (technical education and economic development) and focusing on moving the state forward. \n   \nIn his first days of office, it\u2019s clear that McMaster already has his eyes on the election of 2018 for which he is the obvious frontrunner, thanks to the power of incumbency. For much of his life, he\u2019s wanted to be governor. Now he is. So now let\u2019s see what McMaster has and, hopefully, use it to make South Carolina\u2019s future even brighter.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Andy Brack Statehouse Report"},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"ANDY BRACK: McMaster can learn lessons from past governors","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Florence","zipCode":"29501","state":"South Carolina","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Florence","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"SC Now","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169677639","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"SC Now","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.scnow.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204603396","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T02:55:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:47Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

There must be positive comprehensive gold policy and I believe it is so important for economy that so many people are dependent on it,\" he said. \n\n\"Crores of rupees are traded in the market and so many consumers, so many are producers, and from the linkage it to financial sector is increasing. Therefore, it is time for the government to think of White Paper on positive comprehensive policy for gold,\" Reddy said in his speech titled 'Gold - Black, White and Yellow'. \n\nHe said in 2015-16, for the \"first time\" there was some positive signal with regard to gold from the government's side. \n\nAccording to Reddy, launching of a gold scheme and making PAN number compulsory for purchases of gold jewellery worth more than Rs 2 lakh shows the seriousness of government in making the making gold a commodity. \n\n\"We also found that the gold jewellers were asked to provide PAN details of consumers who bought jewellery worth more than Rs 2 lakh so that it can be tracked. Recognition of gold as commodity or something is important that the public policy cannot ignore. These are signs of positive policy,\" he opined. \n\nRecalling the experiences faced by the Centre in 1990 on BoP crisis, he said the government had very little gold of its own and most of the metal put out in the international market was seized from smugglers. \n\n\"Government of India had leased gold to SBI (during 1990 crisis). How did the Government of India come into possession of gold? Most of the gold was confiscated from smugglers. So the smuggled gold, the confiscate gold came handy,\" Reddy said. \n\n\"Smugglers also helped us to get over the BoP crisis,\" he said in a lighter vein. \n\nHe maintained that gold is the ultimate currency in the world, though domestically possessing it is part of Indian culture and for women it acts like insurance.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Press Trust of India"},"topics":[{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Time to come out with comprehensive gold policy: Y V Reddy","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Business Standard India","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169659514","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"218"},"name":"Business Standard India","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Business"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.business-standard.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://mybs.in/2USkNPa"],"sequenceId":"695204617500","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:02:21Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:51Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

The commission is on a two-day visit to Varanasi to probe the stampede in which as many as 25 people, mostly women, were killed and over 100 injured, while crossing the overcrowded Ganga bridge. \n\nThe incident had occurred when the devotees of Jai Gurudev sect were on their way to attend a religious congregation, two km away in a village in Chandauli district. \n\nMore than a lakh people had participated in the procession that was heading to the religious camp of Jai Gurudev sect. However, permission had been sought only for 3000-5000 people. \n\nFollowing the incident, Uttar Pradesh Chief Minster Akhilesh Yadav had constituted a one-man inquiry commission to probe the stampede. \n\nJustice (Retd) Chauhan had summoned nearly 42 officials, who were on duty the day the incident occurred to record their statements. \n\nThe commission had earlier this month visited Varanasi between January 3 to 6 to probe the stampede incident and completed its first round of inquiry with recording statements of over 100 people, including eyewitnesses and organisers. \n\nHowever, Chauhan while talking to mediapersons here has said that so far only one official from Chandauli district had appeared before the commission to record his statement and no other officials turned up before the commission to record their statements. \n\nHe said that due to being engaged in the Assembly election duties, most of the officials had requested to extend the dates forappearing before the commission (to record their statements), to which the commission had given them one more chance and it will be returning again to Varanasi for holding its third round of inquiry. people including mediapersons that if they had any video footages or photographs taken at the time of the incident, then they may provide it to the commission.\n\n(This story has not been edited by {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:56Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395145765","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WEATHER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"AGRICULTURE","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"METEOROLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WEATHER SENSORS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"AGRONOMY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CROP RESEARCH","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"75"}],"wordCount":"316","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396208112&p=2kx&v=1&x=AMoO4fW4JFj6lnkXDPcXHA","id":"29396208112","content":"Keeping farm activities in mind, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) has decided to set up weather stations in 660 districts of the country, a plan which will be further taken up to the blocks level. \n\nIn the first phase, the IMD plans to set up the system in 130 districts which have already been shortlisted. \n\nThe IMD has also tied up with the Ministry of Agriculture to use the Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs), under the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) in the districts, to use them as weather forecasting observatories. \n\nWeather forecasts will be issued four days a week between Monday to Thursday. \n\n\"We have weather forecasting system in 130 districts which gives predictions for a cluster of neighbouring districts. This will now be diversified and every district will have its own weather forecast. \n\n\"The KVKs have a good mix of scientists with an expertise on different aspects of agriculture. Among them, someone will be made as an in-charge scientist. Plus, we will also make monetary arrangement for a scientific officer and a technical assistant,\" IMD Director General K J Ramesh said. \n\nRamesh added that this will further percolate at the block level, with the MET department giving predictions, keeping the rain-fed and non-rain-fed areas into consideration to give \"crop specific advisories\". \n\nEvery centre in a district will cost nearly Rs 10 lakh for salary and upkeep of infrastructure. Apart from it, the IMD will also spend Rs 3-4 lakh for setting up automatic weather stations which can measure temperature, wind velocity humidity and rains. \n\n\"We plan to cover 660 districts by 2019,\" Ramesh added. \n\n\"As and when district units are made functional at Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) in gradual manner, issue of advisories to those very districts will begin,\" he added. \n\nThe IMD will also start giving state-specific weather forecasts from this year. \n\nIt currently gives region-specific weather forecasts namely for the southern peninsula, northwest, central and northeast regions during monsoons.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"IMD to set up weather stations in 660 districts","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"The Statesman","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169674221","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"16"},"name":"The Statesman","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Science"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thestatesman.net"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204635356","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:30:56Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

She said: \"So very sad to hear that the immensely talented and deeply beloved John Hurt has died. My thoughts are with his family and friends.\"\n\nRecently, he starred as wandmaker Mr Ollivander in the Harry Potter series and an incarnation of Doctor Who in a 50th anniversary special of the series in 2013.\n\nHurt appeared in a number of the Harry Potter films but was best known for his roles in 1984, Alien and I Claudius.\n\nHe made his name in The Elephant Man and in the ground-breaking portrayal of Quentin Crisp in The Naked Civil servant. Bristol University student David Walliams was a huge fan of the actor. He said: Sir John Hurt changed the way we thought and felt with the truth and depth of his acting. The Naked Civil Servant and Elephant Man especially.\"\n\nHis on-screen comedy partner Matt Lucas simply added \"Peerless\".\n\nMeanwhile the Bristol Old Vic tweeted\n\nVery sad to hear the news this morning that the great actor #JohnHurt has died aged 77. A truly gifted performer who will be missed, RIP. pic.twitter.com/lZwiKSPToZ\n\n\u2014 Bristol Old Vic (@BristolOldVic) January 28, 2017 \n\nThe star's latest film Jackie, the Oscar nominated biopic of President John F. Kennedy's widow, is currently showing in cinemas.\n\nAfter rising to fame in A Man For All Seasons, some of his most famous roles include the 1979 blockbuster Alien, the TV series I, Claudius in 1976 and starring as Winston Smith in the adaptation of George Orwell's 1984.\n\nHis screen death in Alien has been voted one of the most memorable in cinema history.\n\nWhile battling pancreatic cancer in 2015, Sir John - the son of a clergyman - said he did not wish for an afterlife, saying: \"I hope I shall have the courage to say, 'Vroom! Here we go! Let's become different molecules!\"\n\nHe also said: \"I can't say I worry about mortality, but it's impossible to get to my age and not have a little contemplation of it. We're all just passing time, and occupy our chair very briefly.\" \n\nAmong those to pay tribute to Sir John was Mel Brooks, executive producer of \"The Elephant Man\".\n\nHe tweeted that he was a \"truly magnificent talent.\"\n\n\"No one could have played The Elephant Man more memorably. He carried that film into cinematic immortality. He will be sorely missed,\" he added.\n\nLast July, Sir John was forced to pull out of a production in the West End after advice from his doctors.\n\nHe had been set to play the role of Billy Rice in The Entertainer but was taken hospital with an intestinal complaint and told by doctors it was \"too soon... to undertake an arduous stage role,\".\n\nIn a statement, he said at the time: \"It is therefore with great sadness and disappointment that I must withdraw.\"\n\nIn October 2015, he was given the all clear after revealing he had been battling pancreatic cancer four months earlier, saying: \"I am overjoyed, I am thrilled. It all looks great for the future, it's fantastic.\"\n\nHe received his knighthood in July the same year, and said of the honour: \"It does make one inordinately proud.\" Notorious for his wild lifestyle, he was reportedly fond of saying his career track record \"isn't bad for an old drunk\".\n\nBut in 2008 he said he'd been without drink for several years, and noted: \"Times change. You change.\n\n\"When it no longer seemed to help, creatively, I mean, as it unquestionably had helped at one stage, it seemed time to give it up.\n\n\"Besides, attitudes to drinking have changed. Would Churchill have been able to get away with his drinking if he had been a politician today?\"\n\nHe married his fourth wife, film producer Anwen, 51, in 2005,and described the pair as being \"wonderfully married\".\n\nBut previously, he was notorious for his tumultuous love life.\n\nDuring his career, Sir John picked up two Academy Award nominations - for The Elephant Man and Midnight Express.\n\nHe won four Baftas for films including An Englishman in New York and The Naked Civil Servant.\n\nHe once described how his friend Sir Laurence Olivier, passed on advice to him, describing: \"I remember Olivier, when I was playing the Fool in his King Lear, saying: 'When it comes to the obituary, they'll only ever mention three things, probably two, but if you're lucky three.'\n\n\"And of course when he died, they mentioned Richard III, Henry IV and either Marathon Man or Wuthering Heights.\n\n\"I mean, if you write your own obituary, I don't know, they'd take the things that got awards wouldn't they? ranked 4th among all California colleges and 18th nationally in the \u201cOverall Mobility\u201d of students. \n \nCarson, CA (PRWEB) January 29, 2017 \n \nCalifornia State University, Dominguez Hills (CSUDH) has been ranked 4th among all California colleges and 18th nationally out of 2,137 colleges in the \u201c Overall Mobility Index \u201d of students category in a comprehensive report released Jan. 18 by The Equity of Opportunity Project . \n \nThis category reflects both access and outcomes, representing the likelihood that a student at CSUDH would move up two or more \u201cincome quintiles.\u201d The university was also ranked 8th out of 369 \u201cselective public colleges\u201d nationally in the category, and 2nd in the 23-campus California State University (CSU) system behind CSU Los Angeles. \n \nThe report and all its categories were made easily searchable online by the New York Times . The report was also featured by Times columnist David Leonhardt in his piece \u201cAmerica\u2019s Great Working-Class Colleges.\u201d \n \n\u201cThis New York Times article is a welcome validation for the great work all of you [CSUDH campus community] are involved in every day,\u201d said university President Willie J. Hagan, who quoted the column. \u201cYou should all be very proud to count yourselves among the \u2018deeply impressive institutions that continue to push many Americans into the middle class and beyond\u2014many more, in fact, than elite colleges that receive far more attention.\u2019\u201d \n \nThe mobility rates were defined as the percentage of its students who come from a family in the bottom fifth of the income distribution, and end up in the top fifth of the income distribution. The report found that some universities, such as CSUDH, with a much larger percentage of students from low-income families, have very high mobility rates, and high earnings outcomes that are closely comparable to students at highly selective colleges. \n \nThe Equity of Opportunity Project\u2019s findings were derived from 30 million college students. The data was compiled from statistics on students\u2019 earnings and their parents\u2019 incomes for each college in the United States. \n \nAbout CSU Dominguez Hills \u2014 With a student population of nearly 15,000, many who are first in their families to attend college, CSU Dominguez Hills provides high quality academic programs to students who aspire to succeed and thrive in a complex, global society. A leader in fostering a college-focused culture in the urban communities it serves, the university offers a proven path to opportunity and social equity and is a national laboratory and model for student access and success. The document covers the technical issues involved in a meet and confer, with an emphasis on being prepared with a solid IG framework and numerous considerations around proportionality. \n \n\u201cThis guide represents years of hard-won practical experience and contains advice around implementing the latest changes to the FRCP,\u201d explains LTPI Board Member Quin Gregor. \u201cIn developing this, while we found a few frameworks, these were either too high level or too in the weeds. None of these laid our vision of how we thought the process should be addressed. With our focus on legal technology and its application our advice is naturally more on the practical than legal. However, we have represented the legal framework as much as we need to within the LTPI purview. We've all witnessed too many drive-by Meet & Confers when one sides ignorance of the process led to shoddy client representation. With this guide, there is no longer any excuse.\u201d \n \nThe guide is broken into 4 stages: pre-conference, activities at the conference, post conference, and \u201ccommon pitfalls\u201d, providing practical guidance and checklist items and related strategic considerations to streamline the process and avoid any missed steps. It is a valuable resource to both the novice and the expert. \n \nThe project team members include Bob Rohlf (Exterro), Peter Pepiton (Dinsmore), Chris Paskach (The Claro Group), P. Sean d\u2019Albertis (Faegre), Kevin Clark (Thompson & Knight), Martin Tully (Akerman), Seth Eichenholtz (Mastercard), Quin Gregor (SigINT), Sunil Ohri (Stein Mitchell), and Noah Lauricella (Goldenberg Law). \n \nLTPI with industry partner ACEDS will host a webinar to discuss the guide and share best practices regarding the technical issues involved in a meet and confer. The webinar entitled \u201cMastering a Meaningful Meet-and-Confer\u201d will take place on February 23, 2017 at 1:00 PM EDT. More information about the webinar including how to register can be here . \n \nThe guide is currently open for public comment for the next 30 days by the legal community before being finalized and released. \n\nTo learn more about the Meet and Confer Guide, visit https://www.legaltechpi.org/Meet-and-Confer . \n \nLTPI is open to suggestions for new projects and accepting new project members. Requests for new projects can be submitted at https://legaltechpi.org/Projects-New-Project-Proposal or sent to programs(at)legaltechpi.org. \n \nAbout LTPI \n\nLegal Technology Professional Institute ( http://www.legaltechpi.org ) is a nonprofit legal association for legal practitioners who are involved in the use of technology utilized by the legal industry, including eDiscovery in litigation and investigations, and information governance. The iHeart80s Party rocked the SAP Center in San Jose, California with a star-studded lineup of artists including New Kids on the Block , UB40 Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey, Colin Hay of   Men At Work , Rick Astley , Starship ,  Eddie Money , and Night Ranger . And it was all hosted by iconic MTV personality Martha Quinn, who hosts the iHeart80s Radio's weekday morning show. \n \n{ \"position1\" : { \"type\" : \"live\", \"id\" : 5060, \"name\" : \"iHeart80s Radio\", \"description\" : \"Commercial-Free 80s Hits\" } } \n \nThe night was filled with some RAD moments from all of the performances of the night, amazing fan reactions, special guests, and more. Check out the best moments from the show below: \n Candace Cameron Bure -- AKA D.J. TANNER -- Helped Kick Off The Night By Introducing New Kids On The Block  \nIn case you didn\u2019t know, Candace is a huge NKOTB fan, and has been over the last 30 years. The band and Bure united on her show Fuller House , so there was no one better to introduce the band and kick off the show than D.J. Tanner herself. \n   New Kids On The Block Brought All The Right Stuff  \nNew Kids On The Block are one of the O.G. boybands, and after over 30 years of performing together, the guys still have  the right stuff . NKOTB took the stage to perform hits like \u201cStep By Step,\u201d \u201cYou Got It (The Right Stuff),\u201d and more, and brought all of their amazing dance moves with them. And yes, we\u2019re talking about those classic steps you learned from watching their music videos. \n Also, the NKOTB fans were out in FULL FORCE. Donnie couldn\u2019t resist\u2026  Starship Reminds Us \u201cWe are all citizens of the world.\u201d  \nAt the very end of their performance at the 2017 iHeart80s Party, which also happened to be the day as President Donald Trump\u2019s Immigration Ban which sparked protests across the country, Starship lead singer Mickey Thomas simply told the crowd, \u201cRemember, we are all citizens of the world.\u201d \n  \n. @starshipcontrol is giving us life right now! \"Remember we are all citizens of the WORLD!\" #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/y0MS7c5uPK \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Rick Astley Opened His Set With A Classic Rickroll  \nAstley kicked off his set with a classic Rickroll by leading fans to believe he was going to open with \u201cNever Gonna Give You Up\u201d by having his band play the instrumentals, but instead he kicked things off with his Whenever You Need Somebody single \u201cTogether Forever.\u201d Also during his set, the \u201880s icon, who turns 50 on February 6th, made jokes about his age and blamed it for his lack of dance numbers and inability to play high-energy songs back-to-back. \n UB40\u2019s \u201cRed Red Wine\u201d Had Everybody Feeling So Fine  \nUB40  Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey  took us all back to 1983 with their hit \u201cRed Red Wine.\u201d The crowd went wild during the band\u2019s performance of the beloved tune -- everybody was feeling it. \n  \nRed red wine has everybody feeling so fine #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/Zf5PhZcv0A \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Not to mention the band themselves\u2026   \nTime to sway.   @WeAreUB40 takes the stage now at our #iHeart80sParty in San Jose! Listen here: https://t.co/fYGa0YV6uc  pic.twitter.com/l9pT5fdvjX \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Eddie Money Issues \u201cTake Me Home Tonight\u201d Sing Along  \nMoney, who was accompanied on stage by his daughter Jesse, performed his iconic single \u201cTake Me Home Tonight,\u201d and lead the sold-out crowd at SAP Center to a full-blown sing along of the 1985 tune. \n  \nThe man himself @ImEddieMoney taking us home tonight!  #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/JCWEdB1yCN \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017   \nTake us home anytime @ImEddieMoney ! NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"NEW YORK, NY, USA; UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"271","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396208635&p=2kx&v=1&x=bU2ryIivEYErUOTYf_zQfA","id":"29396208635","content":"Engineers say data from Twitter and other social media platforms can help improve event planning, route scheduling, crowd regulations and subway operations. \n \n\"Social media offers a cost-effective way to obtain real-time data on monitoring subway passenger flow,\" said the study's corresponding author Qing He from the University of Buffalo. \n \n\"Our results show that data from apps like Twitter can help public transportation officials prepare for and react to passenger surges during concerts, baseball games and other big events,\" he said. \n \nIn addition to Qing, who has appointments in the university's Department of Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering and the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering, the study was co-authored by Ph.D. student Jing Gao, an assistant professor in the UB's Department Computer Science and Engineering, and Ming Ni, a Ph.D. fellow from the UB's Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering. \n \nFor their study, published in the journal IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems, the team gathered subway ridership information of Mets-Willets Point station in Queens, New York, near a baseball stadium and the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Centre, where the US Open tennis championships are held. \n \nThe researchers also collected nearly 30 million tweets geotagged to the New York City area during the time of the events. \n \nUsing six different computer models, the researchers then analysed the data and found a positive correlation between passenger flow and the rates of tweets during big events. \n \n\"The results are encouraging for two reasons. First, they indicate that increases in social media posts and subway ridership can be linked. Secondly, we have developed a method to track this correlation,\" co-author Jing Gao said. \n ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Blogging news","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Social media news","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"}],"title":"Twitter data can improve subway operations","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"The Statesman","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169674221","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"16"},"name":"The Statesman","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Science"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thestatesman.net"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204650217","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

She won 64 grand slam titles in total, including doubles and mixed doubles.\n\n\"I think she will break the record, and I think she will break it soon,\" Court said.\n\n\"It's so much easier for players today to do what they do. She hadn't played for about three months before coming here, and it easier to do these things.\n\n\"But she's playing very well, and records are made to be broken.\n\n\"People keep asking me, 'How do you feel about your record?' but I'm not going to lose any sleep over something like that.\n\n\"My life is very busy and full, and they'll never get my 64 so it's all right. I'll always have that.\"\n\nCourt, who played from 1959 to 1975, watched Williams beat her sister Venus 6-4, 6-4 in the final and was again struck by the resources, support and equipment that players have access to.\n\n\"There was television in the early '60s but no sponsorship and money, none of that. Even the racquets they get to use today are so beautiful compared to what we used to have,\" she said.\n\n\"The facilities are so much better, they have massage people, they can bring psychologists with them as well as their trainers and coaches and whoever else they want to come along.\n\n\"It's a whole different era, so it's very hard to compare. I think back to our Aussie era where we had some of the greatest champions in the world and think, how did we ever do that?\"\n\nCourt has not had the chance to talk extensively with Williams, chatting to her briefly during a presentation at the 2016 Hopman Cup.\n\n\"It's like Fort Knox with the players today. They're so isolated and they're hard to talk to. It's not like when we played where everyone was like brother and sister, it's totally different.\n\n\"I thought it was a very interesting match that she played. I knew she was going to win but there was a lot of hitting up and down the court.\n\n\"We had so much more of an all-round game with the volleying. It's a totally different game now, but she has a wonderful serve. a double in the 5-0 win at Southampton. \n\nWenger feared Welbeck might have lost his edge after 20 months out with two knee injuries, but looked back to his best as he fired his first goals since April to put Arsenal 2-0 in front at St Mary's. \n\nWelbeck had only just beaten knee ligament trouble when he suffered cartilage problems in late April, but he flourished on the south coast on Saturday to banish his injury worries. \n\nGunners boss Wenger hailed the 26-year-old's resolve in fending off not one but two long-term knee blows to move back towards top form. \n\nDanny Welbeck (middle) chips the ball over Southampton goalkeeper Harry Lewis \n\nAsked if he had feared Welbeck may never recover full sharpness, Wenger said: \"You do wonder. I wondered first of all would he be solid enough mentally to cope with that. \n\n\"Then secondly you hope he will go well after he comes back after the second surgery. \n\n\"He worked very hard, he went through some moments of very deep disappointment. Because when he had the setback and he had to go in again, as a professional player that's very difficult. \n\nTheo Walcott celebrates scoring against his former club \n\n\"But he became even more resilient and worked even harder. He's highly respected inside the club because he's shown so much dedication. \n\n\"It was good to see Welbeck be so convincing. I didn't expect him at that level, because I knew he worked very hard but I didn't know how much efficiency it would be in a competitive game. \n\n\"It was great to see he hasn't lost his runs or his finishing; it shows as well when you are able to transform that frustration in not playing into efficiency that he's a special guy. \n\nWelbeck celebrates with Kieran Gibbs after scoring against Southampton \n\n\"There are always two fears, the first is that it takes him too long with decision-making, and second that he would be scared for contact. \n\n\"But the runs and also fighting the defenders, it was important for me.\" \n\nWelbeck opened the scoring with a dinked finish before latching onto Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain's lofted pass to slide home between Harry Lewis' legs. \n\nThe former Manchester United striker then laid on Walcott's first goal, before second-half replacement Alexis Sanchez set up the final two finishes. \n\nWenger hailed Walcott for staying calm to score his treble and kill off any chances of a Saints fightback. \n\n\"Theo is a good finisher,\" said Wenger. \"And the chances we created were very good. Rusk and his brother, David Rusk\u2014will be held at 1 p.m. Monday in the East Texas Research Center, located on the second floor of the Steen Library on the SFA campus. \n \nSFA\u2019s Board of Regents approved the purchase of the collection, which contains about 1,000 items, from members of the Rusk family. The family generously donated approximately 600 additional items, and ETRC staff members have been diligently working since then to prepare the materials for public presentation. \n \n\u201cI have finished organizing the purchased materials,\u201d said Kyle Ainsworth, ETRC special collections librarian. \u201cNow, I\u2019m organizing and describing the donated materials so that I can integrate them with the purchased items and create one collection.\u201d \n \nThe collection contains Republic of Texas historical materials that have been in the Rusk family since the 1830s and includes several legal and personal documents of Thomas J. Rusk, a political and military leader of the Republic of Texas who served as its first secretary of war and as a general in the Battle of San Jacinto. He was later a U.S. politician and served as a senator from Texas. \n \nComprising the majority of the collection are documents addressed to David Rusk, Thomas\u2019 brother, who served as a Nacogdoches County sheriff and tax collector during the Republic period. Additional documents in the collection include letters addressed to David\u2019s son, John, as well as other family members. \n \nThere also are important county records, including delinquent tax rolls from the 1830s, several of David\u2019s civil and criminal sheriff\u2019s docket books, and receipts for the construction of the county\u2019s courthouse. \n \nAccording to Ainsworth, the materials help tell the story of Nacogdoches as well as the Republic of Texas and are an intimate picture of the Rusk family\u2019s private lives and public service. \n \n\u201cThe highlights of the collection are the 60 letters received by David Rusk from his older brother, several rare maps and appointments signed by various presidents of the Republic of Texas naming David Rusk sheriff of Nacogdoches County,\u201d Ainsworth said. \u201cOne of the appointments signed by Sam Houston in 1837 is exceptional because David Rusk was the first sheriff Houston appointed in Texas.\u201d  \n  \nIn one letter penned by Thomas in 1835, he lets David know  that a mail route to Nacogdoches has just been established via Fort Jessup in Louisiana. In another letter, Thomas tells David that he has just arrived at the Capitol, sat in his senate seat and will shortly meet with President James K. Polk.  \n  \nFour letters addressed to David from various veterans of the Battle of San Jacinto ask him to provide details on how they may obtain a Texas Revolution Service Pension. \n \n\u201cThe cursive writing from the 19th century can be difficult to read,\u201d Ainsworth said. \u201cDuring the reception, we will display mostly documents where the noteworthy feature is an important signature that everyone can recognize and appreciate as having value, including signatures from Presidents of the Republic of Texas Sam Houston, Mirabeau Lamar and Anson Jones.\u201d The ETRC will exhibit these noteworthy items outside of their offices. \n \nThe opening reception coincides with SFA\u2019s Board of Regents winter board meeting. There will be several speakers, including SFA President Baker Pattillo. \n \nThe reception is free and open to the public. Refreshments will be served. \n \nThe Rusk collection will be housed inside the ETRC and available for research beginning Feb. 1 from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. weekdays. The exhibit of noteworthy documents is located outside the ETRC and viewable during library hours, 7 a.m. to midnight Monday through Thursday; 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. Friday; 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Saturday; and noon to midnight Sunday. ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Reception planned to open Rusk Family Letters","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Nacogdoches","zipCode":"75962","state":"Texas","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Nacogdoches","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Stephen F.
