\n\nAddressing a press meet here, he praised Panneerselvam for the efforts taken for conduct of jallikattu and for meeting Andhra Pradesh counterpart N  Chandrababu Naidu to get Krishna water to Tamil Nadu. \n \n\"In a similar manner, Panneerselvam should lead a delegation of officials and representatives of political parties to meet Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan and stop construction of check dams across River Bhavani,\" he said. \n\nThanking the students and others for protesting in support of jallikattu in a peaceful manner, Elangovan, a former TNCC president, condemned the police action against the protesters. \n\nHe urged the Tamil Nadu  government to constitute a judicial enquiry commission headed by a retired or current Supreme Court judge to go into the violent incidents. \n\nSuch an inquiry was necessary to ascertain whether anti-socials and mischief mongers infiltrated the protesting crowd at Marina Beach in Chennai, as claimed by the state government and police, he said. \n\nOn reported seating of Panneerselvam along with other party MLAs at a meeting chaired by AIADMK General Secretary V K Sasikala, he said \"It is totally an insult and disrespect shown to the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu\". \n\nThough it was an inner-party meeting, the AIADMK chief should provide 'proper respect' to the chief minister by providing a seat adjacent to her in the podium, he added. \n\nCharing that the BJP manifesto for the Uttar Pradesh elections mentioned support of some castes and communities, he wanted the Election Commission to bar the party from contesting the Appreciating Tamil Nadu Chief Minister O Panneerselvam for his efforts in passing jallikattu ordinance and over Krishna river water issue, Congress leader E V K S Elangovan today asked him to take steps for halting building of check dams across Bhavani river by Kerala. \nAddressing a press meet here, he praised Panneerselvam for the efforts taken for conduct of jallikattu and for meeting Andhra Pradesh counterpart N  Chandrababu Naidu to get Krishna water to Tamil Nadu. \n\n\"In a similar manner, Panneerselvam should lead a delegation of officials and representatives of political parties to meet Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan and stop construction of check dams across River Bhavani,\" he said. \n\nThanking the students and others for protesting in support of jallikattu in a peaceful manner, Elangovan, a former TNCC president, condemned the police action against the protesters. \n\nHe urged the Tamil Nadu  government to constitute a judicial enquiry commission headed by a retired or current Supreme Court judge to go into the violent incidents. \n\nSuch an inquiry was necessary to ascertain whether anti-socials and mischief mongers infiltrated the protesting crowd at Marina Beach in Chennai, as claimed by the state government and police, he said. \n\nOn reported seating of Panneerselvam along with other party MLAs at a meeting chaired by AIADMK General Secretary V K Sasikala, he said \"It is totally an insult and disrespect shown to the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu\". \n\nThough it was an inner-party meeting, the AIADMK chief should provide 'proper respect' to the chief minister by providing a seat adjacent to her in the podium, he added. \n\nCharing that the BJP manifesto for the Uttar Pradesh elections mentioned support of some castes and communities, he wanted the Election Commission to bar the party from contesting the coming polls. \n \n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.) \n his efforts in passing jallikattu ordinance and over Krishna river water issue, Congress leader E V K S Elangovan today asked him to take steps for halting building of check dams across Bhavani river by Kerala. \n\nAddressing a press meet here, he praised Panneerselvam for the efforts taken for conduct of jallikattu and for meeting Andhra Pradesh counterpart N  Chandrababu Naidu to get Krishna water to Tamil Nadu. \n\n\"In a similar manner, Panneerselvam should lead a delegation of officials and representatives of political parties to meet Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan and stop construction of check dams across River Bhavani,\" he said. \n\nThanking the students and others for protesting in support of jallikattu in a peaceful manner, Elangovan, a former TNCC president, condemned the police action against the protesters. \n\nHe urged the Tamil Nadu  government to constitute a judicial enquiry commission headed by a retired or current Supreme Court judge to go into the violent incidents. \n\nSuch an inquiry was necessary to ascertain whether anti-socials and mischief mongers infiltrated the protesting crowd at Marina Beach in Chennai, as claimed by the state government and police, he said. \n\nOn reported seating of Panneerselvam along with other party MLAs at a meeting chaired by AIADMK General Secretary V K Sasikala, he said \"It is totally an insult and disrespect shown to the Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu\". \n\nThough it was an inner-party meeting, the AIADMK chief should provide 'proper respect' to the chief minister by providing a seat adjacent to her in the podium, he added. \n\nCharing that the BJP manifesto for the Uttar Pradesh elections mentioned support of some castes and communities, he wanted the Election Commission to bar the party from contesting the coming polls. \n \n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.) \n \nPress Trust of India \n Business image (PHOTO: ) \n    \nIndia's first dedicated space observatory, ASTROSAT, has captured the rare phenomenon of a small, 6-billion-year-old \"vampire\" star \"preying\" on a bigger celestial body. \n\nScientists say the smaller star, also called a \"blue straggler\", feeds off its companion star by sucking out its mass and energy, causing its eventual death. \n\n\"The most popular explanation is that these are binary systems in which the smaller star sucks material out of the bigger companion star to become a blue straggler, and hence is called a vampire star. \n\n\"The small star becomes bigger, hotter and bluer, which gives it the appearance of being young, while the ageing companion burns out and collapses to a stellar remnant,\" said Annapurni Subramaniam, a Professor at the Indian Institute of Astrophysics. \n\nThough this phenomenon is not unheard of, the observation of the entire process through the telescope will provide insights that will help scientists in studying the formation of 'blue straggler' stars. \n\nThis discovery also highlights the capabilities of the telescopes on ASTROSAT, a dedicated space observatory satellite launched in September {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:03Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395455401","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BIOINFORMATICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PHYSICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DISEASES & DISORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"REPTILES & AMPHIBIANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BIOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BIOPHYSICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SKIN CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"RESEARCH REPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"}],"wordCount":"302","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396208931&p=2kx&v=1&x=tJ-Ud9UnjaqvzVb4Ws9MkA","id":"29396208931","content":"A team of scientists has used artificial intelligence (AI) to gain insight into the biophysics of cancer with their machine-learning platform predicting a trio of reagents that generated a cancer-like phenotype in tadpoles. \n \nThe research, reported in journal Scientific Reports, showed that during these extensive experiments, the biologists observed that all the melanocytes -- a mature melanin-forming cell -- in a single frog larva either converted to the cancer-like form or remained completely normal. \n \nIn their study, the researchers asked their AI-derived model to answer the question of how to achieve partial melanocyte conversion within the same animal using one or more interventions. \n \n\"We wanted to see if we could break the concordance among cells, which would help us understand how cells make group decisions and determine complex body-wide outcomes,\" said Tufts University's Michael Levin, who is the paper's corresponding author. \n \nThe AI model ultimately predicted that a precise combination of three reagents -- altanserin, a 5HTR2 inhibitor; reserpine, a VMAT inhibitor, and VP16-XlCreb1, mRNA encoding constitutively active CREB -- would achieve that outcome. \n \nThe team used the AI-discovered model to run 576 virtual experiments. The last try gave one precise combination of three drugs predicting partial melanocyte conversion. \n \n\"Our system predicted a three-component treatment, which we had never have come up with on our own, that achieved the exact outcome we wanted, and which we had not seen before in years of diverse experiments,\" Levin added. \n \n\"Such approaches are a key step for regenerative medicine, where a major obstacle is the fact that it is usually very hard to know how to manipulate the complex networks discovered by bioinformatics and wet lab experiments in such a way as to reach a desired therapeutic outcome,\" Levin noted. \n \nHe said that the team now wanted to do something different -- cure a disease, control cell behaviour and regenerate tissue. \n ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Cancer news","group":"Science"},{"name":"Medical news","group":"Science"}],"title":"AI helps scientists gain insight into cancer biophysics","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"The Statesman","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169674221","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"16"},"name":"The Statesman","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Science"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thestatesman.net"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204656861","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:03Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:05Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396209155","companies":[{"symbol":"8918","primary":true,"name":"Land Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3968800007"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"RURAL COMMUNITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"CIVIL ENGINEERING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WATER QUALITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ENERGY & UTILITY LAW","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WATER SUPPLY UTILITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BOARDS OF DIRECTORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"INSOLVENCY & BANKRUPTCY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"WATER RESOURCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENTAL LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WATER QUALITY REGULATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENT & NATURAL RESOURCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CONSERVATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PUBLIC HEARINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"RURAL DEVELOPMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"780","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396209155&p=2kx&v=1&x=7NvzYotY96VxxthJfrXtdg","id":"29396209155","content":"Winona Water Supply Cooperative Board trustees (from left) Dan Vingle, Rick Mercer and Alan Gamble spoke with residents this week about how it can go about addressing an Ohio Environmental Protection Agency violation of low pressure in the system. (Salem News photo by Katie White)\n\nWINONA \u2014 A water supply cooperative in Winona is trying to figure out how to satisfy the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency (OEPA) without going bankrupt.\n\nIn addition to facing a potential $25,000 a day fine for not having a water operator, the Winona Water Supply Cooperative Board is looking at how to fix a low pressure violation.\n\nFixing the pressure problem can be done in a variety of ways, but all at a price tag the cooperative board said it just can\u2019t handle.\n\nThe water system was not in violation of any water quality standards, Board Trustee Alan Gamble said.\n\nThe system has supplied water in the small community in Butler Township for several years through a shallow hand-laid brick well that is at least 120 years old. The well pumps to a 10,000-gallon cistern located at the top of a hill.\n\nDue to being privately-run, the company has limited to no access to any public county, state or federal funding to help. By law, public funding cannot be used for private projects.\n\nThe OEPA has recommended the board contact the Rural Community Assistance Program (RCAP) for funding assistance options.\n\nThe board held a public meeting with residents this week to communicate the problem, and Gamble resigned as trustee at the end of the meeting, ending his roughly 20 years of service.\n\nGamble said he made the decision prior to the meeting and is leaving for the same reason David Hull, the company\u2019s water operator of record recently left.\n\nGamble said they fear being held personally liable for the problems, like the former operator, Jim Bates.\n\nBates was serving as operator for Winona while also working as Water Superintendent for Sebring, prior to being fired from Sebring last year following OEPA action.\n\nTrustees said rough estimates to make the repairs to the pressure are anywhere from $200,000 to $300,000 \u2013 a high price for the cooperative that averages $500 to $600 in its account at billing time each month.\n\n\u201cThey (OEPA) know we can\u2019t do it tomorrow,\u201d \n\nRetired water board trustee Homer Althouse said he has been in contact with county engineer and sanitary engineer Bert Dawson.\n\nDawson told the Journal prior to the meeting that while the county has no responsibility to fix the problem, he has been speaking with residents who reached out to him with their concerns.\n\n\u201cI\u2019ve offered to help them, and I\u2019m sure everyone else would too,\u201d \n\nHis suggestions include having the homes with low pressure directly hook into the line that goes uphill from the well to the cistern, which he believes might result in enough pressure to satisfy the OEPA requirements, or installing a larger above-ground water storage tank, which would also increase water pressure since the lines are gravity fed from the cistern.\n\nHowever, Gamble is not sure the cooperative can finance those options.\n\nThe board has reached out to state Rep. Tim Ginter for help, and Ginter said he has also spoken with Dawson and the OEPA about the matter.\n\nThe board was displeased that no one from the OEPA attended the meeting, as they requested.\n\nAlan Gamble\u2019s brother John Gamble Jr., who is the county\u2019s chief assistant prosecuting attorney, was at the meeting and said that while there is a chance the company could walk away and the residents be taken over by another company or public water system, tapping into another system would be expensive.\n\nFor example, if they would become part of the Buckeye Water District, their monthly bill could be as high as $70, he said.\n\nThe city of Salem is another possible public water source, he added, but cautioned against those options due to the increased cost to customers.\n\nWith Alan Gamble out of the picture now as water trustee, the two remaining trustees and Althouse, who volunteered to replace Gamble on the board beginning that evening, will be considering the options and updating residents.\n\nAlan Gamble later said he would continue to help the board and the community as he could.\n\nCOLUMBIANA\u2014The death of a 38-year-old woman struck by a train here Saturday morning is under investigation by the ...\n\nWINONA \u2014 Trustees of the privately run cooperative that supplies water to Winona residents could face a $25,000 ...\n\nLISBON The iHeart80s Party rocked the SAP Center in San Jose, California with a star-studded lineup of artists including New Kids on the Block , UB40 Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey, Colin Hay of   Men At Work , Rick Astley , Starship ,  Eddie Money , and Night Ranger . And it was all hosted by iconic MTV personality Martha Quinn, who hosts the iHeart80s Radio's weekday morning show. \n \n{ \"position1\" : { \"type\" : \"live\", \"id\" : 5060, \"name\" : \"iHeart80s Radio\", \"description\" : \"Commercial-Free 80s Hits\" } } \n \nThe night was filled with some RAD moments from all of the performances of the night, amazing fan reactions, special guests, and more. TANNER -- Helped Kick Off The Night By Introducing New Kids On The Block  \nIn case you didn\u2019t know, Candace is a huge NKOTB fan, and has been over the last 30 years. Tanner herself. \n   New Kids On The Block Brought All The Right Stuff  \nNew Kids On The Block are one of the O.G. boybands, and after over 30 years of performing together, the guys still have  the right stuff . NKOTB took the stage to perform hits like \u201cStep By Step,\u201d \u201cYou Got It (The Right Stuff),\u201d and more, and brought all of their amazing dance moves with them. Donnie couldn\u2019t resist\u2026  Starship Reminds Us \u201cWe are all citizens of the world.\u201d  \nAt the very end of their performance at the 2017 iHeart80s Party, which also happened to be the day as President Donald Trump\u2019s Immigration Ban which sparked protests across the country, Starship lead singer Mickey Thomas simply told the crowd, \u201cRemember, we are all citizens of the world.\u201d \n  \n. @starshipcontrol is giving us life right now! \"Remember we are all citizens of the WORLD!\" #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/y0MS7c5uPK \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Rick Astley Opened His Set With A Classic Rickroll  \nAstley kicked off his set with a classic Rickroll by leading fans to believe he was going to open with \u201cNever Gonna Give You Up\u201d by having his band play the instrumentals, but instead he kicked things off with his Whenever You Need Somebody single \u201cTogether Forever.\u201d Also during his set, the \u201880s icon, who turns 50 on February 6th, made jokes about his age and blamed it for his lack of dance numbers and inability to play high-energy songs back-to-back. \n UB40\u2019s \u201cRed Red Wine\u201d Had Everybody Feeling So Fine  \nUB40  Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey  took us all back to 1983 with their hit \u201cRed Red Wine.\u201d The crowd went wild during the band\u2019s performance of the beloved tune -- everybody was feeling it. \n  \nRed red wine has everybody feeling so fine #iheart80s  pic.twitter.com/Zf5PhZcv0A \n\u2014 iHeartRadio (@iHeartRadio) January 29, 2017  Not to mention the band themselves\u2026   \nTime to sway.   @WeAreUB40 takes the stage now at our #iHeart80sParty in San Jose! WYOMING, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"816","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396209864&p=2kx&v=1&x=bRZMy1DEqI50iqjR6OYmHQ","id":"29396209864","content":"UCSD No. 1 CFO John Williams, sitting next to school district attorney Geoffrey Phillips, talks about some of the budget unknowns the school district is facing this year. (HERALD PHOTO/Bethany Lange)       EVANSTON \u2014 School districts around Wyoming are bracing for impact after the introduction of HB 236 on Wednesday. \nHB 236, also known as the education omnibus bill, attempts to deal with education funding shortfalls. \n\nIf the bill is passed, Evanston\u2019s school district will see an additional 2.13 percent budget cut next year, or $872,500, on top of the anticipated budget cuts. \n\nAccording to the HB 236 Bill Summary Impact document, Evanston enrollment will decrease by 44 students in 2018, compared to 2017 projections. \n\nThe Subcommittee on Education Deficit Reduction Options issued a document Dec. 28, 2016, detailing the state\u2019s education budget crisis and some options to address it. That document, \u201cWyoming K-12 Education Funding Deficit White Paper,\u201d is available at http://tinyurl.com/gnjdums. \n\nWyoming expects an annual shortfall of $360-400 million at least through 2022. This is both caused and exacerbated by the state\u2019s mineral industry crisis. \n\n\u201cDue to the overwhelming dependence on the mineral industry to fund education in Wyoming, we now find ourselves in a budget phenomenon known as the \u2018double-whammy,\u2019\u201d the document states. \n\nIn short, the state is required to prioritize public education funding; the state needs mineral revenue to operate schools; and mineral revenues are declining. \n\nIn 2015 alone, 5,400 oil and gas employees were laid off; total numbers for 2016 are still pending. Wyoming also saw its first population drop since 1990 last year. \n\nSchools are already dealing with the 2016 \u201cpenny cut\u201d and enrollment drops (which means less money), and will have to cut even more this year as it is. \n\nThe Subcommittee on Education Deficit Reductions Options provided five options to deal with the education funding deficit, saying each option could fix up to $80 million of the problem. These options are as follows: \n\n\u2022 Adjust the funding formula for school districts and reduce appropriations from the School Foundation Program Account (including reducing total funding by .06 percent every year, changing the funding formula to \u201ccost-based\u201d levels, consolidating school districts, purchasing instead of leasing school buses, reducing administrative salaries, reducing student activity funding, cutting the instructional facilitator program and cutting professional development days from 10 to five) \n\n\u2022 Find savings to offset shortfalls (using the Legislative Stabilization Reserve Account, or LSRA, to balance the School Foundation Program Account, or SFPA) \n\n\u2022 Find existing revenue (increase taxes or increase mineral royalties to the SFPA) \n\n\u2022 Recalibrate spending policies (increase the balance of the Common School Permanent Land Fund Reserve Account or send more investment income to the SFPA) \n\n\u2022 Enhance revenue (increase mill levies for education, impose a tax on health and professional services and increase sales tax) \n\nThe omnibus bill reflects many of these suggestions. \n\nHB 236 proposes to raise the state sales tax from 4 percent to 4.5 percent as soon as the LSRA has less than $500 million and continues the funding cuts begun in 2016. \n\nFurthermore, personnel will see a sharp impact. Superintendents, assistant superintendents and business managers would see their salaries cut by 10 percent; the instructional facilitator program would be cut in half; and the school year would be cut from 185 to 180 days. \n\nBus purchases and leases and alternative school building would be frozen. \n\nCommittees would be created to study alternative schools and recalibrate funding to a cost-based funding model, including for transportation and special education. \n\nAlso, the LSRA would maintain the SFPA at $100 million every year unless the LSRA has less than $500 million in the account. \n\nThe Uinta County School District No. 1 heard about the omnibus bill at Tuesday\u2019s school board meeting. \n\nSuperintendent Ryan Thomas said he is keeping in touch with Rep. Garry Piiparinen about it. The omnibus bill is only one of many education-related bills; others propose to increase class sizes, while the omnibus bill focuses on cutting school days instead of class sizes, which would in turn cut salaries \u2014 possibly by $1,800 per teacher. \n\nAssistant superintendent Doug Rigby termed it the \u2018ominous bill.\u2019 \n\nRep. Piiparinen, who is also a schoolteacher, told the Herald that he was the only member of the education committee who did not put his name on the bill. When the committee was asked to sponsor the bill, he had not had a chance to read the 53-page bill yet and did not want to put his name to it. \n\n\u201cIt would be hard for me to defend a lot of those things,\u201d he said. \n\nPiiparinen said the bill was run through quickly but that it seems to put the responsibility for the state\u2019s budget issues on education. He added that he would like to see other measures investigated as well, such as putting the Capitol Square Project on hold (including the Herschler building remodel and expansion) and working on the general fund. \n\n\u201cThey\u2019re just expecting education to solve this,\u201d he said. \u201c... It\u2019s a state problem; it\u2019s not just an education problem.\u201d \n\nThe Legislature is accepting public comments on the bill at http://tinyurl.com/zfo9y6e. It will come to a vote on Monday evening.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"School funding on chopping block statewide","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Uinta","zipCode":"82930","state":"Wyoming","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Evanston","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Uinta County Herald","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169696699","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"4"},"name":"Uinta County Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Local","Geographic","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.uintacountyherald.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://tinyurl.com/gnjdums","http://tinyurl.com/zfo9y6e"],"sequenceId":"695204679835","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:11Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

To win, its craft must land on luna \u2014 and a probe must move at least 500 meters (1,640 feet) and send hi-resolution images of its exploration back to earth. \n \nThe winner gets the $20 million grand prize, while runners-up split a $1 million consolation award. \n \nIt\u2019s already taking a bit longer than hoped \u2014 rules that required a complete finish by the Dec. 31 deadline just got loosened to give the competitors a bit more time. \n \nBut the goal is still remarkable: landing a high-tech mobile probe on the moon, 238,900 miles away. The Chinese government, with all its vast resources and desire to win global respect, pulled it off in 2013 \u2014 but the last (non-crash) landing before that was in 1976. \n \nThe five teams include one international one, Synergy Moon, with members from 15-plus countries, as well as the Israeli SpaceIL, the California-based Moon Express, India\u2019s Team Indus and Japan\u2019s Hakuto. \n \nEach has its rocket booked (Team Indus and Hakuto are actually sharing their flight) and the contract verified by X Prize, which sponsors a variety of technical contests aimed at building a better future. \n \nEstablished in 2007, the competition is meant to push a lowering of the cost of spaceflight \u2014 while also inspiring the world\u2019s scientists and engineers. \n \nOnce this competition is won, it\u2019ll be time for a race to get live astronauts back to luna: It\u2019s been far too long (45 years!) since the late Gene Cernan walked on the moon. \n \nGovernment programs alone will never establish a real human presence off-planet: That will require a private sector that can make it pay. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:00:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396210288","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION GRADUATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"65"},{"name":"CONSUMER ELECTRONICS","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"EXECUTIVES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENTREPRENEURSHIP","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"BOARDS OF DIRECTORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"SMARTPHONES","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"MOBILE DEVICES","domains":["IND"],"score":"75"},{"name":"COMPUTER EQUIPMENT","domains":["IND"],"score":"74"},{"name":"HANDHELD COMPUTERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"75"},{"name":"ADULTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"STEVEN JOBS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"89"}],"wordCount":"1606","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396210288&p=2kx&v=1&x=8Rva0QPbh6jVcrnIDghW6A","id":"29396210288","content":"S teve Jobs is widely regarded as the greatest ceo of all time. By the time he died of cancer in October 2011, Apple was the most valuable corporation on Earth. His unique approach to business made the Apple brand stand out above its competition\u2014and above every organization in any field. He reached the height of success in the physical realm, but there is so much more to be gained from the human experience. \n \nJobs possessed the rare ability to focus like a laser on his objectives. \u201cI\u2019ve freed up some good engineers who could work on new mobile devices, and eventually got it right when we moved on to iPhones and the iPad,\u201d he said. \u201cThis ability to focus saved Apple.\u201d At the time, Apple was trying to produce an incalculable number of gadgets. Jobs pared that down to just four: one desktop and one portable device each for both the consumer and the professional. \n \nThe word focus can refer to adjusting the lens of a camera to fixate sharply on one object. We can develop this ability figuratively. Focus is a foundational tool for success. Few possess it. Even fewer possess the ultimate success focus. \n \n[embedded content] \n It Takes Love  \nSteve Jobs was the greatest ceo ever, so it\u2019s no surprise that he gave the most-quoted commencement address of all time at Stanford University in 2005. Here is an excerpt: \n \nI was lucky\u2014I found what I loved to do early in life. Woz and I started Apple in my parents\u2019 garage when I was 20. We worked hard, and in 10 years, Apple had grown from just the two of us in a garage into a $2 billion company with over 4,000 employees. We had just released our finest creation\u2014the Macintosh\u2014a year earlier, and I had just turned 30. And then I got fired. How can you get fired from a company you started? Well, as Apple grew, we hired someone who I thought was very talented to run the company with me, and for the first year or so, things went well. But then our visions of the future began to diverge and eventually we had a falling out. When we did, our Board of Directors sided with him. So at 30, I was out. And very publicly out. What had been the focus of my entire adult life was gone, and it was devastating. \n\nI really didn\u2019t know what to do for a few months. I felt that I had let the previous generation of entrepreneurs down\u2014that I had dropped the baton as it was being passed to me. I met with David Packard and Bob Noyce and tried to apologize for screwing up so badly. I was a very public failure, and I even thought about running away from the valley. But something slowly began to dawn on me\u2014I still loved what I did. The turn of events at Apple had not changed that one bit. I had been rejected, but I was still in love. And so I decided to start over. \n \nGod\u2019s own people failed to love His truth! Because of that, they lost their focus. They don\u2019t face trials and keep pushing forward like Steve Jobs did; they just give up because they don\u2019t love God anyway. Fifty percent of them will eventually repent, but the other half never will. It is impossible to focus on anything if it is not the absolute priority in that moment. Jobs continued: \n \nI didn\u2019t see it then, but it turned out that getting fired from Apple was the best thing that could have ever happened to me. The heaviness of being successful was replaced by the lightness of being a beginner again, less sure about everything. It freed me to enter one of the most creative periods of my life. \n\nDuring the next five years, I started a company named NeXT, another company named Pixar, and fell in love with an amazing woman who would become my wife. Pixar went on to create the world\u2019s first computer animated feature film, Toy Story, and is now the most successful animation studio in the world. In a remarkable turn of events, Apple bought NeXT, I returned to Apple, and the technology we developed at NeXT is at the heart of Apple\u2019s current renaissance. And Laurene and I have a wonderful family together. \n\nI\u2019m pretty sure none of this would have happened if I hadn\u2019t been fired from Apple. It was awful-tasting medicine, but I guess the patient needed it. Sometimes life hits you in the head with a brick. Don\u2019t lose faith. I\u2019m convinced that the only thing that kept me going was that I loved what I did. You\u2019ve got to find what you love. \u2026 [T]he only way to do great work is to love what you do. If you haven\u2019t found it yet, keep looking. Don\u2019t settle. As with all matters of the heart, you\u2019ll know when you find it. And, like any great relationship, it just gets better and better as the years roll on. So keep looking until you find it. Don\u2019t settle. \n \nSteve Jobs focused so intensely on producing great products that many brilliant minds couldn\u2019t handle working for him. Only those who shared his passion for perfection could rise to the challenge. Time magazine quoted Jobs talking about the creation of the iPhone, which debuted in stores in 2007: \n \n[T]here always seems to come a moment where it\u2019s just not working, and it\u2019s so easy to fool yourself\u2014to convince yourself that it is when you know in your heart that it isn\u2019t. Well, you know what? It\u2019s been that way with [almost] every major project at Apple, too. \u2026 Take the iPhone. We had a different enclosure design for this iPhone until way too close to the introduction to ever change it. And I came in one Monday morning, I said, \u201cI just don\u2019t love this. I can\u2019t convince myself to fall in love with this. And this is the most important product we\u2019ve ever done.\u201d And we pushed the reset button. We went through all of the zillions of models we\u2019d made and ideas we\u2019d had. And we ended up creating what you see here as the iPhone, which is dramatically better. \u2026 [W]e had to go to the team and say, \u201cAll this work you\u2019ve [done] for the last year, we\u2019re going to have to throw it away and start over, and we\u2019re going to have to work twice as hard now because we don\u2019t have enough time.\u201d And you know what everybody said? \u201cSign us up.\u201d \n \nJobs scrapped the iPhone! By all accounts, it was a quality piece of technology, but it wasn\u2019t perfect. If Jobs couldn\u2019t fall in love with it, then no consumer ever would. So his team started over. History will show that Jobs made the right decision: Time named the iPhone the Invention of the Year. \n \nCombine focus with a deep love for the subject, and you can \u201cmake a dent in the universe,\u201d as Jobs often described his life\u2019s purpose. If your heart isn\u2019t in it, you will lose focus. \n Full of Light  \n\u201cThe light of the body is the eye: therefore when thine eye is single, thy whole body also is full of light; but when thine eye is evil, thy body also is full of darkness. Take heed therefore that the light which is in thee be not darkness. If thy whole body therefore be full of light, having no part dark, the whole shall be full of light, as when the bright shining of a candle doth give thee light\u201d (Luke 11:34-36). Proper focus requires not only concentration on one clear goal, but also the right goal to pursue. There are a multitude of areas where we can direct our focus, but certain areas are far more important than others. Some areas are good, and others are evil. \n \n\u201cNo man can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon\u201d (Matthew 6:24). You can\u2019t serve God and money! It must be one or the other. God is concerned about where and how we focus. \n \n\u201cServants, be obedient to them that are your masters according to the flesh, with fear and trembling, in singleness of your heart, as unto Christ\u201d (Ephesians 6:5). In all you do\u2014marriage, family, work, recreation\u2014God will give you success if you focus with \u201csingleness of your heart\u201d! \n \n\u201cFor where your treasure is, there will your heart be also\u201d (Matthew 6:21). This is the real key to developing the ultimate success focus. Is our main focus on material riches on this Earth? God wants to give us the universe! (Hebrews 1-2). It is so easy to confine our view to this physical Earth and forget about the incredible reward that God is offering. \n \n\u201cTherefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shall put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment?\u201d (Matthew 6:25). Christ goes on to say that if He provides for the birds and the lilies, why wouldn\u2019t He give us so much more? (verses 26-32). He tells us to take no thought \u2014not to be worried so much about physical things. Real life goes far beyond this temporary existence. \n \n\u201cBut seek ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousness; and all these things shall be added unto you\u201d (verse 33). Here it is! God\u2019s Kingdom should be your ultimate success focus ! Then you will experience the most joyful and successful life imaginable. ▪","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Gerald Flurry"},"topics":[{"name":"Apple news","group":"Companies"}],"title":"Steve Jobs: Focused Like a Laser","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Oklahoma","zipCode":"73034","state":"Oklahoma","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Edmond","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Philadelphia Trumpet","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169819373","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"56"},"name":"Philadelphia Trumpet","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thetrumpet.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204690940","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:00:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

It's un-American' \n\nUpdated: Jan 29, 2017 03:20 AM EST \n\nG. Morty Ortega/ \n\nRelated content \n\n(CNN) - More protests against President Donald Trump's immigration policies are set for Sunday across the country after hundreds of demonstrators converged on airports the day before.. \n\nProtests are scheduled today in Washington, Orlando, Boston, Philadelphia, Atlanta, Seattle, and Chicago, mostly at airports. \n\nThis is the second weekend of demonstrations, with more than 1 million people coming out last weekend for the Women's March. \n\nOlivia Katbi Smith told CNN affiliate KATU she showed up Saturday at Portland International Airport because she believes Trump's immigration policies are cruel. \n\n\"I think it's horrific and terrible and we are basically condemning people to death by not allowing them to come here,\" she said. \n\nShe said the event appeared to be impromptu. She heard about it on Twitter and thinks most people did the same. \n\nIn New York City, a large crowd massed at John F. Kennedy International Airport to protest the detention of two Iraqis who were later released. \n\n\"Mr. President, look at us,\" said US Rep. Nydia Velazquez, a New York Democrat. \"This is America. What you have done is shameful. It's un-American.\" \n\nThe protesters gathered in Terminal 4 at JFK and carried signs reading, \"We are all immigrants!\" and \"No ban! No wall!\" \n\nSeveral New York officials showed support for the protests. \n\nGov. Andrew Cuomo ordered the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to reverse an earlier decision to restrict passage aboard the JFK Airport AirTrain to ticketed passengers and airport employees only. \n\nHe also instructed state police and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to assist with security and transportation for protesters. \n\n\"The people of New York will have their voices heard,\" Cuomo said. \n\nNew York Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted: \"What's happening at JFK is shameful. @NYCImmigrants Affairs Commissioner Nisha Agarwal is on the ground now working to help.\" \n\nAirport arrests \n\nOne of the detained Iraqis, Hameed Khalid Darweesh, was released early Saturday afternoon. He worked with the US government for 10 years after the United States invaded Iraq. \n\nThe other detained Iraqi, Haider Sameer Abdulkaleq Alshawi, had been granted a visa to join his wife, who worked for a US contractor in Iraq, and son, both of whom already live in the United States as refugees. Alshawi was released later Saturday. \n\nThe American Civil Liberties Union argued Saturday evening in a federal court in New York for a nationwide stay that would block the deportation of all people stranded in US airports under what the group called \"President Trump's new Muslim ban.\" \n\nA federal judge in New York granted an emergency stay Saturday night for citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries who have already arrived in the US and those who are in transit, and who hold valid visas, ruling they cannot be removed from the US. \n\nThat move limited part of President Trump's executive order barring citizens from those countries from entering the US for the next 90 days. \n\nRep. Jerrold Nadler, another Democrat from New York, said 10 other travelers were detained, but their status was unclear Saturday night. \n\nVirginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe joined protesters at Dulles International Airport outside Washington. \n\n\"This executive order is antithetical to the values that make America great, and it will make our country less safe,\" he said in a statement. \n\nIn Portland, one demonstrator carried a sign that said, \"Portland coffee comes from Yemen,\" one of the seven Muslim-majority nations on the no-travel list. \n\nLucia Martinez told KATU she used to be a \"hashtag activist\" but felt compelled to protest at the airport. \n\n\"This was the last straw,\" she said of Trump's policies. \"We're all immigrants.\" \n\nA group of community activists, attorneys and others gathered at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. \n\nProtests also took place at airports in Boston; San Francisco, Denver, Dallas and Newark, New Jersey.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Political unrest news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Religion news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Iraq news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Protests against Trump's 'Muslim ban' continue","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Bristol","zipCode":"24201","state":"Virginia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Bristol","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"WCYB-TV","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"173643002","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"39"},"name":"WCYB-TV","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Politics","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.wcyb.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204691630","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. Qantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. The executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country.\n\nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely.\n\nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa.\n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government.\n\nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said.\n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals.\n\n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\"\n\nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination.\n\n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said.\n\n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\"\n\nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. An has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country.\n\nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. Pauline was born in Smyth County, Va. to the late James S. and Demma Osborne Hayes and was preceded in death by her brothers, Bill, Bob, Rush and Roy Hayes; sisters, Robena Jo Hayes and Dorothy Jane Mays. She made her home in Catlet, Va. for over 46 years and was a graduate of Sugar Grove High School, class of 1963. She was an employee of Walmart in Warrenton, Va. where she worked as a people greeter. She was a member of the Auburn Baptist Church and was devoted wife, mother, grandmother and sister who will be missed dearly. She had many friends and was loved by everyone, all of whom showed how much during her illness. She was an extraordinary person. Virginia or Pauline, which ever name you may know her by, is survived by her loving husband, George Kirk, best known as Red; her son, Michael Kirk; granddaughter, Emily Kirk; grandson, Owen Kirk all of Catlett, Va.; her sisters, Mary Dutton, Leesburg, Shirley Powers and husband, Junior, Marion, Stella Maharg, Newark, Ohio, Irene Wyatt and husband, John, Marion, Judy Hopkins, Marion; many nieces and nephews. Interment will follow in Kirk Cemetery. The family will receive friends on Sunday, January 29, 2017, from 6 to 8 p.m. at the Bradley's Funeral Home or any time at the home of Fran Hayes. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to St. Judes Children's Hospital. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to the family at www.bradleysfh.com . The hall will be open to the public until 2 p.m. and will feature \"life-affirming booths and vendors.\" There will also be light refreshments available for a nominal fee. \n \nMembers of the Knights of Columbus Precious Blood Council 4454 are planned to arrive at 9 a.m at Selinger, and at 9:30 a.m., the pre-march rally with speakers will begin. \n \nThis year's speakers are Ryan Bomberger and Dr. Vansen Wong. \n \nBomberger co-founded the Radiance Foundation with his wife, Bethany. \n \nHe describes himself as a broadcast media designer, producer, columnist and author. Beyond media production and appearances, the Radiance Foundation's website said Bomberger travels the country as a pro-life activist and fundraiser. \n \nWong is an OB-GYN from Roseville, California. He used to perform abortions as part of his practice in Sacramento but quit offering the procedure after seven years to become a pro-life advocate. \n \nHe is affiliated with the Kaiser Permanente Medical Group, is a medical director of the Alternatives Pregnancy Center in Sacramento, and has testified in favor of pro-life legislation in the California Legislature, according to the March for Life website. \n \nThe march to the Capitol is scheduled to begin at 10 a.m. at St. Peter Church. It will proceed north \u2014 past the Governor's Mansion \u2014 to Madison Street, then onto High Street toward the Capitol. The route is approximately three-quarters of a mile. \n \nThe rally inside the Capitol Rotunda on the first floor is set to begin at 10:30 a.m. During the rally, the \"Patriot and Statesman for Life\" award will be presented by Team P.L.A.Y. \n \nLunch is scheduled to follow at noon at Selinger Hall. Chili and hot dogs will be prepared by the Knights of Columbus for a nominal fee to help cover event expenses. \n \nAt 2 p.m., a Mass for Life will be at St. Peter Church. Bishop John Gaydos of the Catholic Diocese of Jefferson City will be the principal celebrant. \n \nThe collection at the Mass will go toward covering expenses of the march. \n \nOther guests are listed as Mark Serafino; Bridget Van Means of ThriVe Express Women's Healthcare; Reagan Barklage of Students for Life of America; Steve Rupp, president of Missouri Right to Life; Zina Hackworth of This Race Will Self-Destruct; The movie is nominated, you are nominated, it's all good. Don't think about it, please just celebrate.'\" \n\n\"Arrival\" was competing for best film at the PGAs alongside \"Deadpool,\" \"Fences,\" \"Hacksaw Ridge,\" \"Hell or High Water,\" \"Hidden Figures,\" \"La La Land,\" \"Lion,\" \"Manchester by the Sea\" and \"Moonlight.\" \n\n\"Blade Runner 2049\" -- which comes out in October, some 35 years after the cult neo-noir original -- sees Harrison Ford reprising his role as Rick Deckard, this time opposite Ryan Gosling. \n\n\"It was like the most powerful and intense cinematic experience of my life. .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... .......... \n SAN DIEGO \u2013 When the story of Barack Obama\u2019s presidency is finally written, I hope biographers dedicate a few pages to the 44th president\u2019s abysmal record on the issue that seems to have most baffled him: immigration. \nRight off the bat, Obama put himself on impossible footing by trying to be simultaneously compassionate and tough. He wanted to please Latinos who identify with immigrants so much that they want to give the undocumented legal status, and also union members who are so afraid of competition that they would prefer to hand them a one-way ticket out of the country. \n \nUltimately, Obama took care of labor and settled for trying to fool Latinos into thinking he was in their corner. In reality, he was working against their interests by deporting a record number of people. \n \nIn his first term, Obama wasted a lot of time and energy arguing with supporters who wanted him to stop deportations \u2013 or at least slow them down \u2013 and denying that he had the executive authority to act without Congress. \n  \n \nContinue reading \n    \nIn his second term, he miraculously found that power and gave so-called Dreamers \u2013 undocumented young people brought here as children \u2013 a two-year reprieve from deportations. \n \nObama went from soliciting Latino votes in the 2008 election by promising to tackle immigration reform in his first 100 days to never getting around to crafting a remedy for the estimated 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States. \n \nAnd he went from criticizing the George W. Bush administration for sending federal agents to arrest nursing mothers who were \u201ctorn from their babies\u201d to essentially deputizing, through Secure Communities, thousands of local and state police officers to enforce federal immigration law by checking the immigration status of anyone with whom they came in contact. \n \nIn recent weeks, the same person who \u2013 in August 2010 \u2013 signed a $600 million border security bill proposed by Senate Democrats that put more agents, fencing and equipment on the U.S.-Mexico border expressed worry about his successor\u2019s plan to build a border wall. \n \nIt\u2019s surreal to hear Obama and other Democrats express their indignation at the idea that people could be deported and families separated when, for the past eight years, this has been standard operating procedure for the Obama administration and the party that covered up for it. \n \nThere needs to be an honest and serious accounting of Obama\u2019s cynical and cruel immigration record. \n \nAnd yet we can\u2019t very well expect the media to provide it. They\u2019re too busy scrutinizing the current president for threatening to do much of what the last one already did. \n \nAt the same time, we have pro-Obama spinners who are trying to wipe his record clean and convince us all that the bad stuff never happened. \n  \n \nContinue reading \n    \nIt happened, and it went like this. \n \nAfter winning election in 2008, Obama recruited as his chief of staff Rahm Emanuel who, while he was in Congress, worked hard to keep immigration reform off the agenda. And he named as his first homeland security secretary Janet Napolitano who, as Arizona governor, declared a state of emergency on the border. \n \nOnce in office, Obama broke his vow to make immigration reform a priority, deported about 3 million people, divided hundreds of thousands of families and put into foster care tens of thousands of U.S.-born children whose parents got deported. \n \nHe also pushed back initially against those immigration reformers who asked that he use executive power to halt deportations, claimed falsely that his administration was only deporting criminals and then tried to pin the whole debacle on Republicans. \n \nAnd when faced \u2013 in the summer of 2014 \u2013 with tens of thousands of women and child refugees from Central America streaming across the U.S.-Mexico border, Obama ordered most them deported without due process, jailed thousands of others, including infants and toddlers who were put in what activists have come to refer to as \u201cbaby jails,\u201d and released others into the custody of relatives in the United States \u2013 only to round them up two years later. \n \nWhile all this was happening, the liberal media seemed not all that interested and said very little. \n \nIt\u2019s no wonder they\u2019re so fired up now to go after President Trump on his immigration crackdown. After a siesta that lasted eight long years, they\u2019ve got to be well rested. \n \nCopyright, The Washington Post Writers Group.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US immigration news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"US politics news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Media suffers amnesia regarding Obama\u2019s record on immigration","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Bernalillo","zipCode":"87109","state":"New Mexico","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Albuquerque","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"Albuquerque Journal","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169660875","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"3746"},"name":"Albuquerque Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.abqjournal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204708173","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:20Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:22:10Z","duplicateGroupId":"29362941501","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"TARIFFS & DUTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"JOB CREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EMPLOYMENT GROWTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"TAX LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"TAX REFORM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"65"},{"name":"TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS; ECONOMIC POLICY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"TAXES & TAXATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FREE TRADE TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"FRUITS & VEGETABLES","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"DEREGULATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"PUBLIC POLICY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL TRADE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ECONOMIC NEWS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"EXPORT & IMPORT LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"NORTH AMERICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"747","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396211152&p=2kx&v=1&x=lxNE96MDpu4eJHiUZY64SQ","id":"29396211152","content":"It is still early days, but a picture of the economic policy approach favored by President Donald Trump is gradually coming into focus. Here are some of its key features as signaled by the words and actions of the administration in its first week in office: \n \nIt is targeting higher growth and greater job creation using what can be called an \"import- substitution-plus\" approach to policy making, together with elements of an industrial policy: \n \nIn a manner reminiscent of traditional import-substitution strategies, the Trump administration is seeking to attract to the U.S. production facilities that serve the domestic market from abroad. Also, and this is where the \"plus\" comes in, it is seeking to bring to America foreign-based production facilities that serve non-U.S. markets. To amplify the desired impact on jobs and wages, the administration is adding elements of industrial policy in its interactions with certain sectors (automobiles, for example). \n \nIt operates both at the micro and macro levels : \n \nThis focus highlights the mix of macro and micro interventions being pursued by the administration. The macro level is dominated by four strains: deregulation, tax reform, infrastructure and changing incentives to favor domestic production and the consumption of U.S.-made goods and services. The micro combines sectoral emphasis with the selective application of moral suasion to individual companies and even specific projects. \n \nIt actively uses signals and narratives as economic policy tools: \n \nConventional economists will tend to dismiss the overall impact of such micro measures, but others will note that the signaling effect could be consequential -- through their impact in altering narratives, expectations and behaviors at the more general level. This effect is turbocharged by the president's repeated emphasis on jobs and the active use of a range of communication tools, including more informal ones such as Twitter. \n \nIt is underpinned by a carrot and stick philosophy: \n \nThe message is amplified by an evolving implicit contract between the administration and the business sector that is underpinned by carrots and sticks -- notably the incentives of less onerous regulation and lower taxes and the threats of shaming and punishing businesses that aren't sufficiently responsive to the admonition to \"put America first.\" \n \nWhen it comes to cross-border relationships, the administration isn't shy about upending multidecade constants in U.S. economic policy making: \n \nThis approach seemingly also extends to a willingness to depart from long-established rules and practices governing cross-border relationships -- from talking down the dollar and withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership to threatening to dismantle the North America Free Trade Agreement and to impose tariffs that would be inconsistent with commitments under the World Trade Organization. In the process, and as part of a negotiating strategy with other countries, the administration is signaling its willingness to question and upend, if necessary, deeply engrained principles of international economic management. \n \nIt remains to be seen how all this will come together, especially as many policy intentions haven't made the tricky transition from announcement to detailed design and sustained implementation. Also, Congress will have a say in this process. Despite that, some economists are already comparing the evolving U.S. economic policy approach to those that were pursued in Latin America by populist governments. Veterans of development economics, in particular, are being reminded of the import-substitution growth models that were pursued, on more than one occasion, by such countries as Argentina and Brazil. \n \nBut that comparison could be premature, and perhaps even misleading; and not just because of the very different initial economic and financial conditions prevailing in the U.S. \n \nIf sustained, the impact of Trump's approach would extend well beyond changes to the internal workings and orientations of the U.S. economy, including how it picks and chooses the way it interacts with the global economy . Given that the U.S. is at the core of the international monetary system, what happens here would not stay here. It would most likely trigger reactions from other countries while potentially also shaking the conventional functioning of a rule-based global system. \n \nIf this is managed in a collaborative manner that balances countries' domestic and global responsibilities, the result could be the type of generalized policy revamp that is critical for sustaining high and more inclusive growth and for delivering genuine financial stability. But if it is done in an internationally disjointed and uncoordinated fashion, the result would tend toward greater global economic fragmentation. This would reduce both current and future growth and prosperity while increasing the risk of unsettling financial instability down the road. \n \nThis post  originally appeared  on Bloomberg View.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Mohamed El-Erian"},"topics":[{"name":"Finance latest","group":"Finance"}],"title":"Trump's Economic Approach Starts To Take Shape","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"Seeking Alpha","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169663873","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1282"},"name":"Seeking Alpha","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Financials"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.seekingalpha.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-01-23/trump-said-to-meet-with-dow-ceo-liveris-labor-leaders-on-monday","http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-01-23/trump-said-to-sign-executive-order-on-trans-pacific-pact-monday","http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-24/trump-protectionism-might-help-emerging-markets-hedge-fund-says","http://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-01-26/trump-s-economic-approach-starts-to-take-shape"],"sequenceId":"695204709270","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:22:10Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:23Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:23Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396211125","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MICHAEL BROWN SHOOTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RURAL COMMUNITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"TORNADOES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"SHERIFFS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"DEATHS & INJURIES BY POLICE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"RETIREMENT & RETIREES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"LAKES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"LAW ENFORCEMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"POLICE FORCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERVIEWS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"JEFFERSON CITY, MO, USA; UNITED STATES; MISSOURI, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MISSOURI, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JAY NIXON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"1101","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396211125&p=2kx&v=1&x=RynoeYapbvJU7y3eZPVEoQ","id":"29396211125","content":"Missouri State Highway Patrol Col. J. Bret Johnson grew up on a farm near Unionville in rural Putnam County, worked for the sheriff's department for a couple years after high school \u2014 and joined the Patrol in August 1986. \n \nHe's retiring Wednesday from the superintendent's post \u2014 a job with statewide responsibilities. \n \nThe Patrol requires its members to retire at age 60 \u2014 but Johnson is just 58, so his retirement this week isn't required. \n \n\"If you are going to work (after) the Highway Patrol, I think you have to figure out where you're more marketable,\" he explained in an interview last week. \"You have to make the decision of when's the right time to go.\" \n \nJohnson said he considered retiring a couple years ago while still serving as the Field Operations Bureau's director but stayed when then-Gov. Jay Nixon asked him to succeed Col. Ron Replogle as superintendent in May 2015. \n \nNineteen months later, he coordinated with the incoming Eric Greitens administration to set Feb. 1 as his retirement date. \n \n\"I'm proud of the things that we have accomplished, so I'm glad I stayed,\" he told the News Tribune. \n \nWhile Johnson doesn't know who his successor will be, he has worked with those on his command staff to prepare them for the possibility of being the next superintendent. \n \nCommand staff meetings involving himself, the lieutenant colonel and six majors often involved disagreements on how the Patrol should address issues. \n \n\"We had open discussion (over) long hours,\" Johnson said. \"When we opened these doors and walked out, I felt everyone was on the same page.\" \n \nJohnson was assigned to General Headquarters staff duties in August 2001 and has been part of the command staff since 2007. \n \nThe Patrol faced some major issues during Johnson's work as superintendent and Field Operations director \u2014 including the state's response after the May 2011 Joplin tornado killed more than 160 people, after Michael Brown was killed by Ferguson police officer Darren Wilson, after Brandon Ellingson's May 2014 drowning at the Lake of the Ozarks while in Patrol custody, and the 2010 merger of the highway and water patrols. \n \nHowever, Johnson said, those well-publicized situations didn't change the Patrol, overall. \n \n\"I think, when you live in Jefferson City, those are a lot bigger issues than they are if you're a trooper doing our primary function and living in Kahoka, Hayti, Tarkio\" or elsewhere in the state, he explained. \"I think those issues were more significant for the people who sit around this (command staff) table\" in the superintendent's office. \n \nThe first job inside the Patrol is trooper \u2014 providing basic law enforcement on the state's highways and waterways. \n \nAnd that work begins only after an extensive, six-month training program at the Academy on the hill behind the General Headquarters in Jefferson City. \n \nBefore the new troopers begin working solo, they get in-the-field experience and more training from veterans. \n \n\"Early in your career, I don't think you could ever see yourself being the superintendent,\" Johnson said. \n \nA trooper who wants to become an administrator must first go through the assessment center, which is offered only every two years, he explained. \n \n\"Last year, only 22 percent of our sergeants who took the assessment center even passed it to become eligible to be promoted to lieutenant,\" Johnson said. \"That is the biggest change in our organization, when it comes to rank.\" \n \nWhen Johnson made the switch in 1999, he recalled, the Highway Patrol wasn't using technology in the ways they are now \u2014 and technology has made a major difference in the way the Patrol operates, making it easier to communicate with each other and with other law agencies in other states. \n \n\"We still didn't have email when I came to (Jefferson City-based) Troop F,\" he remembered. \"We had pagers, and the duty lieutenant had a bag-phone for a cellphone. \n \n\"We had no computers in the cars, and we had a computer in the office (where) the reports would come in a hard copy. And the clerical staff would re-type all the reports.\" \n \nThe 2010 Water Patrol merger into the Highway Patrol combined differing law enforcement cultures. \n \n\"Any merger is like a marriage \u2014 it takes time to adjust to each other,\" Johnson noted. \"I certainly had feelings for the administration and those in the Water Patrol who were actually 'losing' their agency \u2014 and we tried to be conscious of that.\" \n \nThe merger was an effort to save the state some money, avoid a cut of 18-20 Water Patrol veterans, and \"gain some efficiencies\" \u2014 and those have happened, Johnson said, although he admitted it's hard to see those efficiencies from the outside. \n \nSeven years after the merger, he said, the biggest change has been better documentation of the training given to recruits on the differences between the road troopers' work and the marine division efforts on Missouri's lakes and rivers. \n \nBecause Trooper Anthony Piercy still faces criminal charges connected with Ellingson's drowning, Johnson declined to discuss the effects that case has had on the Patrol's marine operations. \n \nHe was more open about the effects of Ferguson on law enforcement overall, where the Patrol became directly involved from mid-August through Labor Day 2014. \n \nIt began as a local case, involving the Aug. 9 shooting of an 18-year-old by a local officer, but the shooting and its aftermath attracted international attention. \n \nJohnson said the Highway Patrol troopers who went to St. Louis County helped improve the situation because \"our officers are used to working by themselves. And, in doing so, you have to learn from a very young age to be able to talk with people \u2014 and talk your way out of dangerous or conflicting situations.\" \n \nJohnson said many people still may not understand the complexity of the Patrol's work \u2014 troopers do more than write traffic tickets and investigate accidents. \n \nThey also are involved in overseeing riverboat gambling operations, helping local law agencies in complex drug and crime investigations, operating laboratories that test evidence in criminal cases, and supervising the inspections of motor vehicles and school buses. \n \nAnd what's next for Johnson after his retirement? \n \n\"I'm going to reassess some things,\" he said. \"I'm going to take a little time off.\" \n \nHowever, he already has \"had a few calls\" from people interested in hiring him. \n \nHis son \u2014 who also is a trooper, based in Columbia \u2014 became a father five months ago, so there will be grandchild time. \n \nHis other son works in Chicago, so there will be some travel. \n \nJohnson's wife, Carol, retired from Jefferson City's Public Schools several years ago. \n \n\"I have a lot of habits, but not a lot of hobbies,\" Johnson said. \"We'll have to see how my wife and I will get along, being together more hours than we're used to.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Executive moves news","group":"Business"}],"title":"Johnson ready to retire after 30-year Patrol career","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Cole","zipCode":"65101","state":"Missouri","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Jefferson City","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Jefferson City News Tribune","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"174477660","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"461"},"name":"Jefferson City News Tribune","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newstribune.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://www.mshp.dps.missouri.gov/"],"sequenceId":"695204713634","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:31:23Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

The iHeart80s Party rocked the SAP Center in San Jose, California with a star-studded lineup of artists including New Kids on the Block , UB40 Featuring Ali Campbell, Astro and Mickey, Colin Hay of   Men At Work , Rick Astley , Starship ,  Eddie Money , and Night Ranger . And it was all hosted by iconic MTV personality Martha Quinn, who hosts the iHeart80s Radio's weekday morning show. \n \n{ \"position1\" : { \"type\" : \"live\", \"id\" : 5060, \"name\" : \"iHeart80s Radio\", \"description\" : \"Commercial-Free 80s Hits\" } } \n \nThe night was filled with some RAD moments from all of the performances of the night, amazing fan reactions, special guests, and more.
