to confirm them once we arrive in Singapore,\" he said. \n\n\"It's frustrating, but at the same time the crew is doing their best and the passengers are civilised, so it's not too bad.\" \n\nFlight SQ286 was supposed to depart at 1.30pm but aborted due to potential issues with the nose wheel of the aircraft. \n\nXie thought wind was buffeting the plane as it headed down the runway on its first attempt. \n\n\"The plane was wobbly when we tried to take off, going from side to side,\" he said. \n\nHowever, the aircraft then came to a stop on the tarmac and had to be towed back to the terminal. \n\n\"The captain said there's something wrong with the nose wheel,\" Xie said. \n\nThe flight was initially rescheduled for a 5pm takeoff, but that was repeatedly pushed back. \n\nThe Singapore Airlines office was contacted but refused to comment about the failed takeoff. \n\nThe runway was \"closed for a short time\" about 3pm, possibly to remove debris, an airport spokesman said. \n\nOne plane was diverted from Auckland Airport due to the runway closure. \n\nEmirates flight 406 from Melbourne was due to land at 3.20pm but was diverted to the Ohakea New Zealand Defence Force base, near Bulls, the spokesman said. \n\nLocals in Ohakea remarked on Twitter it was unusual to see an Airbus A380 at the base. Did I just see an A380 land at RNZAF Ohakea...? Nooo I must be seeing things. Ad Feedback \u2014 NZAviation.com (@NZAviation) January 29, 2017 Looks like Ohakea's got an unexpected guest. pic.twitter.com/dzQiua1y2h \n\n\u2014 Matthew (@OuterLegsRace) January 29, 2017 There were about 430 passengers on the Emirates flight, which arrived in Auckland just after 6pm. \n\nMeanwhile, Emirates flight 345 to Brisbane and Dubai was also delayed on the tarmac at Auckland Airport. \n\nIt was supposed to depart at 6.10pm, but it's understood a passenger on board fell ill, and the flight eventually left at 7.55pm. - Stuff","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"JOEL INESON"},"topics":[{"name":"Airline industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Asia-Pacific latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Singapore news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Southeast Asia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"New Zealand news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Stranded Singapore Airlines flight leaves Auckland Airport after seven-hour wait","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","countryCode":"NZ","country":"New Zealand"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Manawatu Standard","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169677392","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1076"},"name":"Manawatu Standard","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://stuff.co.nz"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://twitter.com/NZAviation/status/825530491809861633","https://t.co/dzQiua1y2h","https://twitter.com/OuterLegsRace/status/825560481599410176"],"sequenceId":"695204779827","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:26:57Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:00Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"https://static2.stuff.co.nz/1485678435/479/17272479.jpg"}],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:04Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396215006","companies":[{"symbol":"PBV","primary":true,"name":"Prestige Brands Holdings Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US74112D1019"},{"symbol":"PBH","primary":true,"name":"Prestige Brands Holdings Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US74112D1019"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"CUSTOMS & CULTURAL HERITAGE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"RESTAURANTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"72"},{"name":"HISTORIC SITES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"AFGHANISTAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"TEHRAN, IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF; IRAN","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"99"},{"name":"SHIRAZ, IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF; IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"2201","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396215006&p=2kx&v=1&x=wEvZXmd-rku6sLBEMsDUIA","id":"29396215006","content":"Follow us discovering the fascinating history and spectacular sights on the road from Shiraz to Tehran! \n \n\n \nHow was your trip to Iraq\u2026 or was it Afghanistan?\u201d a friend asked at a recent dinner party. Another pulled me aside to enquire if I\u2019d needed a bodyguard. I had, in fact, been on a 10-day tour of Iran, journeying by luxury coach from the southern city of Shiraz to the capital, Tehran, with a group of 15 other adventurous souls. \n \nTheir confusion was understandable. I\u2019d probably have reacted the same way before experiencing first-hand the utterly beguiling yet much-misunderstood country. After all, back in 2002 Iran was lumped, together with North Korea and Iraq, into US President George W Bush\u2019s \u201caxis of evil.\u201d Since then, unrelenting media coverage of its controversial nuclear programme, placard-waving hate mobs and \u201cDeath to America\u201d murals have done little to dispel this stereotype\u2014but change is afoot. \n \nFollowing last summer\u2019s nuclear deal and the recent lifting of economic sanctions, the world is starting to see Iran as something other than a threat. European governments, including the UK\u2019s, are relaxing travel warnings and the Islamic republic is rapidly becoming a \u201cmust-visit\u201d destination. With its incredible ancient monuments, imperial palaces, dazzlingly decorated mosques, bustling bazaars, breathtaking landscapes, and no less than 20 Unesco World Heritage sites, it\u2019s like no other country I\u2019ve visited and rightly deserves a place on travel hotlists.   \n \nAs for the Iranian people, well, at times a bodyguard might come in handy if only to manage the sheer number of well-wishers who\u2019ll greet you on the streets with big smiles and endless questions. You only need exchange a few simple pleasantries and bingo, you\u2019ll be invited to pull up a chair at their family dinner table. Iranians are intensely proud of their national cuisine and will openly, and ardently, share their frustration about the lack of dishes available to tourists. This is because outside Tehran, the majority of restaurants only serve a monotonous menu of kebabs\u2014for lunch and dinner.   \n \nAs Anthony Bourdain reveals in the Iran episode of his food flavoured Parts Unknown travel series, \u201cThis is a land of secret recipes passed down through families like treasured possessions.\u201d He\u2019s referring to delicious, complex and time-consuming dishes that are mainly served in the home: cardamom infused rice layered with chicken and barberries; pomegranate, walnut and meatball stew; lamb koftas with cranberry, cumin and pine nuts drizzled with spiced orange yoghurt. So if you want something other than sizzling slabs of meat for 10 days straight, just smile, say \u201csalaam\u201d and you\u2019ll eat like a Persian king or queen.  \n \nIran is certainly a country of contradictions and contrasts, and this will be a constant source of fascination as you explore its riches. For example, the city at the start of our tour, Shiraz, shares its name with the world-famous grape variety. The surrounding hills were once blanketed with vines that produced excellent wines, but today not one bottle is produced in the region\u2014or anywhere in Iran. Alcohol has been forbidden since the Pahlavi dynasty was ousted in the Iranian Revolution of 1979, which imposed Islamic law and theocratic rule. Even the word wine is banned from books published in the Islamic republic.  \n \nThe punishment for possessing or imbibing is at best a hefty fine, possibly a public lashing\u2014 or in extreme cases, execution.  \n \nDespite the severe penalties, I discovered alcohol consumption is widespread\u2014behind closed doors. I got the low-down from a daringly candid group of forty-something Shirazis I met while trying the local delicacy faloodeh, a refreshing but intensely sweet sorbet textured with noodles and doused with rose or lime syrup. As we sat around the dessert stall in the shade of a blossoming orange tree, a man whipped out his mobile phone and scrolled through a list of names with the suffix \u201c.drink,\u201d the first one being \u201cSaeed.drink.\u201d \n \n\u201cWe don\u2019t have bars or nightclubs anymore,\u201d he explained, \u201cso we throw parties secretly at home or we hire villas out in the countryside with DJs. Men and women wear what they like. We call up these illegal alcohol sellers, like people in America might call their drug dealers,\u201d he says, sending his pals into fits of nervous titters, \u201cand they come with their car boots filled with every type of alcohol you could imagine. Sure, it\u2019s expensive, but we want to party just like everyone else.\u201d \n \nA more reputable pastime in Iran is picnicking, and Shirazis are indisputably the nation\u2019s best. Not just in public gardens, but on pavements, between parked cars and even on the grassy centres of mini-roundabouts. Cast an inquisitive glance and earn yourself  a place on their rug.  \n \nYou\u2019d be forgiven for thinking boxing is a popular sport in Shiraz, given the number of black eyes and bandaged noses you\u2019ll spot on the busy streets. Our guide laughs at the suggestion and flags down a passing couple bearing injuries. Proudly, these complete strangers unabashedly talk us through the cosmetic procedures they underwent two months earlier. Another couple of strangers stop to show off identical, slightly upturned, doll-like noses sculpted about a year ago. \n \nIran is the nose-job capital of the world and far from being embarrassed, Iranians wear their bandages with pride, like a Birkin or Louboutins. Such is the prestige associated with plastic surgery that there is even a trend for faking it. Young Iranians\u2014both men and women\u2014use make-up to blacken their eyes and bandage their noses to give the impression they\u2019ve gone under the knife.  \n \nThat the pursuit of beauty through cosmetic surgery is so widespread and accepted is bemusing in a country that requires women, by law, to cover their head and hair in public, and to wear loose-fitting clothes to hide feminine curves\u2014with failure to comply risking fines, flogging or imprisonment. But Iran is rapidly changing and the strict religious dress code is being pushed to its limit, especially in the main cities, where you\u2019ll see women in skinny jeans, skyscraper heels, daringly tight manteaus (long jackets), heavy make-up and headscarves covering little but the tips of their ponytails.  \n \nWhile it would be easy to fill your days just strolling, chatting and soaking up the local culture, our bespoke itinerary\u2014crafted by luxury tour operator Country Holidays as part of its Signature Departures collection\u2014was packed from dawn to dusk. It was a little exhausting at times but there\u2019s not one site I\u2019d skip\u2014even if it did mean 6am wake-up calls on most days. Upgrading to a Signature Departures tour guaranteed us a more personal experience thanks to the small size of the group (16 is the maximum), expert guides, thoughtfully curated dining experiences and well-chosen hotels.  \n \nOur first day in Shiraz was epic, starting with the Nasir-ol-Molk Mosque, where we were bathed in kaleidoscopic light as the morning sun blazed through beautiful stained-glass windows. Other highlights included Narenjestan-e Qavam, a gorgeous 19th-century house and garden with orange groves and a central canal, and the tomb of the famous 14th-century poet Shamsuddin Muhammad Hafez, a son of Shiraz. \n \nWhile visiting the tomb, pay one of the canary wielding men at the main gate and his bird will pull from a box a piece of paper bearing one of Hafez\u2019s verses. Like a fortune teller, the bird\u2019s master will interpret the words\u2019 significance for you. At the nearby tomb of Saadi, a famous poet from the 13th century, men gather to sing heartfelt renditions of his poetry under the mausoleum\u2019s mosaic dome.  \n \nOn day two, we head out to the ancient ruins of Persepolis, whose name means \u201cCity of Persians.\u201d Built more than 2,000 years ago as the ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid empire, the crumbling monuments and tombs strewn across a dry, barren landscape are a phenomenal reminder of the majesty and might of the once-great civilisation.  \n \nWe wake the following day in the desert city of Yazd, home to one of the world\u2019s oldest religions, Zoroastrianism. The sombre-sounding Towers of Silence make for an intriguing, if a little eerie, start to the day. The circular hilltop monuments are where the Zoroastrians once left their dead to be eaten by vultures and wild dogs. These \u201csky burials\u201d were supposedly banned in the 1960s as the city began to sprawl and residents started making grisly discoveries in their yards. \n \nAfter a whirlwind 24 hours in Yazd, we bid farewell to its memorable skyline dotted with wind towers\u2014a traditional form of natural air conditioning\u2014and punctuated by the turquoise-tiled minarets of the Jameh Mosque, and make the four-hour journey to Isfahan.  \n \nThere\u2019s a saying in Iran that Isfahan is \u201chalf the world,\u201d something Country Holidays must have taken into account when dedicating two days and three nights of our tour to this beautiful city. It\u2019s also home to one of the country\u2019s most famous hotels, the Abbasi, which although rather underwhelming on the inside, has a beautiful central courtyard blooming with flowers and dotted with frothing fountains.  \n \nThe best place to immerse yourself in local life is Isfahan\u2019s elegant and spacious Imam Square, a former polo field once watched over by the king from the nearby Ali Qapu Palace. Behind the archways that fringe the square is a bustling, maze-like bazaar dating back to the 17th century where you can snap up the fiery red stigmas of saffron for a bargain price, traditional blue and white enamel dishes, Persian rugs, camel bone jewellery boxes and a delicious nougat-like local speciality called gaz. From the \n \nFrom the square you can explore the Imam Mosque, the Sheikh Lotfollah Mosque and the palace. Their blazing blue-tiled mosaic arches, impossibly intricate geometric domes and spiralling carved columns are all showstopping examples of Islamic architecture. As the sun sinks towards the horizon, head to Si-o-Seh Bridge, where the locals regularly break into song or impromptu performances of poetry. \n \nAfter a brief visit to the remote mountain village of Abyaneh\u2014a labyrinth of red mudbrick houses where villagers in traditional dress stroll with their donkeys\u2014Tehran comes as a slap in the face. But once you\u2019ve adjusted to the insane traffic and smog, the designer boutiques, blossoming cafe culture, cool art galleries and fine dining start to feel as familiar as any Asian or European capital. Preconceptions about Iranian fashion sense go out the window in Tehran, where luxury shopping is becoming big business. \n \nTrendy malls are springing up, emblazoned with glossy advertising for prestige brands such as Louis Vuitton and Rolex. The growing curiosity for couture saw Iran hold its first Fashion Week in the capital last year, and a snoop on Instagram\u2019s Rich Kids of Tehran shows young Iranians are not only obsessed with designer logos, but also with supercars, private jets and gold-plated smartphones. \n \nLast year the capital received a creative jolt when 1,500 billboards were adorned with replicas of works by local artists and famous names such as Picasso, Matisse and Munch, along with traditional Persian miniatures, carpets and calligraphy. Titled \u201cA Gallery as Big as a Town,\u201d the 10-day project was aimed at changing perceptions about the city and boosting visitor numbers. Judging by the crowds jostling to see the treasures at the National Museum of Archaeology and the long queues at the National Jewellery Museum, the campaign certainly did its job. \n \nMake sure you catch a glimpse of the latter\u2019s pink diamond, said to be the largest uncut diamond in the world, and the Globe of Jewels, made in 1869 using 51,366 precious stones. Also make time to marvel at the craftsmanship of Iran\u2019s most famous export at the National Carpet Museum. Other highlights include Golestan Palace, the jewel-encrusted former home of the Qajar royal family, and the Azadi Tower, a striking 50m-high monument built in 1971 to commemorate the 2,500th anniversary of the founding of the first Persian empire. \n \nWhile the Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art is definitely worth a visit, art connoisseurs and collectors looking for investment opportunities should do a sweep of the city\u2019s top art galleries (see right). Interest in modern and contemporary Iranian art intensified last year, with record amounts being paid. A work by the late Sohrab Sepehri became the most expensive painting to sell at auction in Iran, fetching about US$800,000 last May. Other works attracting large sums include those of New York-based artist Manoucher Yektai and Vancouver-based sculptor Parviz Tanavoli, as well as pieces by Bahman Mohassess and Aydin Aghdashloo.  \n \nIt\u2019s also worth venturing off the beaten track to discover the work of Tehran\u2019s law-defying street artists. The most famous and prolific is the Banksy-esque Mehdi Ghadyanloo, who works secretly through the night to transform drab concrete surfaces into surreal magical dreamscapes featuring flying cars, fairies and giraffes.  \n \nWhile the number of people visiting Iran is still relatively low, industry experts predict the country will be the next travel hotspot. Late last year, France\u2019s Accor Hotels became the first Western hospitality group to enter the Iranian market\u2014a hint of a tourism boom to come. So if you want to hold court at a dinner party with exclusive tales of this enchanting country, go now. In the words of the 14th-century Persian poet Rumi, \u201cTravel brings power and love back to your life.\u201d Expect to be smitten.  \n \n(Text by Jakki Phillips; Photo by Lucie Debelkova)   \n \nTags: Travel , Destination , Shiraz To Tehran , Iran \n  \nWorld\u2019s Largest Hotel Chains Opens First Golf Resort in China \n  travel","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Consumer: travel news","group":"Lifestyle"}],"title":"Travel From Shiraz to Tehran, Unveiling the True Beauty of Iran","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"South-Eastern Asia","countryCode":"ID","country":"Indonesia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Indonesia Tatler","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"191630188","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1"},"name":"Indonesia Tatler","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["TravelTourism","Recreation","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.indonesiatatler.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204784598","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:04Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Jaitley may hike service tax rate to 16-18 per cent from the current 15 per cent in the Budget, due on Wednesday, as a precursor to the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rollout. \n\nThe move, that will make flying, eating out, phone bills and a host of other services expensive, would be an attempt to take the rates closer to the proposed tax slabs for GST. \n\nGST, which will subsume central and state levies like excise duty, service tax and VAT, is scheduled to be rolled out from July 1. \n\nThe tax slabs decided for the GST are 5, 12, 18 and 28 per cent and taking service tax closer to one of the slabs is a logical move in the Budget, tax experts said. \n\nTax experts say, Jaitley, who had in his previous budget hiked service tax rate by 0.5 per cent to 15 per cent, may raise the levy by at least one percentage point to 16 per cent. \n\nSome others feel there could be different service tax rates with a lower 12 per cent for basic services and a higher 18 per cent for the rest. \n\nAlso, a higher service tax for April-June will help the government garner more revenue to meet expenses on schemes and programmes it may be planning to contain the impact of demonetisation. \n\nA service tax rate closer to the GST rate will also help consumers avoid a greater price shock when the new national sales tax is rolled out. \n\nWhile service tax until now is a central levy, it will be equally split between the Centre and states under the new GST regime. Most services, except essential ones like primary healthcare and basic education, will be covered by GST. \n\nService tax was budgeted to provide Rs 2.31 lakh crore in 2016-17, more than 14 per cent of the Centres total tax revenues of Rs 16.30 lakh crore. \n\nThis will be the third time that Jaitley will raise service tax rate. Service tax from June 1, 2015 was hiked from 12.36 per cent to 14 per cent. A 0.5 per cent Swachh Bharat Cess was levied on all services, taking the total incidence of service tax to 14.5 per cent from November 15, 2015. \n\nIn the last Budget, he imposed a Krishi Kalyan Cess at the rate of 0.5 per cent on all taxable services to take the levy to 15 per cent.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Tax news","group":"Finance"}],"title":"FM may hike service tax to 16-18% in Budget","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"2","name":"Deccan Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169658157","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"67"},"name":"Deccan Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.deccanherald.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204789268","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T02:51:47Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:06Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Morty Ortega/ \n\nRelated content \n\n(CNN) - More protests against President Donald Trump's immigration policies are set for Sunday across the country after hundreds of demonstrators converged on airports the day before. \n\nProtests are scheduled Sunday in Washington, Orlando, Boston, Philadelphia, Atlanta, Seattle, and Chicago, mostly at airports. \n\nThis is the second weekend of demonstrations, with more than 1 million people coming out last weekend for the Women's March. \n\nOlivia Katbi Smith told CNN affiliate KATU she showed up Saturday at Portland International Airport because she believes Trump's immigration policies are cruel. \n\n\"I think it's horrific and terrible and we are basically condemning people to death by not allowing them to come here,\" she said. \n\nShe said the event appeared to be impromptu. She heard about it on Twitter and thinks most people did the same. \n\nIn New York City, a large crowd massed at John F. Kennedy International Airport to protest the detention of two Iraqis who were later released. \n\n\"Mr. President, look at us,\" said US Rep. Nydia Velazquez, a New York Democrat. \"This is America. What you have done is shameful. It's un-American.\" \n\nThe protesters gathered in Terminal 4 at JFK and carried signs reading, \"We are all immigrants!\" and \"No ban! No wall!\" \n\nSeveral New York officials showed support for the protests. \n\nGov. Andrew Cuomo ordered the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to reverse an earlier decision to restrict passage aboard the JFK Airport AirTrain to ticketed passengers and airport employees only. \n\nHe also instructed state police and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to assist with security and transportation for protesters. \n\n\"The people of New York will have their voices heard,\" Cuomo said. \n\nNew York Mayor Bill de Blasio tweeted: \"What's happening at JFK is shameful. @NYCImmigrants Affairs Commissioner Nisha Agarwal is on the ground now working to help.\" \n\nAirport arrests \n\nOne of the detained Iraqis, Hameed Khalid Darweesh, was released early Saturday afternoon. He worked with the US government for 10 years after the United States invaded Iraq. \n\nThe other detained Iraqi, Haider Sameer Abdulkaleq Alshawi, had been granted a visa to join his wife, who worked for a US contractor in Iraq, and son, both of whom already live in the United States as refugees. Alshawi was released later Saturday. \n\nThe American Civil Liberties Union argued Saturday evening in a federal court in New York for a nationwide stay that would block the deportation of all people stranded in US airports under what the group called \"President Trump's new Muslim ban.\" \n\nA federal judge in New York granted an emergency stay Saturday night for citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries who have already arrived in the US and those who are in transit, and who hold valid visas, ruling they cannot be removed from the US. \n\nThat move limited part of President Trump's executive order barring citizens from those countries from entering the US for the next 90 days. \n\nRep. Jerrold Nadler, another Democrat from New York, said 10 other travelers were detained, but their status was unclear Saturday night. \n\nVirginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe joined protesters at Dulles International Airport outside Washington. \n\n\"This executive order is antithetical to the values that make America great, and it will make our country less safe,\" he said in a statement. \n\nIn Portland, one demonstrator carried a sign that said, \"Portland coffee comes from Yemen,\" one of the seven Muslim-majority nations on the no-travel list. \n\nLucia Martinez told KATU she used to be a \"hashtag activist\" but felt compelled to protest at the airport. \n\n\"This was the last straw,\" she said of Trump's policies. \"We're all immigrants.\" \n\nA group of community activists, attorneys and others gathered at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. \n\nProtests also took place at airports in Boston; San Francisco, Denver, Dallas and Newark, New Jersey.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"More protests against Trump's immigration policies planned","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"El Paso","zipCode":"80905","state":"Colorado","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Colorado Springs","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"KRDO.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169663107","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"18"},"name":"KRDO.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Politics","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.krdo.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204792728","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:06Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:06:10Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396215401","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"RACISM & XENOPHOBIA","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RACE & ETHNICITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"HOMELESSNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"GAYS & LESBIANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"65"}],"wordCount":"571","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396215401&p=2kx&v=1&x=UeQ_aWBTZcwNUdbPcnu1mg","id":"29396215401","content":"11:06 p.m. CT Jan. 28, 2017 \n    \nThe Rev. Margaret C. Warn-Walker (Photo: Courtesy photo) \n  \nThe thing I love about Abilene is our residents\u2019 willingness to allow people their own beliefs and opinions even if they are different than theirs. \n \nThe people of Abilene have a devout love for God and a desire to live up to God\u2019s expectations, as well as to hold the dignity and respect of all humanity as an important value.  All the faiths represented in the Abilene community promote the love of God and stress its reflection in our loving actions toward one another. It is also a city where people seek out an understanding of other faiths, ideas and political opinions. \n \nSo, in a city that prides itself in living its spiritual values and understanding those of others, I am often asked  what position my church, Exodus Metropolitan Community Church, has on various issues. The election and the new administration was no exception. \n \nAs a church and as individuals, we respect the office of president,whether held by a Republican, Democrat or Independent. As individuals, we may agree or disagree with candidates on various policies. Collectively, we take our responsibility to vote seriously, and we encourage people to speak out when they believe human rights are being violated, or the people of the country are being hurt, bullied or forgotten. \n \nWe also have a homeless outreach as well as several educational outreaches to raise awareness and meet needs in our community and abroad. As a church, locally and internationally, we stand and support the following ideas which we believe to be in keeping with the will of God. \n \n●     First and foremost, Exodus MCC believes in an inclusive, loving God who sees no racial, national or gender boundaries. We are required to love God with all our being and our neighbor as ourselves. We believe that love is not just a feeling but a feeling translated into action that meets the needs of others. An inauguration is about beginnings, but EMCC has never stopped holding up its core values of human rights, respect, and freedom that are basic to the teachings of Jesus whose life and teachings we follow. \n \nIn regards to political and social actions, we: \n \n● hold any administration \u2014 local, state, or national \u2014 accountable for harmful policies and actions. We speak out, meet with our representatives, and let our dream for a whole and healthy country be known to our elected officials. \n \n● believe any violent rhetoric and actions are not partisan politics but dangerous tactics, which create a climate of intolerance and hate. We require that the dignity of all persons be respected. \n \n● name and reject the rising tide of hate crimes against immigrants, people of color, Muslims, the aged, handicapped, LGBTQ people and any other individual or group targeted because of who or what they are. \n \n● deplore the use of derogatory labels. Hateful labels shatter public discourse. Name-calling is the infancy of bullying which evolves into action. If we don't stand up for those being targeted, how can we expect to be defended? \n \n●  would like to see America whole \u2014 through health care for all, through women's health and reproductive rights, through immigrant family reunion, through defending the integrity of Native lands, through support for public schools, jobs  for all, elder care, racial justice and care for the planet. \n \nThe Rev. Margaret C. Warn-Walker is senior pastor of Exodus Metropolitan Community Church in Abilene. \n\n \nRead or Share this story: http://arnne.ws/2jDk1NL","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Margaret C. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:05:58Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396215408","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SPONSORSHIP","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"CONSERVATISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"INTERNET SOCIAL NETWORKING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LIBERALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"SHOCK ADVERTISING","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"}],"wordCount":"588","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396215408&p=2kx&v=1&x=ELczD2PU5W0HXW3OIcs15Q","id":"29396215408","content":"11:05 p.m. CT Jan. 28, 2017 \n    \nMyra Dean (Photo: Courtesy photo) \n  \nThere was a big Facebook flap over a paid advertisement that ran in the Abilene Reporter-News on Jan. 18. It was definitely controversial, but the response on Facebook had me mystified. \n \nI worked at the Reporter-News for a couple of years and I have a unique perspective as a former employee of the paper. I sold ads in the advertising department. It was obvious there was a lot of misinformation on Facebook about how a newspaper operates. \n \nOne of the first things I learned at the ARN is the editorial department is completely separate from the advertising department: editorial is upstairs, advertising is downstairs. The paper did not want even a suggestion that advertisers and their dollars spent could influence what is printed in the editorial content of the paper. It was like having two different companies in the same building. \n \nWhen I did see an editorial person, they were usually sprinting through the advertising department to get to the nearby bathroom! \n \nI called the woman who was, at the time, my supervisor at the paper\u2026.a Christian and a conservative. To be totally transparent, I am conservative, too. \n \nWe were speculating how this ad might have been printed. We agreed there are lots of ways it could have happened. Now, I don\u2019t know how this controversial ad actually went to print, but I can assure you the \"liberal editors\" upstairs were not responsible. Something happened in the advertising process. To suggest that this ad is an act of liberalism by the editorial staff is ludicrous and is totally against the internal policies of the paper. \n \nA lot of kind, caring, involved, giving people work at the newspaper and live in our community. Their kids play with our kids. They go to church, pray and volunteer with us. They\u2019re our neighbors and friends. They get up every day (and night) to cover stories they think will be of interest to us. \n \nThe Abilene Reporter-News also supports and sponsors many events and activities here in the Big Country. We may not agree with the editorial views, but we can certainly appreciate the local stories and events they cover and their contributions to our city. If an ad offends us, we can turn the page. If we don't agree with an editorial, we can be vocal and let them know or even write an op-ed piece like this one to express our own ideas and opinions. \n \nIf you don't value our hometown newspaper, talk to someone who no longer has a newspaper in their town. \n \nWhen we go after the paper, we're not only hurting the newspaper, we\u2019re hurting the hard working people there and our community. I know I want the paper to continue to be here to report on what's going on in Abilene and the Big Country. I am a conservative and I'm fighting for the principle that I thought conservative people value \u2014 freedom for everyone, even if the ad they submit and pay for is stupid and disgusting. \n \nWhen Republicans only do business with Republicans, Democrats only do business with Democrats and Independents only do business with Independents we are no longer a community. When we only allow ideas that are the same as ours, we are losing our freedom. \n \nI stand with the Abilene Reporter- News as I would any other honest business that takes responsibility for something that happened \"on their watch.\" \n \nMyra Dean is director of development at Global Samaritan Resources. \n \nRead or Share this story: http://arnne.ws/2jDjag2","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Myra Dean, Abilene"},"topics":[{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Newspaper not above criticism but necessary in our town","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Taylor","zipCode":"79601","state":"Texas","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Abilene","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Abilene Reporter","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169730061","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"269"},"name":"Abilene Reporter","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://reporternews.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.gannett-cdn.com/media/2017/01/26/TXGroup/Abilene/636210508200557883-Myra-Dean.jpg","http://arnne.ws/2jDjag2"],"sequenceId":"695204802234","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T05:05:58Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:08Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.gannett-cdn.com/media/2017/01/26/TXGroup/Abilene/636210508200557883-Myra-Dean.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

Together, Congress and the SP will speed up the progress and prosperity in UP, the CM adds.    There is no doubt that we will secure a majority in the Assembly election, Akhilesh says. California Democrats are going on the offensive, firing the first shot in their pitched battle with President Donald J. Trump, and threatening to \u201ccut off the Feds\u201d by withholding taxes.  \nAccording to CBS San Francisco , former State Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, Jr. said: \u201cCalifornia could very well become an organized non-payer. \u2026 They could recommend non-compliance with the federal tax code.\u201d Democrats are considering the tax revolt as part of what CBS San Francisco called an \u201call-out war\u201d against the Trump administration, which could also include holding back state transfers of funds to the federal government. \n  \nSIGN UP FOR OUR NEWSLETTER \n  \nThe list of potential state transfers to Washington is limited, however, according to one expert on the inner workings of California\u2019s government contacted by Breitbart News, who did not wish to be named. He cited the handful of areas where the State of California remits large dollar amounts, including biweekly federal tax withholding from millions of state workers, and worker\u2019s compensation fund payments. \n \nCalifornia is often described as a \u201cdonor state,\u201d  meaning that California remits more money than it takes in federal funds to keep hundreds of entitlement programs afloat. While that may be true, it does not paint an accurate picture of California\u2019s finances. \n \nAs Governor Jerry Brown admitted in his \u201cState of the State\u201d speech last week, the Golden State is dependent on \u201ctens of billions of dollars\u201d to keep Covered California (California\u2019s version of ObamaCare) afloat, such that losing it would blow a hole in California\u2019s budget, creating a massive shortfall. \n \nIf state officials move to stop federal withholdings, that would put California state workers in a very precarious position, and could have profound consequences for the state as a non-compliant employer \u2014 not to mention massive financial penalties that could be assessed. \n \nCalifornia Democrats are accustomed to steamrolling over the weak opposition, to say nothing of crushing individual business large and small, often taking on entire industries like the twin behemoths \u2014 oil and agriculture \u2014 and forcing them to comply or die. \n \n(Remember the Amazon sales tax fight in California?  The world\u2019s most valuable company folded like an empty suit in a hurricane.) \n \nBut California Democrats have never dealt with anyone like our new president.  President Donald J. Trump is not likely to tolerate lawlessness and defiance from a petulant blue minority in a nation turned red. Threats to cut off what would not even amount to 10% of the money flowing from California to Washington, D.C. could trigger President Trump turning off the spigot altogether \u2014 essentially drying up the almost 80% of California funds that are returned to the state in federal funding. \n \nDemocrats, drunk on local power, seem to have forgotten the lessons of 1992 , when Republican Governor Pete Wilson came out and announced, \u201cThis morning, California is running on empty,\u201d and the state began issuing I.O.U.\u2019s in lieu of payment for the first time since the Great Depression. \n \nFailing to remit worker\u2019s compensation funds put California in arrears for decades. \n \nDo Democrats really want to risk California\u2019s solvency by throwing sand in the eye of the Leviathan? \n \nIf the Trump administration holds the \u201cTrump card\u201d simply by shutting off the subsidies for one program \u2014 and Gov. Brown admits they do when it comes to ObamaCare funding \u2014 it is clear which side holds the leverage. \n \nCalifornia is particularly vulnerable because of the dependence of many illegal aliens on public assistance, and on the federal earned income tax credit. \n \nWith the stroke of a pen, President Trump could shut down the state by cutting off or delaying funds. \n \nMoreover, federal funds fuel almost every major institution in California, including: \n Military Bases  K-12 Schools  Public Colleges and Universities (Federal funds, student loans)  Airports  Ports  Federal contracts with technology and defense companies  \nSince the California Constitution forbids deficit funding, the state cannot live off credit cards alone. \n \nWith over $400 billion in debt, and with a state pension system dangerously underfunded, a sustained battle with the federal government would break the already broke state. \n \nTim Donnelly is a former California State Assemblyman. \n \nAuthor, (NASDAQ:OTEX) (TSE:OTC) \u2013 Equities research analysts at National Bank Financial upped their Q2 2017 EPS estimates for shares of Open Text Corporation in a note issued to investors on Thursday. National Bank Financial analyst R. Tse now forecasts that the brokerage will earn $0.31 per share for the quarter, up from their previous estimate of $0.31. Open Text Corporation (NASDAQ:OTEX) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Thursday, November 3rd. The company reported $0.86 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $0.87 by $0.01. Open Text Corporation had a net margin of 61.45% and a return on equity of 19.43%. The firm had revenue of $491.70 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $495.82 million. During the same quarter last year, the business posted $0.84 earnings per share. The firm\u2019s revenue for the quarter was up 13.2% compared to the same quarter last year. The Company designs, develops, markets and sells Enterprise Information Management (EIM) software and solutions. INDIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"492","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396216733&p=2kx&v=1&x=xw02sRo7ib1UY2h-5nlvMw","id":"29396216733","content":"New Delhi: Banks expect Finance Minister Arun Jaitley to announce a slew of measures for the sector in Budget 2017-18, including a hike in FDI limit for public sector lenders to 49 per cent and additional capital infusion to boost credit growth, according to a report. \n \nThe Ficci-IBA Survey of Bankers, which included responses from 17 public, private as well as foreign banks representing 52 per cent of the total banking industry by asset size, said that lenders witnessed a slowdown in credit demand owing to the cash crunch post demonetisation which led to lower consumption. \n \nHowever, many respondents expect credit demand to improve after 3-6 months as economic activities are expected to pick up by that time. On the other hand, flush with liquidity, a majority of banks (82 per cent of those polled) reported a rise in their low cost CASA deposits during the period July-December 2016. \n \nIn fact, 53 per cent of the respondent banks reported a substantial increase in CASA deposits and attributed the same to demonetisation, besides their own efforts to mobilise opening of savings account. \n \nNotably, in the previous survey round, only 25 per cent of respondents had reported a substantial increase, while 50 per cent had reported a moderate increase in such deposits. \n \nLenders believe a hike in foreign direct investment (FDI) limit for state-owned banks (from 20 per cent to 49 per cent) will help in raising further capital and thereby meeting capital requirements under Basel-III norms. \n \nIn the Budget, banks also expect the government to boost consumption demand and investment through reduction in corporate as well as personal income tax, and by providing additional deductions under section 80C and interest on home loans. \n \nWith a thrust on less-cash economy, banks are also eyeing additional incentives for digital transactions, including tax benefits for customers as well as merchants. They have also urged for enhancing capital expenditure, especially for infrastructure. Other key suggestions include measures to fast track NPA resolution, creation of a Central Corporate Repository and interest payment on CRR balance. \n \nBanks also felt interest subvention for farm loans should be parked with them in advance, as it takes 7-8 months for settlement of claims, leading to interest loss. They also want the government to announce additional tax incentives for customers on term deposits, such as reduction in lock-in period for tax saver fixed deposits, and increase in tax exemption limit for interest income from term deposits. \n \nThe survey revealed that iron and steel, infrastructure and textiles continue to account for a large concentration of non-performing assets (NPAs). Overall, the number of banks reporting a rise in the level of NPAs is lower in the current round of the survey as against the preceding round. \n \nWhile 76 per cent of the participating banks reported a rise in the level of NPAs during July-December, 85 per cent had reported so for the preceding six month period. Going forward, the key sectors identified by banks which could see a greater demand for long term credit include infrastructure, automobiles and food processing.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Banking news","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Banks eyeing big-ticket reforms in Budget: survey","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Deccan Chronicle","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169673440","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"137"},"name":"Deccan Chronicle","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.deccanchronicle.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204824151","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:21Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

(NYSE:SPB) \u2013 Equities researchers at Oppenheimer Holdings lifted their Q2 2017 earnings per share estimates for shares of Spectrum Brands Holdings in a report released on Thursday. Oppenheimer Holdings analyst I. Zaffino now forecasts that the brokerage will post earnings of $1.24 per share for the quarter, up from their previous forecast of $1.19. Oppenheimer Holdings also issued estimates for Spectrum Brands Holdings\u2019 Q3 2017 earnings at $1.92 EPS, Q4 2017 earnings at $1.48 EPS and FY2017 earnings at $5.85 EPS. Spectrum Brands Holdings (NYSE:SPB) last released its quarterly earnings results on Thursday, January 26th. The company reported $1.21 earnings per share for the quarter, beating the Zacks\u2019 consensus estimate of $1.16 by $0.05. The company had revenue of $1.21 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts\u2019 expectations of $1.23 billion. Spectrum Brands Holdings had a return on equity of 18.04% and a net margin of 6.58%. The business\u2019s revenue for the quarter was down .7% compared to the same quarter last year. UNITED STATES; NEW JERSEY, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW JERSEY, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"ANDREW CUOMO","domains":["PEO"],"score":"57"},{"name":"TERRY MCAULIFFE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1053","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396216835&p=2kx&v=1&x=ID70dd4Z5Ba4x4e2kwHAsw","id":"29396216835","content":"WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President Donald Trump\u2019s travel ban barring citizens of seven predominantly Muslim nations entry into the U.S. has sparked protests around the country. \n \nA look at what is happening: \n \nNEW YORK \n \nCries of \"Let them in!\" rose up from a crowd of more than 2,000 people protesting at John F. Kennedy Airport, where 12 refugees were detained Saturday. Celebrities including \"Sex and the City\" actress Cynthia Nixon joined the demonstration. \"What Donald Trump did in the last 24 hours is disgusting, disgraceful and completely un-American and I\u2019m here in protest,\" said protester Pamela French. \n \n\n \nThe agency that runs the airport tried to restore order by shutting down the train that runs to airport terminals. Gov. Andrew Cuomo, a Democrat, reversed that decision, saying people had a right to protest. \"The people of New York will have their voices heard,\" he said in a statement. \n \nNEWARK, NEW JERSEY \n \nMore than 120 people clutching signs denouncing the Trump immigration orders gathered at Newark Liberty International Airport. NorthJersey.com reports that they joined lawyers who\u2019d rushed to the airport to defend the rights of refugees and immigrants who were being detained and denied entry. \n \nFAIRFAX, VIRGINIA \n \nDozens of protesters inside Washington Dulles International Airport chanted \"Love, Not Hate, Makes America Great\" and \"Say It Loud, Say it Clear, Muslims Are Welcome Here,\" as travelers walked through a terminal to a baggage claim area to collect luggage and greet their loved ones. There was a heavy police presence during the peaceful protest. Virginia Gov. \n \n\n \nTerry McAuliffe said during a press conference at Dulles that he has asked Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring to look into \"all legal remedies\" available to help individuals who may be detained in Virginia. \n \nDENVER \n \nDozens of people converged on Denver International to show their support for refugees. Standing in the main terminal Saturday, they sang \"Refugees are welcome here.\" Some held signs declaring their identity, such as Jew or Christian, and the phrase \"I come in peace.\" \n \n\n \nDenver has some direct international flights but it wasn\u2019t clear whether anyone has been detained under the president\u2019s executive order. \n \nCHICAGO \n \nA crowd of demonstrators held a rally at O\u2019Hare International Airport. The Chicago Sun-Times reports protesters blocked vehicle traffic to O\u2019Hare\u2019s international terminal for a time. The newspaper says some arriving travelers joined the protest, while others were upset by the demonstrations. \n \nLawyers working with the International Refugee Assistance Project tell the Chicago Tribune that 17 people who had been detained at O\u2019Hare all released by late Saturday. \n \nAmong those released before the federal judge\u2019s order was Hessan Noorian, a suburban Park Ridge resident returning with his family from Iran, the Tribune reported. \n \n\n \nNoorian, who is of British and Iranian citizenship and has a green card, was detained at O\u2019Hare after he and his wife, Zahra Amirisefat, a U.S. citizen, arrived from Tehran, the newspaper said. \n \nThe couple, who told the Tribune that they work at a community college in the Chicago area, said they were questioned for five hours. \n \nAfter Noorian was released, his wife told the Tribune: \"I can\u2019t believe something like this can happen to someone with a green card.\" \n \nDALLAS \n \nProtesters who gathered at Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport Saturday evening voiced their displeasure with Trump\u2019s executive order. The crowd of a few dozen ballooned into hundreds of demonstrators who frequently chanted \"Set them free!\" At times, cheers erupted from the crowd as those who were detained got released. \n \nAmong those still held at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport at midnight Saturday was a 70-year-old Iranian widow, Shahin Hassanpour, whose son said she suffers from high blood pressure and had breast cancer surgery four years ago. She obtained an immigrant visa in November on her son\u2019s petition. \n \nBahzad Honarjou, a 43-year-old network engineer, said he spoke twice to his mother by phone after her 9 a.m. arrival, but that they hadn\u2019t talked since courts stayed the executive order, meaning she should have been released. \n \nHundreds of protesters stood in the waiting area and chanted \"This is what democracy looks like.\" \n \nImmigration agents were not being very communicative, Honarjou said. \n \n\n \n\"They were like a machine when I talked to them today,\" he said. His mother only speaks a few words of English and a fellow passenger was translating for her from her native Farsi as no immigration agents spoke the language, he said. \n \nHassanpour was originally going to be deported on a Sunday flight, she informed her son the first time they spoke. \n \n\"She was about to cry,\" he said. \"She is not able to take (tolerate) a 20-hour flight back to Iran.\" \n \nHonarjou said he is a U.S. citizen, obtained entry in a lottery, and has been in the country for seven years. Why did he come? \n \n\"To have a better life and to make more money,\" he said. \"And, you know, for the freedom.\" \n \nSEATTLE \n \nAbout 1,000 protesters gathered at Seattle-Tacoma Airport, sitting down in the concourse with a large American flag reading \"We are America.\" Aayah Khalaf, a Muslim American, was sitting at home watching the protest on television when she and her friend studying from Egypt decided to join the rally. It was her second time joining a protest. \n \n\n \nThe first one was the Women\u2019s March. \"It\u2019s not just against Muslims. It against environmental rights and human rights overall. I think everybody has to stand up against this,\" said Khalaf, 29. \n \nPORTLAND, OREGON \n \nA protest by several dozen people in and around Portland International Airport briefly disrupted light rail service at the airport. The Oregonian/OregonLive reports that the demonstrators carried signs and chanted \"Say it loud, say it clear, refugees are welcome here\" and \"No ban no wall America is for us all.\" \n \n\n \nLOS ANGELES \n \nAbout 300 people expressed their displeasure with the ban at Los Angeles International Airport Saturday night. Protesters entered the airport\u2019s Tom Bradley International Terminal after holding a candlelight vigil. \n \n\n \nAvriel Epps held a candle and a large photo a drowned 3-year-old Syrian boy who washed up on a Turkish beach in 2015 and became a haunting symbol of the Syrian refugee crisis. \n \nSAN FRANCISCO \n \nHundreds of protesters blocked the street outside at San Francisco International Airport\u2019s international terminal to express their opposition to the barring of some people from Muslim-majority nations. \n \n\n \nSAN DIEGO \n \nAs motorists honked their support, demonstrators outside San Diego International Airport chanted \"No hate, no fear, everyone is welcome here.\" ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Airline industry news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Iran news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Political unrest news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Protests erupt at US airports following Trump travel ban","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"PK","country":"Pakistan"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Dunya News","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169659693","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"41"},"name":"Dunya News","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dunyanews.tv"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204826353","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:22Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

winning that\n\nGrade 1 contest by seven lengths.\n\nFormerly trained by Willie Mullins, whose bid for a seventh consecutive win in the race now relies on Nichols Canyon and Footpad, Petit Mouchoir will be attempting to give owners Gigginstown House Stud a first win in the race, and De Bromhead - successful with Sizing Europe in 2008 - a second victory in the event.\n\nDe Bromhead said of David Mullins' mount: \"He won very well at Christmas and all has gone well with him since. He's in great form and we're looking forward to another good performance.\"\n\nMullins has won every running of the event since current sponsors BHP Insurance became involved in 2011, with Hurricane Fly winning on five occasions before Faugheen's victory a year ago.\n\nThe champion trainer said: \"It's most unfortunate Faugheen misses the race, but he wasn't right yesterday morning and seems to have a muscle problem in his hindquarters.\n\n\"We still have two good horses to represent us and we think Nichols Canyon, who didn't perform when beaten by Petit Mouchoir at Christmas, is back in better form now.\n\n\"As a seven-time Grade 1 winner, he fully deserves a shot at the race. We'll see how things go before deciding whether we keep him to two miles or go back up in trip.\n\n\"Footpad, who won two Grade 1s as a juvenile last season, is difficult to place. While he was well beaten behind Petit Mouchoir and Nichols Canyon in the Ryanair Hurdle last time, we decided to let him take his chance as there is nice prize-money to be won.\"\n\nCompleting the line-up is last year's JCB Triumph Hurdle winner Ivanovich Gorbatov, who has failed to score in six attempts since his Cheltenham Festival victory and who finished third behind Petit Mouchoir and Nichols Canyon last time.\n\nHis trainer Joseph O'Brien said: \"He's in good form and has been coming along steadily. If he can improve another bit he should give a good account. The company\u2019s 50 day moving average price is $139.16 and its 200-day moving average price is $125.16. \n \nRockwell Automation (NYSE:ROK) last released its earnings results on Wednesday, January 25th. The company reported $1.75 EPS for the quarter, topping the Zacks\u2019 consensus estimate of $1.45 by $0.30. Rockwell Automation had a return on equity of 38.57% and a net margin of 12.77%. The firm earned $1.49 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $1.42 billion. During the same quarter in the previous year, the company posted $1.49 earnings per share. The company\u2019s revenue was up 4.5% compared to the same quarter last year. \n \nIn other news, Director Keith D. The Company operates through two segments: Architecture & Software and Control Products & Solutions. TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"67"}],"wordCount":"886","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396217381&p=2kx&v=1&x=6yAobjf4vz2ALSCT8cYoKA","id":"29396217381","content":"Recording gains on all four sessions - the market was closed on Thursday (January 26) for holiday for Republic Day - largely on expectations the finance minister will come out with a growth oriented budget, the key indices Sensex and the Nifty50 ended sharply higher last week (January 23 - 27, 2017). \n\nThe BSE benchmark Sensex ended up 847.96 points or 3.13% at 27,882.46 and the Nifty50 of the National Stock Exchange gained 291.90 points or 3.49% to 8641.25. On the final session of the week, the Sensex and the Nifty50 hit their best levels since 31 October 2016 and 1 November 2016, respectively. \n\nWith scores of midcap and smallcap stocks posting handsome gains, the BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices climbed 3.02% and 2.75%, respectively. \n\nDespite a fall from higher levels that resulted in a brief spell in negative territory around early afternoon, the market ended with modest gains on Monday, with select counters witnessing some strong buying in the final hour. The Sensex ended up 82.84 points, while the Nifty50 gained 42.15 points. \n\nAfter opening on a firm note and moving in a tight range till an hour past noon, the market rose smartly on some hectic buying at several counters and ended Tuesday's session with strong gains. Though global cues were not any encouraging and concerns about likely protectionist policies of the Donald Trump-led U.S. government persisted, stocks found their way up as traders rolled over positions ahead of January series derivatives expiry. \n\nAdditionally, expectations that the forthcoming Union Budget will contain some positive measures to boost economic growth aided sentiment. The Sensex ended up 258.24 points on that session and the Nifty50 gained 84.30 points. \n\nOn Wednesday, the The Indian stock market ended on a buoyant note, with traders indulging in some hectic buying at several counters right through the session on positive global cues and expectations from Union Budget 2017-18. Short-covering ahead of January series derivatives expiry and reports that the Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the U.S. President Donald Trump discussed opportunities to strengthen the partnership between the two countries in broad areas such as the economy and defense aided the rally. The Sensex and the Nifty50 gained 332.56 points and 126.95 points, respectively. \n\nHousing finance stock HDFC ended nearly 11% up last week and was way ahead of other gainers from the Sensex. \n\nFMCG major ITC ended nearly 1% up despite seeing a weak spell on Friday. ITC reported a net profit of Rs 2646.73 crore in the third quarter, as against a net profit of Rs 2503.76 it had recorded in the year-ago quarter. Total income from operations increased 4.69% to Rs 13,569.97 crore in the third quarter,up from Rs 12,961.85 crore in the corresponding quarter last year. \n\nITC's cigarette sales were up 2.2% at Rs 8288 crore in the September - December 2016 quarter, compared to year-ago quarter. Net sales of the top line of the company y 4.1% (Y-o-Y) to Rs 9149.30 crore for the quarter ended December 31, from Rs 8793 crore in the corresponding quarter of last fiscal. \n\nCapital goods sector major Larsen & Toubro gained 1.8%, with strong order book of the company triggering interest in the stock. \n\nIn the automobile space, Maruti Suzuki, Tata Motors,  Mahindra & Mahindra, Bajaj Auto and Hero MotoCorp gained 4% - 6%. Maruti Suzuki said its net profit rose 47.5% to Rs 1744.50 crore on 12.4% increase in net sales to Rs 16,623.60 crore in the December 2016 quarter, compared to December 2015 quarter. \n\nGAIL India ended nearly 5% up. The board of directors of the company approved issue of bonus shares in the ratio of 1:1. The board also approved issuance of secured/unsecured, redeemable, non-convertible, taxable bonds upto Rs 750 crore with green shoe option upto 100% of issue size aggregating upto Rs 1500 crore on a private placement basis, in one or more tranches. \n\nAmong IT majors, Tata Consultancy Services gained more than 3%. Infosys declined marginally and Wipro declined 2.3%. Wipro reported a 5.7% decline in consolidated net profit to Rs 2110 crore in the third quarter. Revenue was up 6.4%. \n\nAmong key bank stocks, ICICI Bank gained 3.3%, Axis Bank gained nearly 5%, State Bank of India ended 6.2% up and HDFC Bank strengthened by 4.7%. HDFC Bank's net profit increased 15.14% to Rs 3865.33 crore in the quarter ended December 2016, over the year-ago quarter, on 13.5% jump in total income. \n\nTelecom stock Bharti Airtel gained 0.9%. The company's consolidated net profit declined 54.54% to Rs 503.70 crore in the October - December 2016 quarter, compared to year-ago quarter. \n\nFMCG major Hindustan Unilever declined marginally. The company reported a modest 6.8% increase in third quarter net profit. \n\nCoal India surged up 4.3%, NTPC gained 3.75%, ONGC added 3.7% and Tata Steel gained 3.3%, while Adani Ports & Special Economic Zone spurted 6.7%. \n\nSuzlon Energy edged higher after the company said that it has bagged a 50.40 MW repeat order from  a leading power utility. Texmaco Rail & Engineering gained after the company announced that it has signed a non-binding MoU with a Chinese firm for promotion and development of transit elevated bus project in West Bengal. \n\nSona Koyo Steering ended with a hefty gain on reports Japanese firm JTEKT Corp is set to buy out Sona Group's 25% stake in the company. NLC India and Mphasis surged higher on share buy-back proposals. \n\nNOCIL, GIC Housing, Trent, Tata Communications, Heritage Foods, Orient Hotels, United Spirits, Gandhi Special Tubes, Automotive Stampings, Bharti Infratel and Chennai Petroleum Corporation saw some bright spells last week on impressive results. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-28T18:01:47Z","duplicateGroupId":"29382774385","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HOUSING AUTHORITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"GRANDCHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"CITY LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ECONOMIC CONDITIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"WATER RESOURCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WOMEN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"FOOD SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"WATER CRISES & SHORTAGES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"CITY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"SLUM DWELLINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LAW ENFORCEMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"POLICE FORCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ASBESTOS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"ZIMBABWE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"882","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396217699&p=2kx&v=1&x=_BLmNbK1_knKCs6Ep11SBw","id":"29396217699","content":"NGOZI MINE, BULAWAYO, ZIMBABWE - The city dump is home to people who illegally settle there, but those residents say they lack water and have to walk more than a kilometer to the nearest water source. \n\nThe Bulawayo City Council has at times provided water to the area, but people in the settlement say they haven't seen a city water tanker since 2014. \n\nSince then, residents say, they're unable to keep the area clean, making them vulnerable to diseases. \n\nWomen and girls carry 20-liter buckets of water on their heads after fetching it from a water tap at the local housing authority office about a kilometer away from the slum. Their bare feet are covered in mud and their faces drip with sweat as they head to the asbestos shacks they call home. The visibly exhausted women say each family's water haul is capped at 40 liters, regardless of the family's size - \n\na rule enforced by a local police officer. \n\nThokozile Sibanda, 54, has lived in Ngozi Mine for 13 years, since she became homeless. She says she wakes up as early as 4 a.m. to fetch water. By 8 a.m., the queue for water is long, and sometimes there's none left for latecomers. Sibanda's early morning trek is filled with fear, as she worries about being mugged on her way to the water source. \n\n\"I have stayed at this slum for a very long time, and I must admit life is very hard and miserable for me and my family,\" she says, holding back tears. \"The struggles I have faced in accessing water are not only numberless, but disheartening and strenuous.\" \n\nThokozile Sibanda, 54, rests after walking about 1 kilometer to fetch water. She says she wakes up as early as 4 a.m. to begin the trek to the public tap. \n\nLinda Chinobva, GPJ Zimbabwe \n\nThe scarcity of water in the slum has contributed to her two grandchildren's diarrhea, Sibanda says. \n\n\"As much as we want to keep our environment clean, we are limited by the unavailability of water because we have to conserve the little that we get, and in the process we are subjected to different illnesses that are left untreated,\" she says. \n\nFour hundred people live at Ngozi Mine, according to local estimates. Those people literally scrounge for food and other needs. Basic amenities don't reach the slums, most of which are illegal settlements, in the zones at the margins of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second-largest city. \n\nThe illegal settlement at Ngozi Mine is more than 15 years old, according to some residents. It cropped up as Zimbabwe's dire economic situation forced numerous people to move to the city's fringes and set up homes there, often due to a lack of job opportunities. Some residents were born there. \n\nHomes there are temporary structures built from corrugated zinc, asbestos and even plastics. They are susceptible to harsh weather conditions. \n\nResidents say they once fetched water from a nearby dam that was on private land, but in 2013 the owner of the farm on which that dam stood banned people from taking water, a measure meant to conserve the precious liquid for his farming activities. \n\nIn 2012, the city council introduced bowsers - \n\nwater tankers - \n\nwhich then became a clean water source for the slum dwellers. The bowser would deliver water at the slum once a week, and the slum dwellers were required to pay a $1 fee for 40 liters per family. The bowsers supplied the slum dwellers with clean water for two years, but in 2014 financial constraints ended that program. \n\nGideon Tshuma, an informal representative known as the resident chairman of the Ngozi Mine slum dwellers community, says water shortages are causing disharmony among the slum dwellers and neighboring communities, because Ngozi Mine residents take water from a stream in Cowdray Park, a nearby suburb, as an alternative to the city council tap. \n\nNgozi Mine residents acknowledge that they fetch stream water. Forty liters from the city tap isn't enough, says Patricia Ndiweni, a 15-year resident of Ngozi Mine. \n\n\"As a result, my family has resorted to fetching water from an unpurified stream,\" she says. \n\nThe stream gurgles with brown water. Empty bottles and plastic bags float on its surface, and a stench pervades the area. \n\nWard Councilor Collert Ndlovu, responsible for the slum area and neighboring suburbs, says he was not aware that the city council had stopped providing water to the slums. \n\n\"I am aware that there have been serious water issues at the slums. In the past, I have engaged the local authority to avail a tap for the slums so that they access clean water, and that is when the bowser was introduced,\" he says. \n\nBut he says he didn't know that the bowser had stopped delivering water. \n\n\"The challenge we have with the slums is that they are illegal settlers, so their plights are overlooked,\" he says. \n\nNdlovu says he plans to engage the council on the issue at its weekly meetings. \n\nStephan Sibanda has lived at the slum for five years. He says water scarcity is a challenge for him and his eight family members. \n\nThe 40 liters the family is allowed to take from the city tap have to stretch far enough so they can bathe, cook, drink and wash clothes. \n\n\"The water runs out before we accomplish all these,\" he says. \n\nLinda Chinobva, GPJ, translated some interviews from Ndebele.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Woman killed in fruit and veg truck crash","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Eastern Africa","countryCode":"ZW","country":"Zimbabwe"},"editorialRank":"5","name":"ZimbabweStar.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"608213529","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"ZimbabweStar.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","National","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://feeds.zimbabwestar.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204854377","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-28T18:01:47Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:32:29Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
