Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. \n    \n Qantas offers refunds to Australians affected by Trump's 'Muslim ban'  \n  exit   \nQantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. \n \nThe executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country. \n \nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely. \n \nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa. \n \nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government. \n \nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban. \n \n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said. \n \n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals. \n \n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\" \n \nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination. \n \n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said. \n \n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\" \n \nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. \n \nAn emergency stay issued by a US federal judge has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country. \n \nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. \n \nThe story Qantas offers refunds to Australians affected by Trump's 'Muslim ban' first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:10Z","duplicateGroupId":"29372898996","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[],"wordCount":"40","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221649&p=2kx&v=1&x=MwmhsFTxNEEnWdfcJrXzAA","id":"29396221649","content":"I got handcuffed and just started crying: Muslim student describes US detention \n\nRead the full Dubai News @ Source link \n Some local news is curated - Original might have been posted at a different date/ time! Click the source link for details.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Religion news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Muslim girl faces sexual assault after Trump's order","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Western Asia","countryCode":"AE","country":"United Arab Emirates"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Dubai Informer","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"544440807","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Dubai Informer","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://dubaiinformer.com/"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://khaleejtimes.com/international/americas/muslim-girl-faces-sexual-assault-after-donald-trumps-order"],"sequenceId":"695204945451","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:10Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:11Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396221753","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EVICTION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LAWYERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RENTAL PROPERTY","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"COUNTY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DECISIONS & RULINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LANDLORD & TENANT LAW","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SUITS & CLAIMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"JUDGES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LITIGATION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"REAL PROPERTY LAW","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CIVIL PROCEDURE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PROPERTY MANAGEMENT","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"1693","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221753&p=2kx&v=1&x=DbTak7fnOKUsTsxh69390w","id":"29396221753","content":"Everyone in Courtroom A on Wednesday was there for the same reason: an eviction notice. \n \nOne tenant was there because he was between jobs and couldn\u2019t pay rent on time. Another said her housemate didn\u2019t pay her half of the rent. A third tenant purposely withheld her rent because parts of her roof had caved in and the landlord didn\u2019t make repairs. \n \nAll three \u2014 and more than a dozen others \u2014 received eviction notices, the common thread that brought them to the Deschutes County Circuit Court, along with landlords, property managers and attorneys. \n \n\u201cWe\u2019ve got a really big docket today,\u201d Justine Kenyon-Benson, a court supervisor, told the group. \n \nThe week before, on Jan. 17, 16 landlord-tenant suits were filed with the court \u2014 more than any day in 2016. \n \nCourt documents show that a majority of the tenants were accused of nonpayment of rent. \n \nAccording to court records, more than 323 landlord-tenant civil suits have been filed since Jan. 1, 2016. Since 2011, there have been more than 500 of those suits, and more than 3,500 eviction cases. \n \nThose are just the cases that make it to court. There\u2019s no way to keep track of the evictions that renters comply with because those never make it on a courthouse calendar. \n \nAlmost all of the renters in the courtroom on Wednesday admitted that they didn\u2019t pay on time. In most of these cases, the law was on the landlord\u2019s side. \n \nBut even when it isn\u2019t, tenants often don\u2019t know. \n \n\u201cLandlords and management companies typically know the system better, and they have better access to financial resources,\u201d said Mark Peterson, a retired Portland attorney who specializes in landlord-tenant law and has been involved in cases all over the state. \u201cTenants don\u2019t realize that they may be able to get a lawyer, and a powerful adversary can steamroll you. I\u2019ve seen tenants settle on terms that were terribly unfortunate for them.\u201d \n \nThere were two options, Kenyon-Benson explained to everyone who showed up to court: mediation or trial. For the three or four tenants who weren\u2019t present, an automatic judgment was filed in favor of the plaintiff. \n \nMediation is an option the Deschutes County Circuit Court offers landlords and tenants in these kinds of disputes. Instead of going straight into court, a court-provided volunteer mediator gives the parties a chance to come to an agreement without a court ruling. \n \n\u201cThe relationship between the parties in these cases is usually one where there\u2019s not a lot of trust,\u201d Peterson said. \u201cThe mediator can help the two to speak. In most cases if the parties can settle then they can have a better shared result. A mediator can help people get past personal hurts.\u201d \n \nLetting a judge decide comes with risks. If a judge rules in a landlord\u2019s favor, an eviction will go on the tenant\u2019s record. And in a rental market like the one in Central Oregon, with a vacancy rate hovering around 1 percent or less, an eviction can be devastating for a renter. Also, in an eviction case, a judge doesn\u2019t make a ruling on rent owed \u2014 only who has a right to the property. A landlord typically won\u2019t be able to recover any money lost from the verdict. \n \n\u201cTrained mediators can save a lot of people from going to trial, where there\u2019s typically a loser and a winner or sometimes just two losers,\u201d Peterson said. \n \nAccording to statistics kept by Deschutes County Circuit Court, 23 mediators volunteered 493.5 hours during the 2015-2016 state fiscal year. \n \nOn Wednesday in Courtroom A, everyone agreed to mediation. \n \nMediation works out differently for different people, depending on their situation. \n \nFor Brad Johnson, a 20-year-old who was between jobs and couldn\u2019t pay his December rent, it allowed him to stay in his apartment, which is managed by local property management company PLUS Property. But there was a cost. \n \n\u201cI didn\u2019t want to have to go to trial because I knew there would be fees, and we both knew I was going to pay the rent, it was simply a matter of us getting it extended,\u201d he said. \u201cMe and (PLUS Property) knew what we were there for.\u201d \n \nJohnson said he had called PLUS Property when he knew he wasn\u2019t going to be able to pay on time and it agreed to let him pay late, with a $75 charge. But when he received an eviction notice the day after rent was due, he called again. \n \n\u201cThey were like \u2018Oh, you just have to go to court on the court date and we can extend it,\u2019\u201d he said. \u201cThey didn\u2019t tell me service fees were going to be there.\u201d \n \nThe deal that came out of Johnson\u2019s mediation with PLUS Property allowed him to continue living in his apartment under his 12-month lease as long as he paid the $1,050 in rent he owed, plus fees. These included $79.99 for the court filing fees associated with the eviction notice, $40 to cover the cost of the time for a PLUS Property representative to be in court, and a $75 charge for the late rent. \n \nLawnae Hunter, who owns PLUS Property, said that her company sends eviction notices \u2014 even in instances that a prior agreement is reached, like in Johnson\u2019s case \u2014 so that the court can be involved with the agreement. She said that if a tenant doesn\u2019t have a history of paying rent late, or is facing an unusual set of circumstances, such as losing a job, her company usually tries to work out a payment plan instead of evicting. \n \n\u201cThe court system is such that you have to get into mediation with a written agreement,\u201d she said, adding that her company always chooses to mediate. \u201cSo we start with an eviction notice. You have to get it into the system, in case (tenants) don\u2019t do what was agreed.\u201d \n \nAs for the fees, Hunter said they\u2019re necessary because her company is representing a property owner that has costs and is paying to file in court. \n \n\u201cWe bill hourly rates, and it costs me more than $40 an hour to send someone over there,\u201d she said. \u201cWe keep that fee low.\u201d \n \nJaquita Harrison, 22, is a tenant with a different story. Harrison lives at Mountain Glen Townhomes with her 3-year-old daughter and a housemate. But when the housemate, who works in childcare, couldn\u2019t pay rent, Harrison said she didn\u2019t have enough to cover the gap. \n \nAfter mediation, Harrison agreed to move out by Friday. \n \n\u201cI went in and basically discussed what\u2019s going to happen,\u201d she said. \u201cThe property manager basically said they want the property back because I\u2019m always late on rent. But I\u2019m always late because I get paid on the 10th and the 25th. I could\u2019ve paid the rent right there in court, and she told me no. I\u2019m a single mom. I have other bills. I can\u2019t pay it on the 1st or the 5th.\u201d \n \nThe mediation agreement that Harrison and Mountain Glen Townhomes signed gave Harrison 10 days to move out. She had asked for 30. \n \n\u201cI don\u2019t know where me and my daughter are going to go,\u201d Harrison said. \u201cI can\u2019t be homeless with her because it\u2019ll get her taken away from me \u2014 it\u2019s cold as hell outside. I work full time and she goes to school. I hardly get to see her as it is.\u201d \n \nA representative of Mountain Glen didn\u2019t return calls for comment. \n \nMichela Estrada\u2019s story is different as well. The only tenant who came to court with a lawyer on Wednesday, Estrada came away from mediation with an arguably better deal. \n \nThe reason Estrada had come to court in the first place was because of the weather. In December, one of the snowstorms caused parts of her roof to collapse. \n \nShe contacted PLUS Property Management, which manages the house she rents, to discuss the damage, but repairs were slow in coming. \n \nHunter, the owner of PLUS Property, said that she\u2019s not surprised about that delay. \n \n\u201cWe had a hard, hard time getting roofers throughout the big storm,\u201d she said. \u201cI couldn\u2019t get a roofer at my own house when my garage ceiling is caved in. There was a waiting list.\u201d \n \nEstrada withheld her January rent because of the lack of repairs, and PLUS Property sent her an eviction notice. \n \n\u201cYour average landlord is a typical property owner \u2014 one or two rentals \u2014 and they don\u2019t have a large budget for massive leaks and snowstorms,\u201d said Joseph Harder, the attorney who represented Estrada. \u201cThey should always plan for it \u2014 they own these properties as an income-generating source, right? Snowstorm hits, roof caves in, no budget, and landlords are in a tough spot. They want to wait for the insurance to pay for it, but the bad thing is they have a tenant in there, and that\u2019s their home. So it needs to be taken care of quickly. It\u2019s hard for both.\u201d \n \nEstrada\u2019s court date arrived after living for a few weeks in a home with caved-in ceilings and a damaged interior, and also racking up a large utility bill because of increased heating costs. \n \nWhile most of the mediations that took place that day lasted an hour or so, the negotiation that took place between Harder and PLUS Property stretched on for about four hours. Harder said the deal that was ultimately negotiated was certainly preferable to Estrada having to move out, or being allowed to stay but having to pay a full month\u2019s rent for a caved-in roof. \n \n\u201cWe ended up negotiating it,\u201d Harder said, adding that Estrada had agreed to pay half of the rent she owed by Friday. \u201c(Estrada) wanted out, so we negotiated a way out of the lease, and now it\u2019s month to month. The landlord is paying for a portion of the cost increases because of the extra heating, and they agreed to waive a portion of rent and get on the repairs immediately. Probably a pretty good resolution for everybody.\u201d \n \nHunter agrees, adding that Estrada most likely didn\u2019t need a lawyer to come to that agreement. \n \n\u201cMediation is available to everybody,\u201d she said, noting she wasn\u2019t familiar with the specifics of Estrada\u2019s situation. \u201c(Estrada) didn\u2019t need a lawyer, she would have ended up with the same result. Our response would have been the same even if she didn\u2019t have a lawyer.\u201d \n \n\u2014 Reporter: 541-617-7829, \n \nawest@bendbulletin.com","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"A day in court: Landlords and tenants negotiate before eviction","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Jackson","zipCode":"97502","state":"Oregon","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Central Point","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bend Bulletin","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668815","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2479"},"name":"Bend Bulletin","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bendbulletin.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204946599","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:11Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. Qantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. The executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country.\n\nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely.\n\nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa.\n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government.\n\nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said.\n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals.\n\n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\"\n\nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination.\n\n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said.\n\n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\"\n\nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. An has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country.\n\nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. For us it's an important time for our Prime Minister to show political leadership in this area.\"\n\nMany people he had spoken to that morning were feeling a sense of loss, he said. She won 64 grand slam titles in total, including doubles and mixed doubles. \n \n\"I think she will break the record, and I think she will break it soon,\" Court said. \n \n\"It's so much easier for players today to do what they do. She hadn't played for about three months before coming here, and it easier to do these things. \n \n\"But she's playing very well, and records are made to be broken. \n \n\"People keep asking me, 'How do you feel about your record?' but I'm not going to lose any sleep over something like that. \n \n\"My life is very busy and full, and they'll never get my 64 so it's all right. I'll always have that.\" \n \nCourt, who played from 1959 to 1975, watched Williams beat her sister Venus 6-4, 6-4 in the final and was again struck by the resources, support and equipment that players have access to. \n \n\"There was television in the early '60s but no sponsorship and money, none of that. Even the racquets they get to use today are so beautiful compared to what we used to have,\" she said. \n \n\"The facilities are so much better, they have massage people, they can bring psychologists with them as well as their trainers and coaches and whoever else they want to come along. \n \n\"It's a whole different era, so it's very hard to compare. I think back to our Aussie era where we had some of the greatest champions in the world and think, how did we ever do that?\" \n \nCourt has not had the chance to talk extensively with Williams, chatting to her briefly during a presentation at the 2016 Hopman Cup. \n \n\"It's like Fort Knox with the players today. They're so isolated and they're hard to talk to. It's not like when we played where everyone was like brother and sister, it's totally different. \n \n\"I thought it was a very interesting match that she played. I knew she was going to win but there was a lot of hitting up and down the court. \n \n\"We had so much more of an all-round game with the volleying. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:08Z","duplicateGroupId":"29382071302","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LAYOFFS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"OUTPUT & DEMAND","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"CALL CENTERS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CUSTOMER SERVICE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"LIFE INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BUSINESS TELEPHONE SERVICE","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"WAGES & SALARIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CIVIL SERVICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"US STATE GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PUBLIC CONTRACTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"HEALTH INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"LOBBYING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"WORKFORCE DEMAND","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SALEM, OR, USA; UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"KATE BROWN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1290","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221451&p=2kx&v=1&x=mXoTGByPSeMoiCLZWoehQg","id":"29396221451","content":"A Baker City couple who employ 54 people at a call center under a state contract are lobbying Gov. Kate Brown to have the state renew their contract to avoid the loss of those jobs next week, but a state official said there are no plans to continue the deal. \n \nRichard and Kathleen Chaves, who own Chaves Consulting Inc., are nearing the end of the first year under contract with the Oregon Health Authority. \n \nTheir employees, whose starting wage is $12 per hour and who have a benefits package including health, dental, vision and life insurance, take customer service calls for that agency, related to the Oregon Health Plan. \n \nThe $2.5 million contract was guaranteed for one year, and included five optional one-year renewals, Richard Chaves said. \n \nHe said last week that he has had no notification from the OHA that the agency intends to renew the contract for another year. The deal expires Tuesday. \n \nChris Pair, a spokesman in Brown\u2019s office, referred questions to OHA. \n \nMichelle McClellan, senior communications manager with OHA, wrote in an email: \u201cWe appreciate the job the Chaves team did fulfilling the temporary need for additional OHP (Oregon Health Plan) call center capacity, as we navigated the impact of a surge in enrollment and the adoption of a new online tool for OHP applicants and members that will streamline renewal processing, reduce call volume and lessen the need for call center assistance in the future.\u201d \n \nMcClellan said OHA signed contracts with Chaves Consulting and with another private firm that runs a call center in Salem to handle what agency officials expected would be a temporary increase in demand for call center workers. \n \nThe contract with the Salem company ends in March, and it is not scheduled to be extended. \n \n\u201cLike any private or public organization, we rely on partners like Chaves Consulting to provide support when we have temporary or unexpected demands,\u201d McClellan said in the email. \n \n\u201cChaves stepped up for us during a time when we had nearly 1.1 million OHP members and faced significant short-term demands. However, the improvements we\u2019ve made to automate and streamline the OHP application experience will make it simpler and easier for OHP members to manage their benefits \u2014 and reduce their need for phone support.\u201d \n \nChaves said OHA\u2019s position baffles him because his employees meet or exceed the state\u2019s performance standards at a cost to OHA that\u2019s roughly half what the agency pays to state employees who work at a call center in Salem; this center is run by the state, not by the private company whose contract expires in March. \n \nChaves said the state pays his company $50,900 per year for each call center employee. The state\u2019s current cost for salary and benefits is $73,500 per year for each call center worker, and that amount is slated to increase July 1 to $78,800. If other operating expenses for the state call center are factored in, the cost per worker for state employees is more than double the cost in the Chaveses\u2019 contract, he said. \n \nHe said the company did not request any increase were the state to renew the contract. \n \nChaves said he and his wife told their employees recently that the future of the contract, and of their jobs, is uncertain. \n \nIn a letter she sent this month to Brown, Kathleen Chaves wrote that \u201cour people will be devastated to lose their jobs.\u201d \n \n\u201cOur incredibly positive, dedicated people have come to work every day to demonstrate to OHA that they are deserving of their jobs and the results they\u2019ve achieved have proven that they are,\u201d Chaves wrote. \u201cThis is an opportunity for an Oregon governor to demonstrate that they are truly committed to employ deserving rural Oregon citizens who have proven their worth to the state.\u201d \n \nRichard Chaves said he and his wife have been asking OHA officials since August about renewing the contract. \n \nAlthough McClellan cited a declining need for call center workers as the reason OHA is not extending the Chaves contract, another OHA employee, in a recent email to Richard Chaves, focused instead on the state\u2019s budget shortfall, which is estimated at $1.8 billion for the two-year cycle that starts July 1. \n \nIn a Jan. 5, 2017, email to Richard Chaves, OHA employee Wesley Charley wrote: \u201cUnfortunately, after conversations with our budget team, we are not able to locate the additional money to extend the (Chaves Consulting) contract through March. As you are aware there are significant budgetary issues for Oregon as we close out this biennium and even more significant as we move into the next. I wish I was delivering better news. The work your team has been doing is great.\u201d \n \nCharley was referring to a two-month extension of the contract, however, not the full year the Chaveses had hoped for. \n \nDespite the OHA claims about budget shortfalls, the Chaveses learned, from information that Oregon Rep. Cliff Bentz, R-Ontario, obtained, that OHA is seeking authority to hire 179 new state employees when the new biennium starts July 1, and that some of those workers would be assigned to the state-owned call center in Salem. \n \nMcClellan confirmed that\u2019s the case. \n \nBrown\u2019s proposed budget for the next biennium includes money to hire 179 permanent employees for OHA, 77 of them call center workers. \n \nRichard Chaves said OHA\u2019s plan to hire new state call center workers in Salem, while deciding not to renew contracts with private firms in a rural county such as Baker, makes parts of Brown\u2019s inaugural speech earlier this month ring hollow. \n \nBrown spoke about the struggling economies in rural Oregon, saying, \u201cFor rural communities such as John Day or Powell Butte, as Republican leaders Ted Ferrioli and Mike McLane know so well, there is a disturbing gap between the unemployment rate in urban Oregon and rural Oregon. For families living in Columbia, Coos, Crook, or any of our rural counties, we must bust open the doors of opportunity so that individuals can find good-paying jobs right where they live.\u201d \n \nFerrioli, who like Bentz represents Baker County in the Legislature, said OHA\u2019s apparent intention to in effect replace Chaves Consulting\u2019s 54 employees, some of whom live in Union County, with more expensive state workers not only defies claims that the state is in dire financial straits, but it also seems antithetical to Brown\u2019s statements about the importance of rural jobs. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s a conflict with the governor\u2019s rhetoric,\u201d Ferrioli said. \u201cIt looks to me like you\u2019re moving jobs out of the private sector in rural Oregon and into the public sector. From a rural economic development standpoint it\u2019s a terrible decision. There\u2019s no reason to see these jobs go away.\u201d \n \nFerrioli said he had scheduled meetings with OHA officials and with the governor that were canceled earlier this month due to wintry weather. \n \nHe plans to reschedule those meetings, at which he will urge the state officials to renew the OHA contract with Chaves Consulting. \n \nIn the meantime, the Chaveses are just days away from having to lay off most of the workers they hired a year ago. \n \nRichard Chaves\u2019 eyes tear up and his voice hesitates when he describes the thank-you card he received Monday from those employees. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s as if they\u2019re thanking us for laying them off,\u201d he said. \n \nHe said he can\u2019t help but replay Brown\u2019s statement about people finding \u201cgood-paying jobs right where they live.\u201d \n \nChaves said that\u2019s precisely what he and his wife sought and accomplished when they secured the OHA call center contract. \n \nHe said the local residents they hired, a few of whom were living in their cars, have exceeded their expectations. \n \n\u201cI have never heard an OHA person say that our performance is anything but stellar,\u201d Chaves said. \u201cThe people that are working for us really want their jobs and they take a lot of pride in their positions, so they excel.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Portland news","group":"US regional"},{"name":"Job markets news","group":"Business"}],"title":"End of call center contract in Baker stark choice in Sunday's presidential primary between diehard leftist Benoit Hamon and reformist ex-prime minister Manuel Valls. \n \nHamon, the surprise winner of the first round of the Socialists' primary last weekend, has wooed voters with his staunchly leftist proposals, notably the idea of a universal basic income, dismissed as a \"mirage\" by Valls. \n \nHe also wants to legalise marijuana and tax robots that replace workers. \n \nThe 49-year-old Hamon, round-faced with a schoolboy haircut, has a crowd-pleasing eagerness that contrasts with the square-jawed assertiveness of Valls, 54, who was interior minister before becoming premier. \n \nHamon joined a rebellion against what he saw as the Socialist government's rightward drift under Valls and President Francois Hollande, quitting as education minister in 2014. \n \nThe combative Valls has dismissed him as a dreamer with no hope of becoming president in May. \n \nSocialist voters face a choice between \"certain defeat\" with Hamon as their nominee and \"possible victory\" if they chose him, Valls declared confidently after the first round. \n \nYet polls show neither man making it past the first round in the presidential vote in April, with conservative ex-premier Francois Fillon, far-right leader Marine Le Pen and centrist ex-economy minister Emmanuel Macron leading the field. \n \nAfter two-and-a-half years as premier Valls believes he is the best-placed to defend France's interests in the face of a new protectionist world order. \n \nHe has been particularly scathing of his rival's signature proposal for a universal basic income. \n \n\"I want nothing of these mirages that evaporate in an instant and that sow disillusionment (and) bitterness,\" he told an earlier campaign rally. \n \nValls' parents, a Spanish painter father and Swiss-Italian mother, fled the dictatorship of Francisco Franco in Spain to settle in France, though they travelled back to Barcelona for his birth in August 1962. He gained French citizenship when he was 20. \n \nHe has four children from his first marriage to a teacher. In 2010 he remarried, to concert violinist Anne Gravoin. \n \nValls makes no apologies for his pro-business stance and desire to modernise the Socialist party. \n \nBut his use of decrees to ram through contested economic reforms as prime minister, as well as a failed proposal to strip dual-national terrorists of their French citizenship, alienated many in the party. \n \nHamon, who hails from western Brittany, is the son of a dockworker father and secretary mother. \n \nHe began his political life as a student activist in the 1980s. \n \nIn 1986, aged 18, he joined massive student protests against proposed reforms which then rightwing president Jacques Chirac was forced to withdraw. \n \nA father of two with his partner Gabrielle Guallar, Hamon has a degree in history. \n \nBroken china \n \nValls has warned \"the left could die\" unless two \"irreconcilable\" factions -- one pragmatic and open to reforms, the other wedded to the class struggle -- unite. \n \nSuch statements have drawn comparisons to former British prime minister Tony Blair who dragged his Labour party towards the centre and won three successive elections. \n \nBut in recent years leftist voters across Europe have soured on the centre-left, preferring hard left leaders like Labour's Jeremy Corbyn in Britain or far-left parties like Spain's Podemos. \n \nValls is not the only one making dire warnings of a lasting rift within the party that swept the board in general elections just five years ago. \n \n\"The PS (Socialist Party) elephants have already broken everything in the china Sascha because at 19 he has a game, as he showed in losing to Rafa, that will take him to tennis' peak. And Mischa because he played a game against Andy Murray that made many wonder if serve volley was back. \n \nIn Melbourne the courts and balls were faster. So Ivo Karlovic set a new Australian Open record for most aces in a match (75 against Horacio Zabellas). Games were taking less time than Rafa takes picking at his undies. \n \nTHE EFFING COMEBACK \n \nEff me if she didn't effing make the effing semis. FFS. Lucic-Baroni delivered the most candid on court post-match interview making her first quarter final in 20 years. \n \nAsked how she persisted for so long against so many obstacles she replied: \"Eff everything and everybody whoever tells you you can't do it. Just show up and win in your heart.\" \n \nShe then won her next match and this time tearfully hinted more at the back story for why the woman dubbed 'The next Steffi Graf' had not realised that potential for 20 years. \n \nTWEET TWEET \n \nRoger does everything the best, even tweets. Federer tweeted a video of his new boy band \u2013 him, Gregor Dimitrov and Tommy Haas \u2013 singing \"Hard to say I'm Sorry\". \n \nALL ADVICE WELCOME, NOT HEEDED \n \nIf losing after imploding on the court wasn't enough Mark Philippoussis giving career advice on how to right his career has to be Nick Kyrgios' penny drop moment. \n \nHis meltdown loss to Andreas Seppi came after being up two sets to one and a break. Big in central Europe but not so pleasing to tennis fans it seems. \n \nTHE INTERNATIONAL LANGUAGE OF \"WHAT ARE YOU LOOKIN AT?\" \n \nThings got testy on court between bustling Jo Wilfried Tsonga and Stan Wawrinka who is ordinarily as deadpan as a fondue bowl. \n \nTsonga muttered about Wawrinka giving him greasy looks. \n \n\"I looked at you when? Did I look at you at all? It's a tennis match. You've got to calm down, relax a bit.\" Wawrinka protested quite reasonably. \n \n\"There's no worries,\" Tsonga said. But plainly there is. \n \nThe pair both live in Switzerland and had been close but things went awry a few years ago after Stan's first slam when Tsonga was quoted in L'Equipe saying \"If Stan can win a slam, then I deserve one too\". \n \nADIEU \n \nAnd with that we bid adieu to Australian Open 2017.
