{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:09Z","duplicateGroupId":"29394067706","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"WRESTLING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"OLYMPIC COMMITTEES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BOYCOTTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"STADIUMS & ARENAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SUMMER OLYMPICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ATHLETES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SPORTS GOVERNING BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"FUNDRAISING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"SPORTS & RECREATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"OLYMPICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EXECUTIVE ORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"AGENCY RULEMAKING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CHINA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"99"},{"name":"IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"LOS ANGELES, CA, USA; UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"1272","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221549&p=2kx&v=1&x=9orrQgniffiTNKaAIHJxLg","id":"29396221549","content":"President Donald Trump\u2019s ban on visitors from seven Muslim nations could have a wide impact on international sports, including jeopardizing a warm relationship between the United States and Iran in wrestling competitions and threatening the chances of Los Angeles hosting the 2024 Summer Olympics and of the United States securing soccer\u2019s 2026 World Cup. \n \nOn Saturday, sports officials struggled to understand the implications of Trump\u2019s executive order, including the question of whether athletes from the prohibited nations could enter the United States to compete, especially in the initial 90-day period of the ban. \n \n\u201cWe are working closely with the administration to understand the new rules and how we best navigate them as it pertains to visiting athletes,\u201d Patrick Sandusky, a spokesman for the U.S. Olympic Committee, said in an email. \u201cWe know they are supportive of the Olympic movement and our bid, and believe we will have a good working relationship with them to ensure our success in hosting and attending events.\u201d \n \nThe most immediate effect may come in wrestling, given that one of the nations affected by Trump\u2019s ban is Iran, which has long had a congenial relationship with the United States in that sport. Iran said Saturday that it would stop U.S. citizens from entering the country, in retaliation for Trump\u2019s order. \n \nThe U.S. freestyle wrestling team is scheduled to participate in a World Cup competition in Iran on Feb. 8. Steve Fraser, the chief fundraiser for USA Wrestling and a 1984 Greco-Roman Olympic champion, said Saturday that the president of Iran\u2019s wrestling federation was scheduled to meet this weekend with government officials there in an attempt to make sure the Americans would still be invited to the meet. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s some nervousness by us that the Iranian government might say, \u2018We can\u2019t get visas to go there, so no Americans can come here, either,\u2019\u201d Fraser said. \n \nWhile Olympic boycotts have resulted from tense political differences between nations, opposing countries have also long found common ground on playing fields, on the track and in sports arenas. One of the most celebrated examples is the \u201cPing-Pong diplomacy\u201d that helped open the relationship between the United States and China in the 1970s. \n \nIn wrestling, the United States, Iran, Cuba and Russia banded together in 2013 to persuade the IOC to keep the sport in the Summer Games. American wrestlers and officials are warmly welcomed in Iran, and Iranian wrestlers compete regularly in the United States. They may be invited to meets in May in New York and in June in Los Angeles, Fraser said. There is uncertainty now, however, about whether they would be granted P1 visas, commonly known as sports visas, to compete. \n \nChristina Kelley, chief international ambassador for USA Wrestling who in 2014 became one of the few women allowed into a wrestling arena in Iran since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, said Saturday that she was frustrated by Trump\u2019s decision. \n \n\u201cI don\u2019t think our current president has any clue what the State Department and what sports diplomats and cultural exchanges do for our country and for the safety of our people around the world,\u201d Kelley said. \n \nThe ban on visitors from Iran, Iraq, Syria, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen comes at a delicate time for the U.S. Olympic Committee. Los Angeles is seeking to host the 2024 Summer Games, and it will learn in September whether it, Paris or Budapest will get the games. \n \nDavid Wallechinsky, an American member of the IOC\u2019s cultural and heritage commission and president of the International Society of Olympic Historians, said the election of Trump in November hurt Los Angeles\u2019s bid with IOC delegates because Trump is perceived as being \u201canti-Muslin, anti-woman and anti-Latino.\u201d \n \n\u201cThis is worse,\u201d Wallechinsky said of the Muslim ban, adding that \u201cI would consider it a blow to the Los Angeles bid, not fatal, but a blow.\u201d \n \nAt a meeting at the Lausanne, Switzerland, headquarters of the IOC several days after the U.S. presidential election, Wallechinsky said he was asked repeatedly, \u201cWhat is wrong with your country?\u201d \n \nHe said he sought to assure IOC officials by explaining that three-quarters of the voters in Los Angeles voted against Trump, describing the city to them as a \u201ca multicultural, Trump-free zone.\u201d \n \nThe United States is expected to bid to host the world\u2019s other major sporting event, the World Cup, in 2026. In June, Sunil Gulati, president of the U.S. Soccer Federation, told reporters that a Trump presidency could complicate a U.S. bid, especially if it were a joint bid with Mexico, given Trump\u2019s plans to build a wall across American\u2019s southern border. \n \n\u201cI think a co-hosted World Cup with Mexico would be trickier if Secretary Clinton isn\u2019t in the White House,\u201d Gulati said at the time, in a reference to Hillary Clinton, who lost the election to Trump. \n \nAfter Trump won the election, Gulati modified his remarks, saying, \u201cIt\u2019s not going to dissuade us or persuade us to bid.\u201d International perceptions of the Trump administration \u201cmatter, for sure,\u201d Gulati said, \u201cbut I think those will be developed in the months to come.\u201d \n \nGulati and U.S. Soccer, reached by telephone, declined to comment Saturday. \n \nMany questions remained unanswered about the ability to travel for a number of athletes. Two NBA players, Thon Maker and Luol Deng, were born in Sudan, one of the seven countries listed in Trump\u2019s executive order. \n \nMaker\u2019s family fled his home country when he was 5 and eventually settled in Australia. Maker, who plays for the Milwaukee Bucks, moved to the United States to play high school basketball in Louisiana, eventually moved to Canada, and is an Australian citizen who holds a passport from that country. \n \nDeng, a forward for the Los Angeles Lakers, has lived in the United States for 17 years. His family fled to Egypt when he was 5 to escape the Sudanese civil war. Deng came to the United States when he was 14 and attended high school in New Jersey. \n \nThe NBA also holds an annual Basketball Without Borders camp, and it is expected to be held in New Orleans during All-Star Weekend in February. While rosters have not been released, last year\u2019s camp involved players from 25 countries, including Amir Reza Shah-Ravesh from Iran. \n \nMajor League Soccer has two U.S.-born players with familial ties to two of the nations facing bans: Steve Beitashour of Toronto has played for Iran\u2019s national team, and Justin Meram of Columbus has played for Iraq. League officials were looking into the matter Saturday. \n \nMo Farah of Britain, who was born in Somalia and has won four Olympic gold medals on the track at 5,000 meters and 10,000 meters, is a Nike-sponsored athlete coached by Alberto Salazar. It remains unclear whether Farah would be allowed into the United States to train or compete. Salazar did not immediately respond to an email Saturday. Farah is in Ethiopia training for an event in Britain. He lives in the Portland area. \n \n\u201cWe clearly need to understand the implications of this new U.S. immigration policy and will be seeking assurances that it will not adversely affect\u201d track and field\u2019s world championships, scheduled to be held in Eugene in 2021, said Jackie Brock-Doyle, a spokeswoman for the sport\u2019s world governing body, the International Association of Athletics Federations. \n \nPhil Andrews, chief executive of USA Weightlifting, said officials were trying to figure out the impact of Trump\u2019s ban on the world weightlifting championships, scheduled for November in Anaheim, California, and on the U.S. team\u2019s participation at a competition in Iran. \n \n\u201cOur view is that politics and sport should be separate,\u201d Andrews said, stressing sports diplomacy among nations. \u201cWe sincerely hope to peacefully welcome these seven nations to Anaheim this November. It is unimaginable to be able to host a true world event without their participation.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Iran news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"How will Trump\u2019s ban affect sports? Nobody knows","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Jackson","zipCode":"97502","state":"Oregon","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Central Point","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bend Bulletin","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668815","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2479"},"name":"Bend Bulletin","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bendbulletin.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204956083","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:09Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:09Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396221550","companies":[{"symbol":"3962","primary":true,"name":"CHANGE Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3507750002"},{"symbol":"7646","primary":true,"name":"PLANT Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3895000002"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"SEWERAGE SYSTEMS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CIVIL ENGINEERING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"SUITS & CLAIMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"CITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"WATER & SEWER SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LITIGATION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"CITY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"NEW MANUFACTURING FACILITIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CONSTRUCTION","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ENGINEERING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BEND, OR, USA; UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; WASHINGTON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"77"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; COLORADO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"57"}],"wordCount":"1719","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221550&p=2kx&v=1&x=VS3LpBBQAkllX0PXZoOtcA","id":"29396221550","content":"City being sued for what construction company calls \u2018extraordinary\u2019 number of design errors \n   \nBudgeting issues, design flaws and construction defects were among a number of challenges the city of Bend dealt with while expanding its sewer treatment plant. \n \nNext month, the city will be responsible for defending how it dealt with those problems in court after the construction company hired to expand the plant sued the city for $8 million. \n \nAccording to the lawsuit, Kennewick, Washington-based Apollo Inc. experienced added costs and delays due to an \u201cextraordinary\u201d number of design errors by the project\u2019s engineer and construction manager, Colorado-based CH2M Hill. Apollo alleges that the city\u2019s design and contract documents were \u201cdefective and deficient,\u201d and is suing Bend for $8 million for unpaid work and damages. \n \nHowever, the city of Bend says the added costs and delays were instead due to Apollo\u2019s poor management and failure to follow the contract \u2014 not issues with CH2M Hill, which has not been brought into the lawsuit. The city also says Apollo\u2019s allegations about damages are \u201clegally insufficient,\u201d and that the company is only owed about $4 million in unpaid work. \n \nTo date, the project has cost city taxpayers about $24 million on construction, $10.8 million for engineering and construction management and $2.7 million in consultants and attorneys \u2014 but has yet to be finished. \n \nThe city blames Apollo for the problems, but the lawsuit could still come with a hefty price tag for Bend taxpayers. They\u2019ll be on the hook to pay for going to court, as well as hiring a new contractor to finish the sewer plant. The outcome of the lawsuit will determine who will take the blame for the problems \u2014 Apollo, CH2M Hill or the city of Bend. \n \nHowever, an examination of city email records obtained by The Bulletin reveals a slew of problems beyond Apollo\u2019s construction troubles. Email records show issues including CH2M Hill working beyond its budget and challenges bringing contract increases to city councilors. In addition, two top city public works officials were longtime employees of CH2M Hill. \n \nMeanwhile, city officials say CH2M Hill\u2019s construction management costs were much higher than anticipated, which in part led the project to go over budget. They also say a poor working relationship between CH2M Hill and Apollo led to further problems including the project running more than a year behind schedule. \n \nHowever, city records show the sewer treatment plant isn\u2019t the first CH2M Hill project that\u2019s experienced problems. The sewer treatment plant contract is only one of 20 contracts the city of Bend has awarded CH2M Hill over the past decade, which total nearly $22 million, according documents The Bulletin obtained from the city. \n \nIn 2010, the city swallowed a $106,000 mistake when CH2M Hill\u2019s designs for a manhole were off by a couple of feet during the city\u2019s southeast interceptor sewer project. Jim Wodrich, a city engineer who previously worked as a planner for CH2M Hill, was involved in negotiating with the firm to determine if the company was liable for the $106,000 manhole mistake. \n \nSewer plant problems \n \nIn 2009, the city of Bend hired CH2M Hill for about $200,000 to start preliminary designs for the sewer plant expansion. That contract was extended several times to pay CH2M Hill to finish engineering work, which totaled about $5.5 million. \n \nEventually, CH2M Hill was hired to work as the project\u2019s construction manager. Today, the contract\u2019s total value is $10.8 million. \n \nBudgeting problems with the project began to surface in 2011, when Bend City Manager Eric King said an accounting software error caused CH2M Hill\u2019s cost for design work to jump from $2 million to about $4 million . \n \nAfter CH2M Hill\u2019s initial design work was finished, the city decided to extend CH2M Hill\u2019s contract, and hire the firm as the project\u2019s construction manager for an additional $4.5 million. That brought CH2M Hill\u2019s contract, which was initially only for engineering work, to about $10 million. \n \nHowever, that decision was made without opening the job to a public competitive bid, which would allow other companies to submit proposals. \n \nCity email records show a local construction company emailed the city expressing interest in submitting a proposal. Bend\u2019s Public Works Director Paul Rheault, who worked for CH2M Hill for 16 years before taking a job at the city, responded to the email by saying that keeping CH2M Hill on board would decrease costs in the long run by allowing city staff to do more work. \n \nBut keeping CH2M Hill on as the construction manager would lead to thousands of dollars in unexpected costs. \n \nBend City Manager Eric King said there is a lengthy review process before all big contract changes are approved. There are multiple people involved, and sometimes committees are formed to review the decision, he said. \n \n\u201cThere is no one individual that has the authority to make decisions,\u201d King said. \n \nOver budget \n \nAbout three years later, in 2014, city staff started to realize the sewer plant project was going drastically over budget, according to city email records. \n \nIn an attempt to get the project back on track, the city decided to hire Wodrich, who had left the city to work for HDR Engineering, for up to $345,000 to help manage the project. \n \nIn an email exchange that took place in Nov. 2014, Wodrich told Jeff England, the city\u2019s engineer for the project, that project costs were higher than expected. England responded to the email, saying that convincing Eric King and council to approve an additional $1.2 million would be difficult. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s really no advance notice that we are this far out of scope and budget,\u201d said England in the email. \n \nOn Tuesday, England said telling the consultant that there are difficulties getting contract increase approved is a negotiation tactic. \n \n\u201cIn other words, I\u2019m already pushing back on the consultant in order to minimize any potential cost increases,\u201d England said. \n \nBut months after the email exchange, city staff had yet to ask the City Council to increase the contract, and CH2M Hill was about to run out of money. CH2M Hill planned on working beyond the $4.5 million contract increase that had previously been approved by the council, according to city email records. \n \n\u201cThe sensitivity of the issue cannot be overstated and the timing for bringing (the amendment) forward, in whatever form, is of critical importance,\u201d said England in an email to CH2M Hill staff. \u201cHad we taken it to council two weeks ago as originally planned, we probably wouldn\u2019t be having this conversation because in all likelihood I would no longer be employed here \u2014 not kidding.\u201d \n \nOn Tuesday, England said there were no problems involving the amendment and bringing it forward for councilors\u2019 approval. Instead, the sensitivity of the issue had to do with the level of uncertainty about the project\u2019s future, England said. \n \nAt the time, the city was talking with another company to take over construction management services from CH2M Hill. City officials were also having discussions with attorneys about how to tackle problems with Apollo, he said. \n \nTom Hickmann, the director of the city\u2019s engineering department, said it took a while to bring the contract increase forward to city councilors because CH2M Hill\u2019s construction management costs were much higher than expected. Those costs grew after Apollo\u2019s construction didn\u2019t pass inspections, which meant CH2M Hill had to do more design work, he said. \n \nThe unexpected costs were something Bend\u2019s city councilors didn\u2019t take lightly, he said. \n \n\u201cThis is ballooning much bigger and even though I can sit here and defend all of it, the appearance of this it doesn\u2019t look good,\u201d said Hickmann. \u201cAnd we were certainly concerned about that public appearance even though we can defend (the costs incurred).\u201d \n \nKing, the city manager, said he was unaware of the email exchanges and any issues involving the contract increase. He said it\u2019s not unusual that city staff overseeing projects negotiate with the companies hired to build and oversee them. \n \n\u201cTheir job is to make sure that they can make the case,\u201d he said. \n \nThe Bend City Council eventually approved the contract increase in November 2015, nearly a year after staff knew the project was running over budget. The contract change increased CH2M Hill\u2019s contract by about $840,000 \u2014 more than $600,000 of which went to paying the company back for work that had been completed beyond the original contract\u2019s scope. \n \nAt that time, CH2M Hill\u2019s design errors and omissions on the project totaled between $415,000 and $620,000 \u2014 not including additional redesign and construction costs, according to city documents. In general, a certain number of design errors are considered normal \u2014 about 3 percent of total construction costs, according to city documents. \n \nAt that point, the city had approved about $1 million for construction changes, \u2014 about 3.17 percent of the project\u2019s total cost. \n \nCity of Bend officials would not comment about what portion of those construction changes were caused by design errors. However, Hickmann said a 3 to 5 percent change in the construction amount is not uncommon, and is not indicative of any serious design flaws. \n \nCH2M Hill officials would not comment on its involvement with the project. \n \nTaxpayers on the hook? \n \nDepending on what happens in court, taxpayers could be on the hook to pay Apollo up to $8 million on top of the $24 million the city has paid the company to date. \n \nSo far, the city has also spent about $465,000 on legal fees, which includes mediation efforts with Apollo. However, those legal costs will rise if the case goes to trial. \n \nDepending on the outcome of lawsuit, Bend taxpayers may also be footing the bill to finish 15 percent of the project that hasn\u2019t been completed. \n \nThis time, the construction project will be overseen by more strict city procedures, in part because of dealings with the sewer treatment plant project, said Hickmann. Several city policies were changed in response to problems on the project, he said. \n \nFor example, the city now tries to stay away from hiring outside engineering firms to work as construction managers on projects they\u2019ve designed, said Hickmann. Meanwhile, the city also made its request for proposal process more stringent, he said. Additionally, the city plans to avoid low-bid contract awarding \u2014 which is how Apollo was awarded the construction contract \u2014 in the future, Hickmann said. \n \n\u201cWe certainly didn\u2019t want to end up where we\u2019ve ended up,\u201d said Hickmann. \u201cWe did everything we could that we could think of in bringing outside expertise to help guide us to get the project on its rails and keep it there. And despite all that effort, we weren\u2019t successful.\u201d \n \n\u2014 Reporter: 541-633-2160, mriker@bendbulletin.com","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Construction news","group":"Industry"}],"title":"Bend sewer project plagued with cost overruns","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Jackson","zipCode":"97502","state":"Oregon","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Central Point","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bend Bulletin","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668815","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2479"},"name":"Bend Bulletin","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bendbulletin.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204956259","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:09Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:09Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396221551","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"OFFICE MANAGEMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"VETERANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"ARMIES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"79"},{"name":"INSPECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"INVESTIGATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"MEDICAL RECORDS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"73"},{"name":"NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BEND, OR, USA; UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; OREGON, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"}],"wordCount":"2299","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221551&p=2kx&v=1&x=Ebzd8O0DWccwH2pQQ-N6vg","id":"29396221551","content":"Animosity among staffers, distrust from veterans and improper record keeping that may have delayed or prevented clients from receiving disability benefits have plagued a Department of Veteran Affairs facility in Bend since it opened in 2010. \n \nThe Central Oregon Vet Center, which counsels combat veterans and veterans who were sexually assaulted in the military, failed its regional office\u2019s clinical inspections \u2014 those that assess its quality of service and client records \u2014 in each of the past six years. \n \nIts staff of five is the smallest of the five Vet Centers in Oregon and currently serves roughly 230 veterans in an area that extends east to the Idaho border and south to Christmas Valley. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s absolutely sickening,\u201d said Cody Standiford, who worked for the Vet Center for eight months before leaving in late 2014. \u201cThe management of that Vet Center had known from the day they opened their doors that they are not performing. They\u2019re failing clinical inspection after clinical inspection after clinical inspection. And yet, nothing is ever done to address it.\u201d \n \nBut things appear to be changing for the better since the arrival, early last year, of Amanda Juza as the Vet Center\u2019s new director. She started by getting patient records in order and meeting with employees individually to ensure they understood their duties. \n \n\u201cIn terms of continuity of care, in terms of providing the best care for veterans, absolutely our records need to be up to date and they need to be accurate and timely,\u201d said Juza, an Army veteran. \n \nThat\u2019s no small task. A 2016 inspection report echoed deficiencies from previous investigations and noted that counseling notes hadn\u2019t been completed for more than 300 patient visits. Half of the client files reviewed didn\u2019t have the military discharge paperwork used to prove eligibility. Seventy-five treatment plans were overdue. \n \nThe report was blunt: Juza had \u201cinherited counselors who weren\u2019t doing their jobs.\u201d \n \nNo records for claim \n \nStandiford, a veteran who currently works for the nonprofit Central Oregon Veterans Outreach, first learned about problems at the Vet Center while handling veteran\u2019s issues in Congressman Greg Walden\u2019s Bend office. \n \nMultiple veterans told Standiford they were struggling to get their claims for service-connected disability approved through the VA because the Vet Center could not provide records of their counseling, he said. \n \n\u201cWe couldn\u2019t prove that the veteran actually went to or received treatment on the dates that they claimed because if it\u2019s not in the record, it didn\u2019t happen,\u201d he said. \n \nStandiford began working at the Vet Center as an office manager in March 2014. His suspicion prompted a deeper dive into the facility\u2019s records, turning up more than 200 patient visits over the course of six months in 2014 that were accounted for on paper log-in sheets but not documented in electronic records. He said many of those patients had been seen by Gary Hunter, a counselor who also directed the Vet Center. \n \nHunter, who continues to work at the Vet Center as a counselor, declined to comment for this article. Juza would not offer details about why Hunter was allowed to remain a counselor. \n \nEvidence of disability \n \nI nstructions for filing a claim for disability benefits with the Veterans Benefits Administration directs veterans to provide all relevant evidence in their possession, including treatment records and medical evidence. Vet Centers are not involved in the process beyond providing records. \n \nThe Center always gives clients their records when they ask for them, Juza said. She said it\u2019s also possible to get disability benefits for PTSD without having received counseling, although she couldn\u2019t explain more about the process. \n \nDavid Kaplan, chief professional officer for the American Counseling Association, a membership association for the counseling profession, said when he was in private practice, he provided treatment records for veteran clients for use in disability assessments. \n \nJuza said she does not recall speaking with veterans whose lack of records prompted the rejection of their disability claims. The Bulletin could not confirm any claims of veterans being denied benefits as a result of bad record keeping. \n \nStarting over with vets \n \nOnce Juza took over, new counselors had to start over with veterans because their former counselors hadn\u2019t kept records from their visits, she said. Juza declined to say whether former counselors were disciplined, but said at least one was transferred to a different Vet Center. \n \n\u201cThere were a lot of veterans that we as a team had to say, \u2018I\u2019m really sorry, unfortunately, the counselor who saw you before is gone,\u2019\u201d she recalled. \u201c\u2018They\u2019re not here anymore and this was never completed, so if you don\u2019t mind, maybe we could start again.\u2019\u201d \n \nThe American Counseling Association\u2019s code of ethics directs counselors to keep notes of all their sessions with clients. \n \nMissing records from a previous counselor could trigger a lack of trust in the new one, Kaplan said. \n \n\u201cIf somebody said that to me, my feeling was, \u2018That other counselor didn\u2019t care about me. They didn\u2019t care about me at all. \u2026 Why should I open up to you and give you a chance to earn my trust?\u2019\u201d he said. \n \nStandiford agreed. \n \n\u201cThat vet will need to start at the beginning to get that person up to speed, which \u2014 speaking as a combat vet with PTSD \u2014 that is not a fun thing to do,\u201d he said. \u201cIt takes a long time to build that rapport.\u201d \n \n\u2018Bureaucracy at its worst\u2019 \n \nHunter led the Vet Center during Standiford\u2019s time there in addition to working as a counselor. \n \nA handful of veterans described having personal issues with Hunter\u2019s counseling style. \n \nRoger Riolo, a 73-year-old Vietnam veteran who lives in Bend, is a longtime member of a counseling group for veterans with PTSD. When Hunter started leading the group, Riolo said some veterans stopped going because of they weren\u2019t comfortable with him. \n \n\u201cWe had bad experiences with Gary,\u201d he said. \n \nRiolo, a former Air Force captain, recalls one veteran who appeared to be struggling with severe PTSD and never spoke at meetings. Finally, after several months, the man began to talk about his experience. \n \n\u201cGary shut him down in group immediately and said, \u2018We don\u2019t talk about that stuff here,\u2019\u201d Riolo said. \u201cWe never saw that guy again.\u201d \n \nThat incident upset many in the room, said Rex Tompkins, a 69-year-old Vietnam War veteran who lives in Bend. \n \n\u201cEverybody in the group just looked at each other and went, \u2018That was messed up,\u2019\u201d he said. \n \nTroy Wise, a 69-year-old Army veteran who served two tours in the Vietnam War, said after that, he and others were fed up with Hunter. \n \n\u201cThe group made it clear that if Gary showed up, we were leaving,\u201d he said. \n \nWise also received couple\u2019s counseling with Hunter and said the counselor would have trouble referring to previous sessions. It seemed to him Hunter hadn\u2019t kept good notes from previous sessions. \n \n\u201cThat didn\u2019t work for me at all,\u201d said Wise, who is now divorced. \u201cLike most of the vets there, I have no respect for Gary. He\u2019s just putting in time.\u201d \n \nBefore he left the Vet Center, which employed five people, Standiford said he and two colleagues signed a letter of no confidence calling for Hunter\u2019s resignation. When nothing came of it, Standiford said he quit. VA spokesman Dave Bayard declined to comment on Standiford\u2019s departure. \n \nRiolo describes the situation as a \u201ctravesty.\u201d \n \n\u201cIt was bureaucracy at its worst,\u201d he said. \u201cWhen three employees stand up and say we have no confidence \u2014 thank God they did \u2014 but none of those three work there anymore, and Gary Hunter still does.\u201d \n \n\u2018A considerable number of complaints\u2019 \n \nProblems started shortly after the Center Oregon Vet Center began seeing patients from a temporary location in 2010. That year, it failed its first clinical inspection. \n \nThe VA provided The Bulletin copies of inspection reports dating back to 2011 in response to a Freedom of Information Act request. Although the 2010 report was not provided, the 2013 report deemed the facility unsatisfactory \u201cfor the third year in a row.\u201d \n \nThe VA\u2019s regional office strives to perform clinical inspections of Vet Centers annually, Bayard wrote in an email. Clinical inspections are a subjective analysis of the quality of service provided and focus heavily on patient charts. \n \nThe inspections repeat the same issues year after year. Each are signed by Steve Reeves, the manager of the Fairfield, California, office that oversees Vet Centers in Oregon and a number of other states. Reeves did not respond to multiple requests seeking comment. \n \nIn 2011, the clinical inspection report found nearly half of the Vet Center\u2019s cases lacked proof of eligibility, although about half of those had been transferred in from a different VA clinic. Eighty percent of closed cases were missing summaries the VA requires when patients stop coming. \n \nThe report\u2019s concluding remarks were damning. \n \n\u201cThere have been a considerable number of complaints from various members of the Veteran and Veteran services community since this center was opened,\u201d the report stated. \u201cThese complaints have continued and have required interventions by the regional office.\u201d \n \n\u2018No longer functioning as a team\u2019 \n \nBy 2015, the Vet Center seemed to have reached a breaking point. That year\u2019s inspection report cited \u201cmultiple staffing challenges and disagreements to the point where it is no longer functioning as a team\u201d and said its reputation had suffered greatly due to the \u201cinconsistent services\u201d provided. \n \nThat year, several patient files were missing treatment plans or the plans were late. Treatment plans outline the issues a patient wants to resolve. \n \nDozens of patient files were missing their military release or discharge documents, which serve as proof of eligibility. Seventy percent of patients whose cases were closed had not been sent a follow-up letter or email, which is required. \n \nKaplan said the American Counseling Association considers failing to follow up with clients who fail to make appointments abandonment. \n \n\u201cWe have a responsibility to try to reach out to them and say, \u2018Hey, is everything OK? Would you want to make another appointment?\u2019\u201d he said. \n \nHunter stepped down as the Center\u2019s leader in 2015. \n \nProblems persisted into the following year, when an inspection found 42 intakes were past due. Intakes are performed when clients begin counseling and assess issues, behaviors, thought patterns and contributing factors such as drug use, medical conditions or relationships. \n \n\u201cWithout that kind of thorough assessment, you\u2019re just sort of flying by the seat of your pants,\u201d Kaplan said. \n \nProgress notes \u2014 about what happened during counseling sessions \u2014 hadn\u2019t been completed in 326 cases, according to the 2016 report. \n \n\u201cLet\u2019s say you went for a checkup and the physician did not write a single thing down,\u201d Kaplan said. \u201cHow would you feel?\u201d \n \nDisagreements between staff \n \nEmails between Vet Center staff members in recent years provided by Standiford illustrate a precarious work environment. \n \nBoth Standiford and Wells Kempter, then a counselor at the Vet Center, expressed concerns to superiors about financial ties the Vet Center and its outreach specialist, Greg Ford, had with outside groups. It\u2019s unclear whether ethical or legal violations existed. Kempter, who is currently listed as a counselor on the Portland Vet Center\u2019s website, could not be reached for comment. \n \nFord, who declined to comment for this article, now serves in a newly created position at the Vet Center focused on suicide prevention and crisis response, Juza said. \n \nCounselors Kempter and Hemmer both complained in 2014 emails to Hunter \u2014 which they included Standiford on \u2014 about new clients being placed on their caseload without their knowledge. \n \n\u201cArbitrarily assigning people, w/o informing me of this action, at worst, sets me up for failure as a member of this team and at best creates a lot more work for me that may not be completed in a timely manner, since I hadn\u2019t been consulted or informed,\u201d Hemmer wrote. \n \nThe tension between staff members was obvious to Tompkins when he visited the Vet Center for both individual and group counseling. The negativity \u2014 among both employees and fellow veterans \u2014 prompted him to stop going. He\u2019s currently being treated for lung cancer. \n \n\u201cI just couldn\u2019t deal with it anymore,\u201d he said. \u201cI have to keep my attitude high. I have to keep positive.\u201d \n \n\u2018Just what this place needs\u2019 \n \nVeterans interviewed for this article say they lobbied hard for a new director to replace Hunter. They wanted Juza, a Blue River native who served two tours in the Iraq War, to lead the facility. \n \n\u201cShe seems like just what this place needs,\u201d Wise said. \n \nJuza, a licensed independent clinical social worker, welcomed the change. She worked at the Portland Vet Center before coming to Bend. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m not really a city girl,\u201d Juza said. Plus, Central Oregon is closer to family. \n \nOn top of her administrative duties, Juza also performs counseling. She has a bachelor\u2019s degree in psychology and a master\u2019s degree in social work. Juza is the facility\u2019s only female counselor and its designated military sexual trauma counselor. \n \nWise said he found one-on-one counseling with Juza comforting after his divorce. \n \n\u201cShe helped a great deal with taking the worst-case scenario and making a plan for it,\u201d he said. \n \nJuza has added a women\u2019s group and a class for military spouses and family members. The Center now sends counselors to La Pine, Prineville and Madras. A counselor also sees veterans at the Deschutes County jail every two weeks. \n \nThere are weekly staff meetings, and Juza said she performs extensive reviews of patient charts once a month. \n \nUntil Juza arrived, 71-year-old Vietnam veteran Craig Jorgensen said the Center was \u201cpretty chaotic and not very helpful.\u201d Recently, he said things are turning around. \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s things that are happening that never happened before,\u201d Jorgensen said. \n \nDespite failing its 2016 clinical inspection, the report noted it expected significant improvements the following year. \n \nJuza said she wants veterans to know that the Vet Center is \u201cre-energized.\u201d \n \n\u201cWe are basically a brand-new facility from what it was in the past,\u201d she said, \u201cand we would really love the opportunity to earn a chance to get to know them.\u201d \n \n\u2014 Reporter: 541-383-0304, \n \ntbannow@bendbulletin.com","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Vietnam news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Veterans news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Veterans hope new director improves counseling center","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Jackson","zipCode":"97502","state":"Oregon","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Central Point","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bend Bulletin","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668815","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2479"},"name":"Bend Bulletin","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bendbulletin.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.benefits.va.gov/compensation/evidence.asp"],"sequenceId":"695204956434","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:09Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

(Photo: STAR FILE PHOTO) \n  \nMore than 60 vendors are scheduled to attend the fourth annual Camarillo Ranch wedding showcase from noon to 4 p.m. Feb. 11, organizers said. \n \nPartnering with Camarillo Ranch are Party Pleasers Event Rentals, Camarillo Bridal Boutique and Unique Floral Designs. Organizers said the aim is to create a luxurious, unique and memorable experience for local brides and grooms-to-be, as well as their family and friends. \n \nThe event at 201 Camarillo Ranch Road in Camarillo will include a bridal fashion show and grooms\u2019 dance-off. Other  highlights will include: \n  Wedding industry vendors, including rentals, caterers, florists, photographers, disc jockeys and more.  Wedding bingo and raffle prizes valued at $100 each.  Food, dessert and alcohol samples from caterers, bakeries and wineries.  Wedding design inspiration in all Camarillo Ranch event spaces.  A grand prize of a complimentary wedding and reception hosted at the Camarillo Ranch, valued up to $6,500 (restrictions apply).   \nIf the event is rained out, the alternate date is Feb. 26. \n \nFor {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:10Z","duplicateGroupId":"29351608119","companies":[{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"BER","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"STU","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"DUS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"MUN","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"FRA","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYT","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"NYS","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501111073"},{"symbol":"NYTAB","primary":true,"name":"New York Times Co","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US6501114044"},{"symbol":"4318","primary":true,"name":"Quick Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3266000003"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"COLLEGIATE SPORTS ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MOVIE REVIEWS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TWINS & MULTIPLE BIRTHS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY SPORTS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"POSTPRODUCTION SERVICES","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MOVIE INDUSTRY","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"SPECIAL EFFECTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"66"},{"name":"FILM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ACTORS & ACTRESSES","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WINTER SPORTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"INTERVIEWS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MINNESOTA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"1220","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396221582&p=2kx&v=1&x=P_kehOynvFiTNlbFtVBXww","id":"29396221582","content":"BEMIDJI, Minn. \u2014 Once in a while, when school is out and the hockey-playing Fitzgerald triplets are home in Port Alberni, British Columbia, on Vancouver Island, friends will text them that one of their movies is on television. \n \nThey usually ignore it. \n \nLong before Gerry, Leo and Myles Fitzgerald played hockey here for Bemidji State, they were child actors who appeared in two major studio films: \u201cBaby Geniuses,\u201d released in 1999 and starring Kathleen Turner and Christopher Lloyd, and a 2004 sequel featuring Jon Voight. \n \nThey remember almost nothing about the first movie, which came out when they were curly haired 5-year-olds, and a bit more about the sequel. But they have not watched either in years, mainly out of embarrassment. Think of your parents breaking out the childhood home movies on prom night. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s been on TV a couple of times back at home,\u201d Gerry said. \u201cWe just kind of skip right through it.\u201d \n \nCritics panned \u201cBaby Geniuses,\u201d about super-smart toddlers communicating in their own language, for an over-the-top script and awkward computer-generated special effects. (The Fitzgeralds took turns playing twins.) \n \nOne scene appeared to feature Gerry in a white disco suit dancing like Tony Manero, John Travolta\u2019s character in \u201cSaturday Night Fever.\u201d A stunt double did the dancing, with Gerry\u2019s head superimposed in postproduction. \n \nIn The New York Times, Janet Maslin began her review of the movie with this: \u201cOne way to get through \u2018Baby Geniuses\u2019 is to think about whether it really is the worst movie you\u2019ve ever seen. Probably not, but pretty darn close.\u201d Film critic Roger Ebert called it one of the worst movies of 1999. \n \nWhen \u201cSuperbabies: Baby Geniuses 2\u201d wrapped, so did the Fitzgeralds\u2019 big-screen careers. \n \n\u201cThey did those two movies, and in between they were typical little boys,\u201d their mother, Janet Fitzgerald, said in a telephone interview from Port Alberni. \u201cTheir love was hockey from the day they put skates on when they were like 5 years old. Hockey was their passion. Acting was definitely not their passion.\u201d \n \nThough undersize \u2014 Leo is 5 feet 9, Gerry 5-8 and Myles 5-7 \u2014 the Fitzgeralds formed such a prolific forward line through junior hockey that they were twice traded as a unit. Their wish to attend college together brought them to Bemidji State, an NCAA Division I program in the north woods of Minnesota that made an unexpected run to the Frozen Four in 2009. \n \nNow juniors, the 23-year-old triplets have combined for 15 goals for the 20th-ranked Beavers (16-9-3 overall), who lead the Western Collegiate Hockey Association standings by nine points and seek their first NCAA Tournament berth since 2010. \n \nResearch by Bemidji State officials turned up only one other set of triplets on the same college team: Brian, Craig and Glenn Seabury of Mass.-Lowell from 1989 to 1990. \n \n\u201cIn junior hockey, you could just see it \u2014 they were rink rats,\u201d Bemidji State coach Tom Serratore said of the Fitzgeralds. \u201cThose are the kind of guys you want on your team because you never have to motivate them. We really wanted those guys, and we worked on them for a while.\u201d \n \nSerratore mostly kept the Fitzgeralds on the same line in their first two seasons, with Myles on left wing, Leo at center and Gerry on right wing. The Beavers captain, Charlie O\u2019Connor, described them as \u201cthree fireballs on the ice at once, kind of like three Tasmanian devils.\u201d \n \nBut this season Serratore, seeking better offensive balance, moved Myles off the line and installed senior Brendan Harms on left wing with Leo and Gerry. That line has accounted for 19 of Bemidji State\u2019s 66 goals. \n \nHockey players can be cruel teasers, and Harms said the Fitzgeralds still took occasional needling about the movies. Serratore, though, has never shown either film on the team bus. For that, the triplets are grateful. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m surprised they haven\u2019t, I\u2019ll be honest,\u201d Leo said. \u201cIn juniors they put it on once, and we were pretty embarrassed at the time. We were around 17 years old. They razzed us a little bit, nothing crazy.\u201d \n \nThe story of how the Fitzgeralds landed in Hollywood might make a better movie than the ones they appeared in. \n \nJanet Fitzgerald said her sister thought the boys were adorable and urged her to submit photos to a Vancouver talent agency. So she did. A few weeks later, the agency invited them to a casting call in Vancouver for \u201cBaby Geniuses.\u201d The producers sought triplets or twins for the two leading toddler roles. \n \n\u201cWe went to the audition and thought nothing would happen,\u201d she said. \u201cBut the boys got called back for another interview and audition, and they got the part.\u201d \n \nFive months of filming in Southern California followed. (The sequel was shot in Vancouver.) Their mother said that Turner and her co-star Dom DeLuise were wonderful with the boys, and that she still kept in touch with Jimmy Wagner, a so-called Hollywood baby wrangler who helped the boys learn their dialogue. \n \nGerry remembers rehearsing lines for the second film with Voight in the star\u2019s trailer. \n \n\u201cI didn\u2019t even know who he was at the time,\u201d Gerry said. \u201cI wasn\u2019t very good at it because I was 7 years old, 8 years old. But looking back, it was pretty cool he kind of did that. I got the opportunity to sit down with Jon Voight, a pretty big star.\u201d \n \nBut hockey quickly consumed them. Leo took it up first, following their older brother Sheldon, and Gerry and Myles soon joined in. Their mother said she only recently repaired the broken windows and smashed stucco on their house, caused by thousands of pucks sailing high and wide of the net that the boys set up in their carport. She declined to identify the son who destroyed a living room window with a poorly aimed slap shot from the road. \n \n\u201cOur parents asked us if we wanted to keep trying the acting thing or play hockey,\u201d Myles said. \u201cObviously, we all wanted to play hockey. We were so young at the time to make a decision, but hockey is where we wanted to focus.\u201d \n \nAt Bemidji State, it did not take long for teammates and coaches to figure out how to tell the Fitzgeralds apart. (Leo and Myles are identical and Gerry is fraternal, their mother said.) Leo is the tallest, the only left-handed shot, and prefers a clear face shield on his helmet; the others wear the wire-cage style. \n \nSitting for an interview at the Sanford Center, Bemidji State\u2019s home rink, the Fitzgeralds subtly differentiated themselves. Leo and Gerry wore Bemidji hockey ball caps, Leo with the brim facing forward, Gerry\u2019s backward. Myles sported a Minnesota Twins cap. \n \n\u201cWhen they first came in, when I first saw them, it was kind of tough to tell who was who,\u201d Harms said. \u201cBut once you get to know them, they\u2019ve got three different personalities, three completely different guys. Leo is the most outgoing, for sure. Myles is a little bit quiet, and he\u2019s the smallest one, too. Gerry and Leo are a little similar.\u201d \n \nThe Beavers do not score a lot, instead relying on team defense and standout junior goalie Michael Bitzer. Bemidji State leads Division I in scoring defense at 1.79 goals allowed per game, and in penalty killing at 90 percent. \n \n\u201cEveryone knows their roles,\u201d Leo said. \u201cWe all come to the rink and want to work. We know what we\u2019ve got to do to win games.\u201d \n \nNo acting required.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Triplets at Bemidji State, once child actors, are stars on the ice","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Jackson","zipCode":"97502","state":"Oregon","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Central Point","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bend Bulletin","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169668815","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2479"},"name":"Bend Bulletin","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Sports","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bendbulletin.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695204956865","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:10Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

So I\u2019m sure it\u2019s going to be a few days, they told us, before they can come up with any answers for us.\u201d \n \nThe congregation\u2019s pastor, known as an imam, was awake in the early morning hours and checked online surveillance of the mosque and found no alarm active and the doors unlocked, Hashmi said. On Jan. 21, someone broke in and stole some electronics, including laptops. \n \n\u201cHe was worried about it and drove over there,\u201d Hashmi said. \u201cBy that time, fire engines were already there pouring water on the fire.\u201d \n \nThe structure was built in 2000. \n \nNo injuries were reported. It took about four hours to extinguish the blaze. \n \nHashmi, who\u2019s lived in Victoria 32 years, said the congregation of about 140 has had few other problems and has enjoyed support from the city of about 115 miles southwest of Houston. He already has received offers of temporary quarters for the congregation to worship. \n \n\u201cWhen 9/11 happened, Muslims and non-Muslims, we all got together,\u201d he said. \u201cOf course, we will rebuild.\u201d \n \nThe Victoria Advocate on Saturday reported that in July 2013, a man admitted to painting \u201cH8,\u201d a computer shorthand for \u201chate,\u201d on the outside of the building. \n \nOn Jan. 7, a mosque under construction near Lake Travis in Austin was burned to the ground. \n \nThe Texas office of the Council on American-Islamic Relations said like that blaze, it would monitor the investigation of the Victoria fire. \n \n\u201cBecause of growing anti-Muslim bigotry in our nation, and because of the recent spike in hate incidents targeting Islamic institutions and individuals, we urge investigators to keep the possibility of a bias motive for this fire in mind,\u201d CAIR-Houston Executive Director Mustafaa Carroll said. \n \nThere\u2019s been no determination yet for the Austin blaze, Diane Kanawati, with CAIR-Austin, said Saturday. \n \nIn December, a man was sentenced to four years in prison for setting fire to a Houston mosque where he worshipped. how to instil a sense of pride, build something solid.\n\nBut instead the group awoke in this idyllic setting on Sunday morning to the ugly news that US President Donald Trump had decreed that citizens of Somalia and six other predominantly Muslim countries would be barred entry to the United States for 90 days.\n\nAnd this divisive move has taken the gloss off their special Anglesea trip.\n\n\"We are shocked, it's very disappointing,\" Mr Haraco said. \"This is banishing normal, honest people who are trying to visit their families.\"\n\nMr Haraco, a dual citizen of Somalia and Australia, speaks from personal experience.\n\nHis mother-in-law, Nadira Tabid, raised him as her own after she married his father in Somalia.\n\nNow she lives in Houston and he had planned to visit her in July, continuing the rhythm of trips he has always made to her. From Somalia, to her last home in India, and now Texas, the state that abuts another Trump target: Mexico.\n\nMr Haraco, secretary of the Somali Australian Council of Victoria, doesn't know if he should book tickets or wait to see what unfolds when the 90-day period ends.\n\nWill the ban continue? When will he see his elderly mother-in-law again? She is over 70 now; he doesn't want to leave it too long.\n\nConfusion and concern among immigrants and refugee advocates has been widespread, with travellers detained or sent home from US airports.\n\nThere is confusion, too, among the young men that Mr Haraco has brought down to the ocean to mull over the qualities of a leader.\n\nSome have talked about finding it difficult to get a job in Melbourne because of the colour of their skin, or their religion.\n\nThe group also discussed gangs, and young people they know who are dropping out of school, drawn to these groups.\n\nBut the bigger purpose was to inspire them, says council member Abdi Aziz, and he remains convinced that Trump's ruling won't quash their enthusiasm for multiculturalism.\n\n\"Diversity is mainstream in Australia \u2026 but the risk is there. For us it's an important time for our Prime Minister to show political leadership in this area.\"\n\nMany people he had spoken to that morning were feeling a sense of loss, he said. their connecting flights in Singapore. \n \nHowever, passenger Gabriel Xie, who is heading to Tokyo with his wife for their honeymoon, said most were fairly relaxed about the extra wait. \n were going to to make sure everyone was OK. \n \n\"They're trying to arrange everything for connecting flights, but we'll have to confirm them once we arrive in Singapore,\" he said. \n \n\"It's frustrating, but at the same time the crew is doing their best and the passengers are civilised, so it's not too bad.\" \n \nFlight SQ286 was supposed to depart at 1.30pm but aborted due to potential issues with the nose wheel of the aircraft. \n \nXie thought wind was buffeting the plane as it headed down the runway on its first attempt. \n \n\"The plane was wobbly when we tried to take off, wheel,\" Xie said. \n \nThe flight was initially rescheduled for a 5pm takeoff, but that was repeatedly pushed back. \n \nThe Singapore Airlines office was contacted but refused to comment about the failed takeoff. \n \nThe runway was \"closed for a short time\" about 3pm, possibly to remove debris, an airport spokesman said. \n \nOne plane was diverted from Auckland Airport due to the runway closure. \n \nEmirates flight 406 from Melbourne was due to land at 3.20pm but was diverted to the Ohakea New Zealand Defence Force base, near Bulls, the spokesman said. \n \nLocals in Ohakea remarked Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. Qantas is offering refunds to any passengers travelling from Australia to the United States who are affected by a new entry ban. Dozens of travellers have been detained at US airports and protests have erupted around the country. The executive order signed by US President Donald Trump has barred citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries \u2013 Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen \u2013 from entering the US for 90 days. That includes legal US residents temporarily out of the country.\n\nThe order has also barred all refugees from entering the US for 120 days and Syrian refugees indefinitely.\n\nAdditionally, Australian citizens who have travelled to the seven countries since March 1, 2011 are no longer eligible to enter the US under the Visa Waiver Program, and are now required to apply for a US visa.\n\nAustralians who are dual citizens of the nominated countries, including government officials, and \"have previously been issued an [Electronic System for Travel Authorisation] are likely to have the ESTA revoked\", according to the Australian government.\n\nNo travellers from Australia are known to have been immediately affected by the ban.\n\n\"The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not received any requests for consular assistance from Australians unable to board transport to the United States,\" a spokeswoman for Foreign Affairs Minister Julie Bishop said.\n\n\"The Australian embassy in Washington is engaging with US officials on the potential implications of the suspension for Australian travellers, including dual nationals.\n\n\"Travellers are advised that visa and other entry and exit conditions can change at short notice.\"\n\nQantas is advising anyone who thinks they may be affected to contact the airline directly or speak to their travel agent, and said it will provide affected passengers with a number of options, including a refund or a change of destination.\n\n\"Qantas notes the advice from the US government regarding tighter entry conditions,\" a spokesman for the airline said.\n\n\"We will reflect this change in our processes and booking systems, however it is not likely to materially impact Qantas passengers.\"\n\nIt is estimated 100 to 200 people who had already begun their journey when Mr Trump signed the order yesterday have been detained at US airports, according to the American Civil Liberties Union. An has temporarily stopped the government from sending those who landed with valid visas out of the country.\n\nCrowds of protesters have gathered at US airports in response to the order and subsequent detainments. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:18:26Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396187182","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"STADIUMS & ARENAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"NEW ZEALAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"58"}],"wordCount":"328","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396222198&p=2kx&v=1&x=h_0VUHxe-xr_anB9FdCXSw","id":"29396222198","content":", 7:18 pm \n   \nWellington blew a chance to sneak into the A-League's top six when two Adelaide United novices scored goals on Sunday in a 2-2 draw. \n\nAdelaide's 18-year-old Riley McGree and Nikola Mileusnic potted their first A-League goals in stifling heat at Coopers Stadium. \n\nMcGree scored first before Wellington's Thomas Doyle and Roy Krishna put the visitors on the brink of a valuable away win. \n\nBut with 20 minutes remaining, Mileusnic scrambled a tap-in to deny the Phoenix, who would have risen to fifth with a win but find themselves in seventh spot. \n\nDefending champions Adelaide remain last with just two wins, after a match played in oppressive heat topping 38 degrees - there were as many drinks breaks (four, at 15-minute intervals) as goals. \n\nAdelaide took an early lead when McGree scored in the seventh minute with a thundering left-footer from 15 metres after a lay-off from Marc Marino, brought into the side to replace discarded Spanish striker Sergio Guardiola, who has returned to his homeland. \n\nBut it took the visitors just four minutes to square the ledger when Doyle made a mockery of Adelaide's defence. \n\nThe left-back sliced through four Reds before unleashing a cracking left-footed strike which clipped the inside of the near post before finding the net. \n\nKrishna extended Wellington's lead in the 37th minute after being played in by Kosta Barbarouses in a swift transition. \n\nKrishna was marked by Adelaide attacker Henrique but shrugged the attention before calmly sliding the ball past Adelaide goalkeeper Eugene Galekovic and into the net. \n\nAdelaide pressed for an equaliser for much of the second half and were rewarded with Mileusnic's breakthrough goal in the 80th minute - after Ben Garrucio's free kick struck the left post, he scrambled a tap-in from the rebound near the right post. \n\nAdelaide's Cirio could even have pinched the points in the 90th minute when a shot dribbled just wide and the stalemate remained for the 10 minutes of extra-time - They keep going. We spoke about it before the game - winners find a way to win.\" \n\nThe result left Western Sydney in eighth spot, but still only two points outside the top six. \n\n\"To think we're going home with nothing is hard to believe. AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"CANADA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"98"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"THAILAND","domains":["GEO"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PAPUA NEW GUINEA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"SYRIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"MALCOLM TURNBULL","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JUSTIN TRUDEAU","domains":["PEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"DONALD TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"76"},{"name":"BARACK OBAMA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"56"}],"wordCount":"517","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396222489&p=2kx&v=1&x=GjNkL5eijHp7Nb0XIZFhJg","id":"29396222489","content":"A leading refugee advocate has called on the Turnbull government to begin negotiations to resettle people held on Manus Island and Nauru in Canada, capitalising on Justin Trudeau's record in welcoming nearly 40,000 Syrians in two years. \n \nMelbourne community organiser Anne Horrigan-Dixon said the announcement that US President Donald Trump would honour a deal signed with the Obama administration last year to resettle some refugees raised a series of questions, including how many people being held by Australia would move to the US and how long the process would take.  \n SHARE  Share on Facebook  SHARE  Share on Twitter  TWEET  Pin to Pinterest  PIN  Link   Advocate Anne Horrigan-Dixon with Syria-born former refugee Michael Aboujundi in Melbourne.  Photo: Darrian Traynor  \nMr Trump's controversial executive order on Saturday suspended entry to the US for refugees for 120 days and barred Syrians indefinitely. It will also block entry for citizens of Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.  \n \nThough the crackdown was expected, US Homeland Security officials continued interviews of refugees held by Australia on Nauru as late as Friday. \n SHARE  Share on Facebook  SHARE  Share on Twitter  TWEET  Pin to Pinterest  PIN  Link   Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has welcomed refugees since coming to office.  Photo: AP  \nMs Horrigan-Dixon received the medal of the Order of Australia in last week's Australia Day honours, recognition for more than 30 years of work to support waves of refugees arriving in Australia, including from Europe, China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Thailand. \n \nShe said Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull should immediately explain how many people would go to the US. \n \n   \n\"Australia needs to start thinking about how we can work with local groups in Canada,\" she said.  \n \n\"The major problem remains the 1500-odd people being held on Manus Island and in Papua New Guinea, because no other country will accept them.  \n \n\"Justin Trudeau and his government have welcomed people. Maybe we need a delegation over there, and Australia could take people Canada would have otherwise taken to get people off these islands.\"   \n \nAn adviser to the St Mary's House of Welcome project in Fitzroy and founder of a series of local engagement and English-language programs, Ms Horrigan-Dixon said the Coalition and Labor had denied thousands of people the chance to build successful lives in Australia's cities and towns.  \n \nShe said the reinstatement of temporary protection visas by the Abbott government in 2013 meant many asylum seekers living in the community were in limbo, while those given permanent resettlement were thriving.  \n \n\"They want to be here and they want to work and settle. The thing they say they love the most is our democracy, our stable system of government and the inclusion and safety of Australia,\" Ms Horrigan-Dixon said.  \n \n\"What we set out to do is think how would we treat these people if they were our own children? \n \n\"Everything has been teamwork, because we've had a common cause.\" \n \nCanada has accepted 39,671 Syrians since November 2015. \n \n\"After these poor people have suffered for years on Manus and Nauru, they need to be somewhere welcoming and Justin Trudeau has shown he's prepared to provide that,\" she said.  \n \nFollow Tom McIlroy on","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"}],"title":"Negotiate with Trudeau for refugee resettlement, says advocate","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","countryCode":"AU","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"1","name":"Sydney Morning Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169587970","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Sydney Morning Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Politics","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.smh.com.au/","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://www.facebook.com/tcmcilroy"],"sequenceId":"695204971457","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:33:18Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
