UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"KAMALA HARRIS","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"JERRY BROWN","domains":["PEO"],"score":"58"},{"name":"XAVIER BECERRA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"59"}],"wordCount":"534","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396227403&p=2kx&v=1&x=gRlH2cn3nJXl7JMj650l8g","id":"29396227403","content":"Of the many tasks facing Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra in his new job, it was an unheralded duty that Republican legislators wanted to pin him down on during recent confirmation hearings in Sacramento: the vetting of ballot initiatives.\n\nThe attorney general is tasked under California law to write a brief title and summary of each measure that will end up on the state ballot.\n\n\u201cWhat will you do to ensure that you\u2019re being descriptive and objective, and following the election code, when you write those ballot titles and summaries?\u201d asked Assemblyman Jordan Cunningham (R-Templeton).\n\nTo understand the question requires knowing a bit of California political history. Attorneys general have long had the duty to collect and then prepare proposed initiatives before the measure\u2019s backers can begin collecting voter signatures.\n\nBut in the era of big money initiative campaigns \u2014 generally viewed as the years following the landmark 1978 property tax rollback, Proposition 13 \u2014 critics have occasionally complained of partisan scheming, alleging that the title and summary of an initiative are sometimes crafted in a way that pleases the attorney general\u2019s political allies. Opponents of Proposition 13 complained that former Atty. Gen. Evelle Younger, a Republican, wrote a summary that didn\u2019t reveal the law made it harder to pass tax increases in the Legislature. Gov. Jerry Brown, in his time as attorney general, took fire over the ballot summary for the 2008 ban on same-sex marriage, Proposition 8, and its emphasis on how the (now defunct) law would \u201celiminate\u201d the right of same-sex couples to marry.\n\nAdvocates of overhauling California\u2019s public employee pension system have balked more than once over initiative titles and summaries written by Democrats serving as attorney general. In 2005, a proposed reform was summarized as removing death and disability benefits. The most recent attorney general, now Sen. Kamala Harris, also came under fire for her summaries of efforts to change pension benefits for government workers.\n\nThe evidence is largely circumstantial. And judges have generally given pretty wide latitude to the attorney general, who\u2019s simply instructed in state election law to summarize \u201cthe chief purpose and points\u201d of an initiative.\n\nBut it\u2019s also a potential game changer. Strategists and pollsters often believe an initiative\u2019s title and summary is a prescient predictor of the campaign ahead. And some California voters make snap decisions on ballot measures based on those easily accessible nuggets of information.\n\nGiven that Democrats have held the office of attorney general for 18 years, it\u2019s hardly surprising that the loudest calls for change come from Republicans. But those efforts have been routinely rebuffed.\n\nIn 2015, legislation to impose new rules on the attorney general was quietly killed in the Assembly\u2019s appropriations committee. Earlier this month, newly elected Assemblyman Kevin Kiley (R-El Dorado Hills) decided to go one step further. His proposal would change the state\u2019s constitution and transfer the responsibility for initiative titles and summaries to the independent Legislative Analyst\u2019s Office, which currently writes a fiscal analysis of each measure.\n\nAs for Becerra, the Los Angeles Democrat told lawmakers in confirmation hearings this month that he believes in fairness when it comes to summarizing initiatives.\n\n\u201cI know many of you will be reading over my shoulders,\u201d he told assemblymembers on Jan. 10. \u201cAnd I understand the importance of a word.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"US politics news","group":"Society"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Political Road Map: Some believe theres bias baked into the official descriptions of California initiatives","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"1","name":"Los Angeles Times","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169587902","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"22602"},"name":"Los Angeles Times","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Politics","Society","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.latimes.com","publisher":"Tribune Company"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.twitter.com/johnmyers","https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/california-politics-podcast/id1067429614?mt=2"],"sequenceId":"695205065628","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:11Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:15Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396228050","companies":[{"symbol":"INFT","primary":true,"name":"Infinity Energy SA","contentCount":1,"exchange":"LON","titleCount":0,"isin":"LU0726886947"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"HISTORY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"INDICTMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"EVIDENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"REFERENDUMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"JOURNALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"VOTERS & VOTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PRESS CONFERENCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"WITNESSES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"BREXIT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"IRAQ WAR","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"INTELLIGENCE SERVICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"INTERVIEWS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"MARKET DEMOGRAPHICS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"UNITED KINGDOM","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"54"},{"name":"TONY BLAIR","domains":["PEO"],"score":"67"},{"name":"NIGEL FARAGE","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"890","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396228050&p=2kx&v=1&x=1ZETXtA0JFJQqbJB6uBKkA","id":"29396228050","content":"FOLLOWING DONALD TRUMP\u2019S inauguration, the newly appointed White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, lambasted journalists for what he claimed was \u201cdeliberately false reporting\u201d regarding the attendance figures at the ceremony. He declared: \u201cthis was the largest audience to ever witness an inauguration, period.\u201d\n\nThis was Spicer\u2019s first official press briefing and his lecturing tone to the attending press was rightly received both in a critical and ridiculing manner, particularly given his inaccurate claims on crowd size which were easily disproved through available aerial photographic evidence circulating on social media.\n\nTrump already circulating \u2018misinformation\u2019\n\nIt is alarming however, that despite such clear evidence confirming the disparity in numbers between former President Obama\u2019s first inauguration in 2009 and Trump\u2019s in 2017, Spicer (and more so the new regime) persisted in knowingly relaying incorrect information to the world\u2019s press, in an unashamedly and blatant attempt to reconstruct the truth.\n\nIn other words, circulating \u201cmisinformation\u201d. To compound such falsehoods, Trump\u2019s senior advisor Kellyanne Conway attempted to defend and spin such nonsensical statements by claiming Spicer \u201cgave alternative facts\u201d.\n\nOf late, the term \u201cmisinformation\u201d has become commonplace within the political arena, and is in itself a sad indictment of the way politics has developed and transitioned in recent years.\n\nBrexit propaganda\n\nThe Brexit propaganda machine utilised for the \u201cLeave\u201d side during last year\u2019s EU referendum campaign, which saw the UK electorate voting to leave the EU, aptly demonstrated the powerful effect misinformation can achieve if orchestrated to the right target audience.\n\nConservative MP Michael Gove, a talisman for the Vote \u201cLeave\u201d side had said during a Sky News interview before the vote that, \u201cBritain has had enough of experts.\u201d Such rhetoric was clearly unsubstantiated but utilised to fuel doubts about the role of experts and their societal importance.\n\nFormer UKIP Leader Nigel Farage admitted the day after the shock result, that it was a \u201cmistake\u201d to promise that £350 million a week would be spent on the NHS if the UK backed a Brexit vote, after this monumental funding pledge had been used as a key influencing tactic throughout the campaign.\n\nThe deliberate propagation of ignorance\n\nKellyanne Conway gets ready to go on television outside the White House, January 22 2017. \n\nTony Blair apologised publically last year following the damning report from the Chilcot inquiry, which heavily criticised Blair for his decision to lead Britain to war in Iraq in 2003. The report noted that Blair had exaggerated the case for war in Iraq and that Britain\u2019s intelligence agencies produced \u201cflawed information\u201d.\n\nThe above examples, to name but a few, demonstrate that the use of covert misinformation is not a new phenomenon and has been the subject of much research in previous decades. One prominent expert on this topic is Robert Proctor, a science historian at Standford University, who coined the word \u201cagnotology\u201d to describe the study of \u201cdeliberate propagation of ignorance\u201d.\n\nProctor\u2019s initial research into the so-called study of \u201cagnotology\u201d arose from the communicative tactics Big Tobacco companies deployed in the 1970s, to allegedly create doubt in the minds of the public about the harmful effects of smoking. Such confusion and deceit was aimed at obscuring the facts for the benefit of the ever lucrative tobacco industry.\n\nIn a more modern context, occasional dissenting and unverified data reports that question the validity of legitimate facts relating to climate change and the imminent need for protective measures, could be linked with such deliberate dissemination of mass ignorance for unscrupulous corporate gain.\n\nGlobal brands use covert propaganda\n\nLarge-scale corporate self-interest enables global companies and brands to fund mass manipulative propaganda in a more covert and sophisticated manner than ever before.\n\nThrough the creation of biased think-tanks that have the potential to influence policy or through the promotion of online bloggers who gain financially for their impartial support of industry positions or products, all play an important role in shaping public opinion and swaying the political agenda.\n\nThere is little doubt that Trump is unlike most modern day politicians and he has prided himself on being a businessman first. This exception to the rule can be attractive for some of the electorate who have grown tired or apathetic towards the political elite.\n\nWhat is most unusual however, is that in the past such misinformation was carried out in a disguised and guarded fashion as to avoid unwanted detection or scrutiny by the media or various interest groups.\n\nOpenly altering the truth\n\nOn the contrary, the attempt to overtly contradict clear evidence of previous crowd data as done this week by the new Trump team, sends a powerful message that the truth may be challenged and facts altered to suit Trump\u2019s manifesto and future policies.\n\nIt can be quite innocuous where the truth is openly altered for something as irrelevant as mere crowd numbers, but can be fatal when orchestrated for acts to justify war or the use of nuclear weapons.\n\nIt is a worrying time for world politics and international affairs. There is now an even greater need for journalistic endeavour to uphold the truth and maintain ethical integrity.\n\nSimilarly, an even greater role must be placed on all citizens to ensure they take responsibility for their civic duties in questioning such misinformation and seeking the truth, where possible, to ensure that justice and liberty prevail in these turbulent times.\n\nJason O\u2019 Sullivan, is a solicitor and public affairs consultant at JOS Solicitors.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Jason O'Sullivan"},"topics":[],"title":"Alternative facts: 'Trump sent a powerful message that facts can be altered to suit his own agenda'","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","countryCode":"IE","country":"Ireland"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"TheJournal.ie","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"175383370","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"286"},"name":"TheJournal.ie","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thejournal.ie"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://jossolicitors.ie/"],"sequenceId":"695205073377","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:15Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://img2.thejournal.ie/article/3207199/river/?height=400&version=3207276"}],"video":[]}}

the anniversary of the day she became Queen  - Elizabeth II will have reigned for 65 years. \n \nBut there are no grand festivities planned to mark the head-of-state's new milestone. \n \nThe Queen is, at this stage, not due to be out and about on official engagements on the landmark day.  \n \nThe sovereign, who missed church over Christmas due to a heavy cold, will undoubtedly be matter of fact about this historic occasion. \n \nIn 2015, when she thanked the nation for its kind messages after overtaking Queen Victoria to become the longest-reigning monarch in British history, she admitted bluntly that the royal record was ''not one to which I have ever aspired''. \n \nShe added: \"Inevitably, a long life can pass by many milestones. My own is no exception.\" \n \nThe Queen celebrated her 90th birthday last year and had a busy schedule commemorating the occasion, with a walkabout, beacon lighting and a black tie dinner for family and friends in Windsor on her actual birthday. \n \nA weekend of national celebrations, including a party on The Mall, was held for her official birthday in June. \n   \nIt is likely that any large-scale jubilee celebrations will be reserved for the Platinum Jubilee in 2022 - although any events will take into account the fact that Queen is due to turn 96 that year. \n \nThe Duke of Cambridge is about to become a full-time royal this summer and will increase his official duties on behalf of the Queen. William and the Duchess of Cambridge are carrying out an engagement on Monday February 6, but not to do with the Queen's record-breaking reign. \n \nThey will be attending Place2Be's Big Assembly at a primary school in north London to mark Children's Mental Health Week. \n \nThe anniversary of Elizabeth II's accession to the throne in 1952 is a poignant time for the Queen, marking the day her father George VI died. \n \nShe often spends Accession Day privately at Sandringham, having staying there through the Christmas period. She usually makes her return to Buckingham Palace a few days later. \n \nRoyal gun salutes will be staged in London on February 6, as is the tradition. \n \nA 41-gun salute will be fired by the King's Troop Royal Horse Artillery in Green Park at noon, \n \nThe Band of the Royal Artillery will play a selection of celebratory music close to the firing position, and 89 horses will pull six First World War-era 13-pounder field guns into position in the park. \n \nA 62-gun salute by the Honourable Artillery Company will be fired at the Tower of London at 1pm.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Finance latest","group":"Finance"}],"title":"Queen to reach Sapphire Jubilee","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","countryCode":"GB","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"AOL UK","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169662251","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"AOL UK","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Financials"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.aol.co.uk"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695205075875","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:14Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:18Z","duplicateGroupId":"29382748814","companies":[{"symbol":"CTHZ","primary":true,"name":"Cancer Treatment Holdings Inc","contentCount":1,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US1373893007"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BUDGET PLANNING & MANAGEMENT","domains":["IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"INSURANCE RATE REGULATION","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"INSURANCE PREMIUMS","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"GOVERNMENT BUDGETS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"US REPUBLICAN PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MEN'S HEALTH","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"PROSTATE CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"US STATE GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PROSTATE DISEASE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"BUDGET PROPOSALS","domains":["IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"US DEMOCRATIC PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"GOVERNORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"HEALTH INSURANCE","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CANCER","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ACADEMIC MEDICAL CENTERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LIFE FORMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"65"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; MINNESOTA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"MARK DAYTON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BILL CLINTON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"1040","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396228475&p=2kx&v=1&x=4apyV0QiFQsVvKQm56YN1w","id":"29396228475","content":"ST. PAUL \u2014 Gov. Mark Dayton is ready for the Capitol to return to its normal level of bickering, chaos and policy after telling the state he had cancer and fainting in front of a statewide audience last week. \n \n\u201cNow, it\u2019s back to business to usual,\u201d the Democratic-Farmer-Labor governor said Wednesday. \n \n\u201cBusiness as usual\u201d included defending his $46 billion two-year budget proposal, signing a long-awaited health insurance premium relief bill and hosting a water summit in Morris, Minn. But it also included a trip to Rochester\u2019s Mayo Clinic, well-wishes from former President Bill Clinton and repeated defenses that he can \u2014 and will \u2014 perform the job the state elected him to do. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m intellectually in my prime and I\u2019m physically capable of doing the job. And I\u2019ve done the job. I haven\u2019t had a vacation in almost two years,\u201d the governor said. \u201cI know I\u2019m fit for the job.\u201d \n \nThe split screen may last throughout what is expected to be a brutal legislative session, dominated by battles between Republicans and the Democratic governor on how much of the state\u2019s cash to spend. Dayton, who turned 70 on Thursday, pledges he will stay as involved in that fight as he ever was and legislators, while sympathizing with his health issues, will stand firm in return. \n \nLawmakers last week already added some humanity to their normal legislative process. \n \n\u201cI think maybe it humanized our relationships a little more,\u201d said House Speaker Kurt Daudt, a Republican from near Crown. \u201cI think it helps us see him, and have a more personal relationship.\u201d \n \nWhen Republican legislative leaders reacted to Dayton\u2019s budget plans \u2014 too rich, by far, for many in the GOP \u2014 they expressed concern about the governor before they began their critique. The Minnesota Senate on Thursday paused after passing the $325 million insurance measure to acknowledge Dayton\u2019s health concerns and sing \u201cHappy Birthday\u201d to him. And Alexandria Rep. Mary Franson, a Republican who is generally not a fan of Dayton\u2019s policies, sent the governor flowers after his Monday collapse. \n \n\u201cMy heart just went out to the governor; what happened to him was on live television. \u2026 My model is practice kindness, and what a way to show compassion and kindness,\u201d she said. \u201cWe can disagree about policies, but that does not negate the fact that we are human beings.\u201d \n \nOTHER STATES \n \nDayton felt the need to announce his prostate cancer diagnosis Tuesday because of his dramatic tumble 40 minutes into his State of the State speech. He had fainted, he and his medical providers at the Mayo Clinic said. The collapse, which happened in a House chamber packed with lawmakers, state officials and watching Minnesotans, was \u201crelated to standing for a long time while giving his speech and possible dehydration,\u201d the clinic said. \n \nAlthough he had told close staff and advisers of the diagnosis, he had planned to release it more publicly after he consulted with his doctors on the course of treatment. \n \nThat\u2019s the route other governors have taken. \n \nLast year, both Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf and Alaska Gov. Bill Walker disclosed to their states that they had been diagnosed with prostate cancer, a common ailment among older men. \n \nWhen Wolf announced it, he was \u201cunclear about the exact course of treatment he will undergo, he said it wouldn\u2019t require surgery or involve chemotherapy,\u201d according to a news report. Walker, surrounded by his family, shared the news of his cancer at the same time he said that he would have surgery to treat it. \n \nIn neither of those states did the cancer news change the political dynamics at play. Both of those governors took some time away from the public eye and then returned to work. \n \n\u201cThe mood really did not change,\u201d said Jan Murphy, capitol bureau chief for Pennlive and the Patriot-News in Pennsylvania. \u201cWe have other issues that are occupying our lawmakers\u2019 attention these days.\u201d \n \nIn Alaska, the governor was out of commission for about a week. While there was an outpouring of well-wishes, like there has been in Minnesota, the cancer news and treatment did not change the mood. \n \n\u201cThere has been no difference whatsoever in the way anyone has treated anyone,\u201d said Nathaniel Herz, a reporter for the Alaska Dispatch News. \u201cIt was almost sort of like a one-day distraction and then everyone moved on.\u201d \n \nDayton has long been dogged by speculation that he might prematurely quit his political life. The fainting spell and the cancer diagnosis, though, may have brought more attention to his health than other governors have experienced. \n \nWHAT\u2019S NEXT? \n \nDayton aggressively returned to work, despite the health issues. \n \nOn Tuesday, the day after he fainted and before he announced his cancer, he strode to a Capitol podium to promote his budget plans. Although the governor, who has had hip and back surgeries while in office, appeared slightly winded when he began speaking, he gained steam as the hourlong unveiling went on. \n \nHe also kept up a schedule of public appearances \u2014 including a Wednesday morning speech to an educators conference and a Wednesday evening reception with lawmakers \u2014 throughout the week before capping it off with travel to Morris, nearly three hours outside of the Twin Cities, to talk about water. He also was to appear on live television shows on Friday and Sunday. \n \nIn the coming weeks, Dayton has said, other than a trip to the Mayo Clinic to talk cancer treatment, it will be more of the same. He has dozens of meetings scheduled with state officials and others for the first week of February as well as speaking engagements. \n \nDespite his appreciation of the expressions of concern from legislators across the aisle, Dayton said he does not think his ailments will have a lasting effect on the tone of the negotiations. \n \n\u201cI\u2019d like to believe they would all just agree to my budget now. It\u2019s just common courtesy,\u201d he joked. \u201cNo, it\u2019ll go down the same.\u201d \n \n\u201cI have my mandate, and they got elected recently and they have their mandate,\u201d he said of Republicans who control the Legislature. \u201cThey\u2019re very different perspectives on what\u2019s best for Minnesota. We have very genuine, very deep-seated and very sincere differences. But I\u2019m not going to back down on what I believe is best for Minnesota, and I expect them to do the same.\u201d","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"}],"title":"With health in the spotlight, Dayton seeks return to normalcy","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Montgomery","zipCode":"19034","state":"Pennsylvania","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Fort Washington","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Montgomery Life","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"355125383","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Montgomery Life","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://montgomerynews.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695205077361","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:18Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

On Thursday\u2019s Morning Drive on the Golf Channel, live at the Orange County Convention Center, the STAR EV Sirius took center stage along with big industry names like Club Car, E-Z-Go, and Garia. \n \nAlthough primarily associated with golf, the golf car industry now encompasses a wide range of small vehicles from LSVs (a street legal low-speed vehicle) to utility vehicles to the classic golf course companion. STAR EV kept the golf course-to-neighborhood overlap in mind with the ground-up creation of the new Sirius model, which boasts automotive conveniences like an electronic locking trunk, USB port, LED illuminated dashboard, and self-cancelling turn signals. But it is still golf course worthy, with optional golf ball holder inserts, and a large bagwell, or the option of a 2-in-1 Combo Seat (a patented design that turns a rear seat into a golf bag holder without tools). \n \nSTAR EV revealed two prototypes at its PGA show exhibit; a standard Sirius with 2-in-1 Combo Seat, and a \u201ctricked-out\u201d version to show how customizable the Sirius will be. The front trunk gives the golf car the look of a hood that can be painted a different color from the main body, like the sleek matte black trunk on the deep metallic maroon prototype. STAR EV also offers a variety of wheels, with rim finishes in machined aluminum, matte black, dura chrome, black PVD, and special color accents. \n \nWhile the models at the show were standard 2 and 4-passenger vehicles, the Sirius line will expand to include 6 and 8 passenger models like the STAR EV Classic. As all STAR\u2019s vehicles, the Sirius is 100% electric with a 4 kW AC motor, 350 A Curtis AC controller, and can travel at a top speed of 19.5 mph. (The LSV version peaks at 25 mph.) Goals from Arjen Robben and David Alaba helped the Bundesliga leaders to secure the 14th win of the season, reports Xinhua news agency. \n \nThe \"Green-Whites\" started on a highly motivated note and kept the uninspired Bavarians busy. Yet, the hosts lacked in accuracy and wasted opportunities.  \n \nBayern increased their pressure at the half-hour mark and broke the deadlock out of the blue when Franck Ribery rushed down the left wing to pass into the box to find Robben, who poked home the opener with a one-timer into the bottom right with 31 minutes played. \n \nCarlo Ancelotti's men doubled the lead just before the break as David Alaba curled the ball over the wall into the top right corner following a free kick from 20 meters. \n \nAfter the restart, Bremen were able to reduce the arrears after Max Kruse overcame Manuel Neuer from close range in the 53rd minute. The hosts gained momentum but Bayern were able to protect their 2-1 lead to the end. \n \nWith the result, Bayern stay atop the standings with a three-point advantage whereas 15th-placed Bremen remain at the edge of the relegation zone. \n \nIn the other match, Leipzig wrapped up an important 2-1 comeback win over third-placed Hoffenheim, whose unbeaten streak ended.  \n \nTimo Werner and Marcel Sabitzer were on target to keep the \"Red Bulls\" on Bayern's heels. \n \nDespite being under pressure in the opening period, the visitors from Hoffenheim opened the scoring with 19 minutes into the game.  \n \nSebastian Rudy forced a turn over following a Leipzig corner, allowing Nadiem Amiri to complete a five-pass counter attack. \n \nLeipzig remained unimpressed and responded in the 38th minute as Timo Werner slotted home Naby Keita's build-up play to restore parity before the half time. \n \nAfter the restart, things went from bad to worse for the visitors as Sandro Wagner received his marching orders following a rude foul play on Stefan Ilsanker in the 60th minute. \n \nThe hosts capitalised on their numerical advantage and snatched the 2-1 winner through Marcel Sabitzer, who unleashed a 22-meter effort to beat Hoffenheim goalkeeper Oliver Baumann in the 77th minute. \n \nWith the 13th victory of the season, Leipzig remain second while Hoffenheim slipped from the third to fourth spot. \n \nElsewhere, Cologne crushed last-placed Darmstadt 6-1 thanks to Yuya Osako's brace. \n \nWolfsburg lost 2-1 to Augsburg while Ingolstadt shocked Hamburg 3-1 and Monchengladbach turned the tides from two goals down to beat Leverkusen 3-2. \n \n© 2017 IANS India Private Limited. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:20Z","duplicateGroupId":"29396228659","companies":[{"symbol":"IRON","primary":true,"name":"Egyptian Iron and Steel","contentCount":1,"exchange":"CAI","titleCount":1,"isin":"EGS3D061C015"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[],"wordCount":"34","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396228659&p=2kx&v=1&x=XBF0HqpUbNyzEz2QzrJ6Cw","id":"29396228659","content":"Jan 29 (Reuters) - Egyptian Iron And Steel Co \n \r \r \r \n* H1 net loss EGP 188.7 million versus net loss EGP 322.4\nmillion year ago \n \r \r \r \n* H1 net revenue EGP 805.3 million versus EGP 597.7 million\nyear ago\n\nSource: ( bit.ly/2kfGSQE )\nFurther company coverage:","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Steelmaking news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Stockwatch","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Earnings news","group":"Finance"},{"name":"Africa news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"North Africa news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Egypt news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"BRIEF-Egyptian Iron and Steel H1 loss narrows","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Southern Africa","countryCode":"ZA","country":"South Africa"},"editorialRank":"1","name":"Reuters Africa","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169591575","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"31"},"name":"Reuters Africa","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","Consumables"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://feeds.reuters.com/","publisher":"Thomson Reuters"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://bit.ly/2kfGSQE"],"sequenceId":"695205084850","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:20Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:25:27Z","duplicateGroupId":"29391385076","companies":[{"symbol":"7855","primary":true,"name":"Cardinal Co Ltd","contentCount":1,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3204800001"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CATHOLIC POPES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"CLERGY & RELIGIOUS VOCATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"93"},{"name":"INVESTIGATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"RELIGIOUS PILGRIMAGES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CONSERVATISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"71"},{"name":"CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"GAYS & LESBIANS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"RESIGNATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"ART DEALERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"63"},{"name":"ROME, ITALY; ITALY","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"MYANMAR","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"HOLY SEE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"POPE FRANCIS I","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1383","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396228660&p=2kx&v=1&x=ZgezL0vkoGWT3Sw4T9CCYg","id":"29396228660","content":"VATICAN CITY: On the afternoon of Jan. 24, a black BMW pulled out of a 16th century palace in Rome, crossed the Tiber River and headed for the Vatican, a short trip to end a brazen challenge to the authority of Pope Francis. \n \nInside the car was 67-year-old Englishman Matthew Festing, the head of an ancient Catholic order of knights which is now a worldwide charity with a unique diplomatic status. \n \nFesting was about to resign, the first leader in several centuries of the Order of Malta, which was founded in 1048 to provide medical aid for pilgrims in the Holy Land, to step down instead of ruling for life. \n \nThe move was aimed at ending a highly-public spat between Festing and the reformist pope over the running of the chivalric institution. The weeks-long conflict had become one of the biggest internal challenges yet to Francis' efforts to modernize the 1.2 billion member Roman Catholic Church. \n \nAt issue was the Order's reaction to the discovery that condoms had been distributed by one of its aid projects in Myanmar. The Order had fired its Grand Chancellor, Albrecht Freiherr von Boeselager, whom it held responsible for the condom distribution. Von Boeselager declined to comment for this article. \n \nThough condom use goes against Catholic teaching, the Vatican had ordered an investigation into the firing of von Boeselager. It subsequently publicly castigated Festing, who had refused to cooperate with the investigation. \n \nBacking down, Festing, a former Sotheby's art auctioneer, gave a hand-written resignation letter to Francis in the pope's private residence, according to a senior Vatican source. Festing, who has the title of prince, declined an interview request. \n \nInstead of quelling the conflict, however, Festing's resignation was followed by yet another challenge to Francis' authority - led by vocal pope critic American Cardinal Raymond Leo Burke, according to Vatican and Knights sources. \n \nIn particular: Burke tried to convince Festing to withdraw his resignation and keep fighting the pope, these sources say. On Saturday, the Knight's Sovereign Council accepted Festing's resignation and re-instated von Boselager, a clear defeat for Burke. \n \nBurke declined to comment for this article. \n \nThe tussle suggested Francis is still battling to consolidate his power over the Church almost four years into his tenure, Vatican insiders say. \n \nBeyond a fight over condoms, the clash pointed to lingering divisions between the Church's conservatives and more progressive factions who support the pope's reformist agenda, they add. \n \nFrancis is trying to make the Church less dogmatic and more welcoming to whose who have felt excluded, such as homosexuals and the divorced. \n \n\"While this whole saga was an internal matter that probably should have stayed that way, it metamorphosed into a clash that showed the divide between conservatives and progressives,\" said Andrea Tornielli, author of several books on Pope Francis. \n \nThe Vatican declined to comment on the clash and on Pope Francis' efforts to consolidate his power. \n \nIt directed Reuters to two public statements. One, on Dec. 22, relates to the Vatican order to investigate the firing of von Boeselager. The second, on Jan. 17, followed a pledge by Festing on the Knights' web page not to cooperate with the Vatican. It decried his resistance and ordered members of the order to cooperate. \n \n    GERMAN ARISTOCRAT \n \nThe all-male top leaders of the Knights of Malta are not clerics, but they take vows of poverty, chastity and obedience to the pope. \n \nA German aristocrat whose father participated in a failed plot to kill Hitler in World War Two, von Boeselager was fired by Festing in December, and accused of having allowed the use of condoms while he was head of the Knights' global humanitarian projects. \n \nFesting fired him in Burke's presence, arguing that the German had hidden the condom use from the order's leaders when he was named Grand Chancellor, according to Knights and Vatican sources. \n \nImmediately, the firing set off the conflict between the Knights' hierarchy and the Vatican. \n \nVon Boeselager , a devout Catholic, said in a statement on Dec. 23 that he was fully behind Church teachings. He closed two projects in the developing world when he discovered condoms were being distributed but kept a third running in Myanmar for a while because closing it would have abruptly ended all basic medical services to poor people. \n \nThe Church does not allow condoms as a means of birth control and says abstinence and monogamy in heterosexual marriage is the best way to stop the spread of AIDS. \n \n    In the same statement, von Boeselager said Festing and Burke told him the Vatican wanted him to resign and that there would be \"severe consequences\" for the Order if he did not. \n \nThe Vatican denied, in a letter from its secretary of state to the Order and seen by Reuters, that it had mandated the resignation, saying it had told the Knights the pope wanted a solution through dialogue. \n \nThe German said his sacking was against the Knights' constitution and appealed to the pope, who ordered the investigation. \n \nFesting refused to cooperate, issuing a series of increasingly strident public statements. In one, he called the papal commission that was investigating the firing \"legally irrelevant\". \n \nIn a Jan. 14 confidential letter to the top echelons of the order and seen by Reuters, Festing wrote: \"In refusing to acknowledge this group of people's jurisdiction, I am trying to protect the order's sovereignty\". \n \nThe institution has the status of a sovereign entity, maintaining diplomatic relations with over 100 states and the European Union and permanent observer status at the United Nations. \n \nThe pope was irritated by Festing's defiant stand, a senior Vatican source said, and the Vatican shot back with a public statement ordering the Knights to obey. \n \nAfter that public order, Festing changed his tune and resigned in the pope's residence a week later. \n \nFesting's resignation came as a shock for many inside the Knights: some of them told Reuters it was akin to the resignation of Pope Benedict in 2013. \n \nFour sources said that for many others in the order, it came as a relief. They feared the clash was damaging the image of the institution whose 13,000 members, 80,000 volunteers and 20,000 paid medical staff help the neediest around the world. \n \nThe day after Festing handed his resignation to the pope, Cardinal Burke drove to the order's headquarters from his apartment near the Vatican and sought to persuade Festing to withdraw his resignation, a source from the Vatican and one from the Knights said. \n \nBurke declined to comment on his meeting with Festing. \n \nBurke has long been leading challenges against the pope. Pope Francis demoted him from a top Vatican job in 2014 with no official explanation and assigned him to be the \"patron\" of the Order of Malta. \n \nSuch \"patron\" positions are usually given to older cardinals after they retire at 75. Burke was only 66 then and the demotion was widely seen as a sign of the pope's irritation with the cardinal's constant sniping over Francis\u2019 reforms. \n \nIn particular, Burke has contested moves by the pope that would allow Catholics who have divorced and re-married outside the Church without an annulment to return to the sacrament of communion. Burke declined to comment on his demotion. \n \nSince the demotion, Burke has become even more of a rallying point for conservatives, flying around the world to give lectures to conservative groups and often giving interviews criticising the pope's decisions. \n \nIn November, he led a rare public challenge to the pope with three other cardinals who accused the pontiff of sowing confusion on important moral issues such as that of communion for the divorced. \n \nBurke later said in an interview that if the pope did not respond to their letter, the cardinals might need to \"correct\" the pope themselves for the good of the Church. \n \nThe Vatican did not comment on the uprising at the time but many of the pope's supporters publicly criticised the four cardinals. \n \nThe pope will now appoint a \"pontifical delegate\" to help run the order, at least until elections can be held for a new Grand Master. \n \nIn a personal letter to the Sovereign Council on Jan. 27 and seen by Reuters, Francis made clear that the Vatican did not want to interfere with the Order's sovereignty but said his delegate would seek to \"renew the spirituality of the Order, specifically of those members who take vows.\" \n \n(Editing by Mark Bendeich, Philippa Fletcher and Alessandra Galloni)","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Malta news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Italy news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Religion news","group":"Society"}],"title":"The Knights of Malta-Vatican feud - students study Zebrafish for medical uses. \n   \nCarson, CA (PRWEB)  January 29, 2017 \n \nCalifornia State University, Dominguez Hills (CSUDH) has been ranked 4th among all California colleges and 18th nationally out of 2,137 colleges in the \u201c Overall Mobility Index \u201d of students category in a comprehensive report released Jan. 18 by The Equity of Opportunity Project . \n \nThis category reflects both access and outcomes, representing the likelihood that a student at CSUDH would move up two or more \u201cincome quintiles.\u201d The university was also ranked 8th out of 369 \u201cselective public colleges\u201d nationally in the category, and 2nd in the 23-campus California State University (CSU) system behind CSU Los Angeles. \n \nThe report and all its categories were made easily searchable online by the New York Times . The report was also featured by Times columnist David Leonhardt in his piece \u201cAmerica\u2019s Great Working-Class Colleges.\u201d \n \n\u201cThis New York Times article is a welcome validation for the great work all of you [CSUDH campus community] are involved in every day,\u201d said university President Willie J. Hagan, who quoted the column. \u201cYou should all be very proud to count yourselves among the \u2018deeply impressive institutions that continue to push many Americans into the middle class and beyond\u2014many more, in fact, than elite colleges that receive far more attention.\u2019\u201d \n \nThe mobility rates were defined as the percentage of its students who come from a family in the bottom fifth of the income distribution, and end up in the top fifth of the income distribution. The report found that some universities, such as CSUDH, with a much larger percentage of students from low-income families, have very high mobility rates, and high earnings outcomes that are closely comparable to students at highly selective colleges. \n \nThe Equity of Opportunity Project\u2019s findings were derived from 30 million college students. The data was compiled from statistics on students\u2019 earnings and their parents\u2019 incomes for each college in the United States. \n \nAbout CSU Dominguez Hills -- With a student population of nearly 15,000, many who are first in their families to attend college, CSU Dominguez Hills provides high quality academic programs to students who aspire to succeed and thrive in a complex, global society. A leader in fostering a college-focused culture in the urban communities it serves, the university offers a proven path to opportunity and social equity and is a national laboratory and model for student access and success. However, the target of 93.236 could not be achieved. \n \n\"The generation in the month of November was almost on track as there is not much difference in the actual output and target. But power generation is 1.8 BUs short of the targetted output in December,\" said an expert. \n \nAccording to the CEA data, the per capita consumption of electricity was 1,075 units in 2015-16 as per provisional estimates. Hollywood producers named\nthe musical \"La La Land\" the best film of 2016 on Saturday at a\nceremony marked by criticism of President Donald Trump's\nimmigration policies. \n \r \r \r \nThe big win by \"La La Land\" at the 28th annual awards set up\n the film, which stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, as an\nodds-on Oscar favorite, after it scored a record-tying 14 Oscar\nnominations earlier this month. \n \r \r \r \nThe Producers Guild of America (PGA), which is among the\nleading industry organizations representing makers of movies and\nTV shows, also named its best animated film which went to\n\"Zootopia,\" favorite documentary, won by \"O.J.: Made in America\"\n and honored Netflix's \"Stranger Things\" as the top television\ndrama. \n \r \r \r \nMusician John Legend, a star of \"La La Land\", criticized the\nnew president's executive order placing curbs on people arriving\nin the United States from certain Muslim-majority countries,\nwhich spawned protests and confusion at several U.S. airports on\nSaturday. \"We encourage everybody out there to speak out against\nit,\" Legend said. \n \r \r \r \nLater, introducing the splashy, colorful musical film,\nLegend said \"Our vision of America is directly antithetical to\nthat of President Trump. I want to specifically tonight reject\nhis vision and affirm that America has to be better than that.\" \n \r \r \r \nAccepting the award, \"La La Land\" producer Marc Platt\ncontinued in a similar vein, saying \"It is the power of cinema\nfueled by free artistic expression that cannot be denied, that\nhas no borders, and will never be banned from our hearts, our\nminds and our souls.\" \n \r \r \r \nIn past years, PGA best film winners have often gone on to\nwin the best picture Oscar, Hollywood's big prize. \n \r \r \r \nAmong other honors for television productions, two FX shows\nprevailed, as another look at the famous O.J. TRUMP","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1095","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29396228715&p=2kx&v=1&x=Hh3AzIDelcIabutpwNQK_g","id":"29396228715","content":"President Donald Trump's order to restrict people from seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the United States sparked confusion and anger on Saturday after immigrants and refugees were kept off flights and left stranded in airports. \n\nIn his most sweeping decision since taking office a week ago, Trump, a Republican, put a four-month hold on allowing refugees into the United States and temporarily barred travelers from Syria and six other countries. \n\nCivil rights and faith groups, activists and Democratic politicians were furious and vowed to fight the order. \n \nCapping a day of confusion and chaos and protests in several airports across the country, a federal judge in Brooklyn, New York, granted a temporary reprieve. The American Civil Liberties Union successfully argued for a temporary stay that allowed detained travelers to stay in the United States. \n \nSupporters outside the Brooklyn courtroom and at protests at airports in Dallas, Chicago, New York and elsewhere cheered the decision, but a bigger fight lay ahead. \n \nThe court action does not reverse Trump's order, which was criticized by some of America's closest allies. \n \nTrump, a businessman who successfully tapped into American fears about terror attacks during his campaign, had promised what he called \"extreme vetting\" of immigrants and refugees from areas the White House said the U.S. Congress deemed to be high risk. \n \nHe told reporters in the White House's Oval Office on Saturday that his order was \"not a Muslim ban\" and said the measures were long overdue. \n \n\"It's working out very nicely. You see it at the airports, you see it all over,\" Trump said. \n \nAlong with Syria, the ban affects travelers with passports from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. \n \n\n\n \nThe Department of Homeland Security said about 375 travelers had been affected by the order, 109 of whom were in transit and were denied entry to the United States. Another 173 were stopped by airlines before boarding. \n \nThe order \"affects a minor portion of international travelers,\" the department said in a statement, saying the measures \"inconvenienced\" less than 1 percent of travelers. \n \nThe new rules blindsided people in transit and families waiting for them, and caused havoc for businesses with employees holding passports from the targeted nations and colleges with international students. \n \nPegah Rahmani, 25, waited at Washington's Dulles airport for several hours for her grandparents, both Iranian citizens with U.S. green cards. \"They weren't treating them very well,\" she said. \n \nRahmani's grandfather is 88 and legally blind. Her grandmother is 83 and recently had a stroke. They were released to loud cheers and cries. \n \nSeveral Democratic governors said they were examining whether they could launch legal challenges, and other groups eyed a constitutional challenge claiming religious discrimination. \n \n\"I don't think anyone is going to take this lying down,\" said Cleveland immigration lawyer David Leopold. \"This is the tip of the spear and more litigation is coming.\" \n \nThe White House did not respond immediately to a request for comment. \n \nThe Department of Homeland Security said the order would stay in place. \n \n\"No foreign national in a foreign land, without ties to the United States, has any unfettered right to demand entry into the United States,\" the department statement said. \n \nMark Krikorian, the director of the conservative Center for Immigration Studies, called lawsuits challenging the order \"last ditch efforts\" that would only apply to a few individuals, and he said a broader constitutional argument would be hard to win. \n \n\"The first amendment doesn't apply to foreigners living abroad. The law explicitly says the president can exclude any person or class of people he wants,\" Krikorian said. \n \nSome leaders from the U.S. technology industry, a major employer of foreign workers, issued warnings to their staff and called the order immoral and un-American. \n \n\"This ban will impact many innocent people,\" said Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber Technologies Inc, who said he would raise the issue at a White House meeting on Friday. \n \nArab travelers in the Middle East and North Africa said the order was humiliating and discriminatory. Iran vowed to retaliate. \n \nSudan called the action \"very unfortunate\" after Washington lifted sanctions on the country just weeks ago for cooperation on combating terrorism. A Yemeni official expressed dismay at the ban. \n \nIraq's former ambassador to the United States, Lukman Faily, told Reuters that Trump's ban was unfair to a country that itself has been a victim of terror attacks, and could backfire. \n \n\"We have a strong partnership with U.S., more so in the urgent fight against terrorism. This ban move will not help, and people will start questioning the bond of this partnership, Faily said. \n \nAllies in the United Kingdom, France and Germany were critical. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau tweeted a photo of himself welcoming Syrian refugees. \n \nConfusion abounded at airports as immigration and customs officials struggled to interpret the new rules. Some legal residents with green cards who were in the air when the order was issued were detained at airports upon arrival. \n \nHowever, senior administration officials said it would have been \"reckless\" to broadcast details of the order in advance. Other officials said green card holders from the affected countries would require extra screening and would be cleared on a case-by-case basis. < \n \n\n\np>Airlines were blindsided and some cabin crew were barred from entering the country. \nTravelers were handled differently at different points of entry and immigration lawyers advised clients to change their destination to the more lenient airports, said Houston immigration lawyer Mana Yegani. \n \nAt Chicago O\u2019Hare International Airport, brothers Bardia and Ayden Noohi waited for four hours for their father Kasra Noohi - who has an Iranian passport and a U.S. green card - to be allowed through. \n \nThey knew Trump had pledged tougher rules but did not expect the problems. \"I didn\u2019t think he\u2019d actually do it,\" Bardia Noohi, 32, said. \"A lot of politicians just talk.\" \n \nThousands of refugees seeking entry were thrown into limbo. Melanie Nezer of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society said she knew of roughly 2,000 who were booked to come to the United States next week. \n \nTrump's order indefinitely bans refugees from Syria. In a television interview, he said he would seek to prioritize Christian refugees fleeing the war-torn country. \n \nU.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they were not consulted on the action and in some cases only learned the details as they were made public. \n \nAt the State Department, a senior official said lawyers were working to interpret the executive order, which allows entry to people affected by the order when it is in the \"national interest.\" \n \nHowever, a federal law enforcement official said: \"It's unclear at this point what the threshold of national interest is.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Religion news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Iran news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Middle East news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Chaos, anger as Trump ban halts Muslim immigrants","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Sify","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657349","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"9"},"name":"Sify","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.sify.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695205090903","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:21Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Photo: Kate Geraghty \n  \nSchool students across NSW will sweat through their first days back at school, with scorching temperatures tipped to reach 42 degrees in Penrith and Richmond on Monday. \n \nThe extreme heat will continue on Monday night through to Tuesday before an afternoon cool change brings some relief. \n \n\"It's going to be a hot start to the school year,\" Bureau of Meteorology duty forecaster Rob Taggart said. \"Dropping off the kids, it's going to feel pretty warm and humid.\" \n \nWhile a sea breeze will keep Sydney's predicted maximum to a comparatively mild 32 degrees on Monday, Richmond is poised to break an all-time record with a sixth January day above 40 degrees. \n \nThere will be no relief on Monday night with temperatures in the west still hovering around or even above 30 degrees at midnight, Mr Taggart said. \n \nCompounding the heat is a \"widespread severe fire danger\" in southern NSW and far western NSW on Monday, with a \"very high fire danger\" for Sydney and the Hunter region, Mr Taggart said. \n \nIn central and south-western parts of state, last year's floods have left the region vulnerable to grass fires . \n \n\"Grass fuel loads are pretty high because of all that rainfall,\" Mr Taggart said. \"The grass is pretty brown and there's a lot of it. It's ready and waiting to go.\" \n \nThe state's maximum temperature is expected in Wilcannia, with a blistering top of 46 degrees.  \n \nThe three-day heatwave forecast for Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Photo: Bureau of Meteorology \n  \nIf this January has seemed hotter and drier than usual, that's because it has been - especially at night. \n \nMaximum daytime temperatures in Sydney last January averaged 27.4 degrees. This January has so far averaged 29.1 degrees, which should rise with two more hot days to end the month. \n \nMeanwhile, Sydney has smashed the previous record for hot nights in January, with four nights (so far) staying above 24 degrees. The previous record was two. \n \nSydney is on track to break the record for the number of summer days above 35 degrees, with just two more needed to break the all-time record \n \nMr Taggart said this January has been \"almost certainly one of the hottest on record\". \n \nAnd the heat won't end this week. Next weekend is forecast to again hit 40 degrees, Mr Taggart said, as the Bureau forecasts a \"hotter than average\" February with hot conditions pushing into March. \n \nJanuary is also likely to end with less than half the month's average rainfall. So far the city has had 48.8mm, much lower than the average of 102.5mm. \n \nIt's also significantly less than last year when Sydney received 249.8mm during January. \n \nElsewhere in the state, Moree is in the middle of a remarkable hot streak, with the town sweltering through 34 consecutive days above 35 degrees. Mr Taggart expects that to stretch to 41 days based on current forecasts, close to the state record. \n \n\"The forecast for the next seven days is pretty horrific,\" Mr Taggart said. \"That heat is completely unrelenting.\" \n \n\"The forecast seems bad for Richmond and Sydney, but it's nothing compared to Moree.\" \n \nThe story first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald .","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Josh Dye"},"topics":[{"name":"Weather news","group":"Science"},{"name":"Oceania latest","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"NSW weather: Heatwave, severe fire danger as students return to school","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"4812","state":"Queensland","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Hyde Park","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"North Queensland Register","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"170597955","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"North Queensland Register","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.northqueenslandregister.com.au"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695205091073","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:05:24Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:21Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://nnimgt-a.akamaihd.net/transform/v1/crop/frm/silverstone-feed-data/b1388d02-e7af-480c-8629-bb881cc357f5.jpg/r0_0_727_410_w600_h338_fmax.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

\n  \nSITTING in a tree and getting a bird\u2019s eye view of your property is one way to go about planning how you will design your future home. \n \nOr at least that was the trick Doug MacDonald used for 25-27 Forest Ridge , Bonogin . \n \nThe prominent builder behind some of the Gold Coast\u2019s most beautiful and unique homes teamed up with his interior-stylist wife Terri-Lee to create his own family home. \n \nThe home was designed to maximise privacy while remaining an eye-catching spectacle. \n \nArmed with a specific set of plans and with the help of architect Jared Poole, the director from HA Building built his dream home in 10 months. \n \n\u201cWe bought the land six years ago,\u201d Mr MacDonald said. \u201cWe had it for a year and constantly mulled over how we would build our dream home. \n \nAn eye-catching design. \n  \n\u201cI would come up to the block in the afternoons and sit in one of the trees on the property to get a feel for the landscape. \n \n\u201cWe ended up building the neighbour\u2019s house which was very fortunate because we could design it so it wouldn\u2019t spoil our privacy and would fit into the style of its surroundings and not just be another average home.\u201d \n \nPoised on an elevated block, the 574sq m concrete and steel residence was inspired by native bushland. \n \nLandscaping was important. \n  \nPlaying with colours and raw materials as well as taking ideas from indigenous flora and fauna, Mr MacDonald said he wanted the home to become one with the land. \n \n\u201cTerri-Lee and I love acreage so we wanted to make the best use of the space,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cIt is a very industrial design and the materials connect with the bush landscape. \n \n\u201cIt is very open and light, and because it is a sloped block the home is on three levels. But it is still quite flat because of the split elevation.\u201d \n \nThe frameless glass door entry opens to reveal polished concrete floors, 4.5m ceilings and enormous glass windows that capture ocean and forest views. \n \n\u201cConcrete and timber doesn\u2019t age,\u201d Mr MacDonald said. \n \n\u201cTrends in homes change all the time so we stuck to a style that wouldn\u2019t go out of fashion. \n \nBuilding materials connect with the bush landscape. \n  \n\u201cThere are rust-style features which are actually just painted plastic to look authentic. \n \n\u201cIt took me three months to paint the rusted iron style feature around the stairs but it is more sustainable and durable that way. We wanted something that would last, especially since we have four children.\u201d \n \nMr MacDonald said the property overlooked a nice sunset but he described the morning sunrise as magic. \n \n\u201cIt is a cracker of a sky,\u201d he said. \n \nThe home is listed for offers over $2.35 million, through Nicole Carter and Russel Segal at RE/MAX Regency, Gold Coast","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Hannah Sbeghen"},"topics":[{"name":"Real estate news","group":"Industry"},{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Architecture and design news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Owner designs dream family home from treetop vision","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","countryCode":"AU","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Realestate.com.au","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"279204395","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Realestate.com.au","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Professional","RealEstate"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://realestate.com.au"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695205094029","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:25:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T08:34:22Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
